DEBATE.TITLE: FREEDOM OF INFORMATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 16 October.
Consideration of Senate's amendments.
Senate's amendments-
No. 1-Page 4, paragraphs 10 (b) and (c), lines 7 to 11, leave out the paragraphs.
No. 2-Pages 4 and 5, clause 11, line 12 (page 4) to line 21 (page 5), leave out the clause.
No. 3-Page 5, paragraph 13 (b), lines 29 to 33, leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:
``(b) by inserting in paragraph (3) (b) `or a person on whose behalf the application was made' after `applicant' (second occurring).''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate's amendments be agreed to.

The Senate has made four changes to the Freedom of Information Laws Amendment Bill 1986, having rejected the Government's request that the time for answering of freedom of information requests remain at 45 days. The existing statute provides for that period to be reduced to 30 days from 1 December. The Senate has rejected the proposed more stringent tests providing for the refusal of burdensome requests. It also wants to insert public interest as a mandatory consideration for remission of new application fees and broaden the criteria in relation to remission on the grounds of hardship and personal affairs. I am advised that these changes will affect the Budget to the extent of an increase in annual costs of $600,000 or a little less-say, $400,000.

The Government, of course, is not satisfied that the changes proposed by the Senate are justified and I want briefly to refer to our reasons. Reducing the time for answering requests to 30 days is likely to increase the cost to the taxpayer without substantial reductions in pro- cessing time. False expectations will be raised and the number of applications to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal on the basis of a deemed refusal will increase. It is not an answer just to say that agencies should respond more quickly. In many cases requests are for sensitive documents that require consultation with State or foreign authorities or businesses and the information cannot be obtained in the time suggested. It would be irresponsible to disclose potentially sensitive matter without proper consultation. The present Opposition, when in government, saw difficulties in a rigid timetable when it responded in 1981 to the 1979 Senate report. I think Senator Durack suggested then that there ought to be the opportunity to do this by regulation.

Another matter is why highly burdensome requests should be able to disrupt agency operations. As I mentioned earlier, some requests involve massive amounts of work and it is wrong to blame agencies alone for lengthy processing time. Agency processing efficiency has improved substantially since the FOI Act commenced, but it is irresponsible not to properly consider the consequences of disclosure of material. Agencies need protection against either deliberate or unintentional disruption of their work. Again, in response to the 1979 report of the Senate, the Opposition, when in government, rejected the work load test involving unreasonable burdens on agencies-in its terms-and it suggested tests of extreme burdens or considerable interference; in other words, much the same as the Government has now proposed.

Another matter is that the public interest should be considered in relation to the remission of charges and fees. We agree with that, but the issue is whether it should be mandatory. We do not think the consideration of public interest would be prevented by the Government's proposals; it is just that it would not be mandatory. It is always a question of balancing the benefits of access against costs. In practice, those claiming remission from cost on public interest grounds mostly tend to be the media, which operate commercially with tax deductions; members of parliament, who have other recognised avenues to information such as parliamentary questions, whether on notice or otherwise; and interest groups with a capacity to make some contribution.

I have already given examples of the enormous time spent in trivial areas in having to comply with requests. I made the point that a request for details of every item involved in the costs of ministerial travel was made by a former member, Mr Newman. It involved a cost of $40,000-odd to comply with that request. Why should one want to put everyone to that trouble with those details? The taxpayer has to pay that money. Why should not Mr Newman pay it? Somebody has to. If someone wants to do research on the Westinghouse project and wants every item of information made available, why should he not pay for it? Everyone can understand the justification for the information, but putting the cost on the taxpayer is not reason- able and is wrong.

The Government is in the position of either accepting or rejecting the amendments proposed by the Senate, with all the connotations that has for the Budget. We will accept them in the short term because we do not want to delay the Budget, but I make the point that we will be looking at what further savings we can achieve. We will need to make up the shortfall, so voluntary reporting of statistics on the use of secrecy provisions, administrative costs and the like may have to be discontinued, consistent with the proposals in the Bill for much reduced mandatory reporting of statistics.

Contrary to Press reports, the Government remains committed to freedom of information and we will continue to seek ways to make the legislation more efficient. The Government has made an enormous amount of information available to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, which is reviewing the operation and administration of the Freedom of Information Act. About 60 submissions to that Committee have already been made by agencies on their experiences. A detailed submission has been made by my Department on the operation and administration of the Act, including an extensive analysis of legal trends. The report of the interdepartmental committee on freedom of information costs was forwarded to that Committee. At present the Government has not had an opportunity to look at the report because it received it only recently. In addition, the Committee has three of the very detailed annual reports on freedom of information. The fourth report is expected by the end of November. The interdepartmental committee report has already pointed out the way to further improvements in the Freedom of Information Act, and the Government will consider the changes to the Bill requested by the Senate when it is considering that IDC report and any recommendations by the Senate Committee. But as I indicated, the Government reluctantly accepts the Bill as amended by the Senate because of the urgency of putting its other freedom of information Budget measures in place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has said that it supports freedom of information. Anybody who has looked at this Bill knows that that is false. I say that not to call the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) a liar-I would not do that-but it is an assertion which is demonstrably wrong. Let me go through the reasons the Government has given here today. It has complained about the additional cost of the amendments we proposed in this chamber and which were supported in the Senate by the Australian Democrats. The Attorney-General said that the additional cost will be in the order of $600,000. We all know how reliable the cost estimates of this Government are. The Attorney-General in his second reading speech referred to costs that would be recouped by the additional charges as being in the order of $4m. That, one might say, is a pretty straightforward statement. But, in talking about recoupment, he stated-this is recorded at page 909 of Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: We will be fortunate if we recoup $2m or $3m having regard to all the exceptions relating to hardship and other matters.

It is a good example of rubbery figures and rubbery thinking. Let us turn next to the time question. He referred to the Fraser Government's response to the 1979 report on freedom of information. But the Fraser Government supported at the time of introduction-and it subsequently supported, and so have we in opposition-the time limits which were laid down by the legislation which was introduced in this place. I think the Attorney-General will agree that the time limits originally introduced are those which he now seeks to change. The departments and the offices of Ministers have had four years to get themselves used to the working of the Freedom of Information Act. The Attorney-General made plain in his second reading speech that this experience has been valuable, that they now process requests more quickly. But what are we told? We are told that somehow or other it is a bit burdensome to have the time limit brought down from 45 days to 30 days for the purpose of compliance. Compliance should be timely. People should get the information that they require under the Freedom of Information Act, if we believe in freedom of information, as we on this side of the Parliament do and as the Government plainly does not.

He then referred to public interest remissions. He complained that the public interest remissions-which we support and which will remain in the Act as a consequence of our action-were mainly sought by the media or by members of parliament. If he thinks that there is a problem about the media and about wealthy organisations misusing freedom of information, if he thinks there is a problem about specific abuses, he should legislate to deal with those specific abuses. It is a very simple thing.

He does say, of course, that members of parliament may ask questions in the House during Question Time or place questions on the Notice Paper-that they have these other avenues available to them. Is that not rich? We have been sitting here in opposition for just over 3 1/2 years. We have put to this Government questions which, day in and day out, are evaded. We know that the interpretation given to Standing Orders is such that the provision of Standing Orders which states that an answer shall be relevant to the question is virtually meaningless. If we place questions on notice, for example, to the Treasurer (Mr Keating), in his arrogance, in his disdain, in his refusal to come to grips with the detail of his portfolio, what does he do? He simply does not answer the questions. There is no means of making him answer questions on notice; nor is there any means of making any Government Minister answer questions on notice. So that is a pretty spurious kind of excuse to put to this chamber.

The Attorney-General said, however, that, much as the Government did not like the amendments to the Act, he did not want to delay the budgetary processes. If I understand him correctly, what he is saying is that somehow the increased charges under this Act, as it will be, constitute a budgetary measure which is so locked in with other budgetary measures that he has to concede the amendments so as to get those measures passed. That, of course, is nonsense. We are dealing with a specific subject matter and the subject matter is increases in charges and new charges under the Freedom of Information Act. Those charges can be considered quite by themselves in the sense that they do not form any inseparable part of other measures.

He spoke, lastly, of his commitment to freedom of information. Had the measures which this Government proposed been accepted by the Senate, the Freedom of Information Act would have been gutted. In opposition the then shadow Attorney-General had this to say about the Bill which the Fraser Government presented on freedom of information. Senator Gareth Evans, speaking on freedom of information, said this:

Good freedom of information legislation is that which would set a minimum of procedural obstacles by way of delay or complexity of costs and afford the maximum of practical assistance to those who are pressing access to information.

That was a test which demonstrably this Bill did not meet because it had the necessary consequence of, first, giving to the public servants and ministerial officers wide powers of discretionary refusal based on their views as to whether the burden of acceding to the request for freedom of information would be too great and, secondly, proposing heavy charges which will effectively debar freedom of information from all save the wealthy. That is not our view of how freedom of information should work but since this Bill is a measure which was brought down by the Government in the context of its financial planning for this financial year, a government which is desperate to get money from whatever source it can, we do not propose to object, by amendment, to those charges. But let it never be forgotten that those charges and every other charge which has been imposed are charges of this Government, not charges of the Opposition. While I am on the subject of the so-called commitment to freedom of information, let me remind the Committee again of what Senator Gareth Evans and this Attorney-General said. Senator Evans, when speaking on the original Bill, said:
The present Bill is not a good, effective freedom of information Bill.

I wonder how he would describe, in the closeness and privacy of his mind, the amendments which this Government proposes. I think he would find them disgraceful. What did the present Attorney-General say when speaking on the same Bill, that is, the Fraser Government's Bill? He said:
If we look at the Bill from the point of view of assessing its merit in marking it, it would get about five out of ten, barely a pass.

If one looks at what this Government proposes, if one looks at the charges which will be added and which will price freedom of information out of reach of the ordinary Australian and if one looks at what is intended by way of providing road blocks for public servants and ministerial officers, one would give the Bill zero out of 10. Let me pass on to one or two other criticisms of the amendments and generally of the Government's position on freedom of information. Since my time is coming to an end, I will have to wait until I am next called when I will have 10 minutes in which to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will reply briefly to enable the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) to be called again to speak for 10 minutes. He has again raised a number of issues he raised earlier. The work load test, of course, is always subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, for example, and so there will be no question of any abuse of that test. The revenue figure was an estimate and it would depend on the amendments. I have already indicated that there will be additional costs. I make the point that we now have to meet a 30-day deadline in which to provide information. That will increase the number of charges because there will be additional requests. I am told that there will be appeals in certain circumstances because of the nature of the information, which I endeavoured to mention to the honourable member earlier, and because of its sensitivity. It may have to be obtained from overseas or businesses, so one cannot always comply with the deadline. One will run into the difficulty of a number of applications being made to the AAT. I am advised that the number of applications might well double, and that will certainly increase costs.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable gentleman then spoke about commitment to freedom of information. We certainly have a strong commitment to it. In fact, the provisions are well used and nobody objects to that. However, as I said at the outset, this is a Budget matter. The real purpose of the legislation is to try to recoup some of the costs. No government can afford the luxury of expending taxpayers' money on someone else's requests. I think this is basically what the legislation is all about. There is no doubt that the legislation works well in terms of personal information. However, I think people who want all sorts of information which has nothing to do with them personally but which perhaps would help them in writing a thesis or a newspaper article, ought to make a substantial contribution towards the cost of preparing that information. I think that is basically the reason for the measure. There are no other particular problems.
I think to use up the rest of his 10 minutes speaking time, the honourable gentleman then talked about Question Time. I am not here to give him advice about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You raised it.

—Yes, in respect of where one would get information. The honourable member raised the matter on the basis that one could not get information. Perhaps he has been asking the wrong questions. I can only say that if he has not learnt after three and a half years how to obtain information, he probably needs a bit longer. I am not here to improve his performance in the Parliament. As Madam Speaker has already told him, if he feels that the Standing Orders are inadequate, he can take appropriate steps to get them altered. It is not much good coming in here and complaining about the Treasurer (Mr Keating) or anybody else. We have all lived in this place long enough to know that we succeed or otherwise on the merits of our intellect. If the honourable member after three and a half years does not know how to go about these things, he will have to do better in the next three and a half years. I think that the matter is completely irrelevant to what we are about. Questions on notice are always answered effectively and well.
—By the Treasurer? He is 12 months overdue.

—That is a matter that the honourable member can take up with the Treasurer's Department. The point I want to make is that information is always readily available. Why should taxpayers be asked to pay for somebody else's request? Compliance with some requests involves up to 150 working days. Why cannot information such as that sought in the Newman request or the Westinghouse request be paid for? If requests of such an extensive nature have to be dealt with, what is going to happen to the other requests, which run to about 35,000, that have to be answered? There has to be some balance in the situation. I know that the honourable member sees the merit in this argument. He will not acknowledge it while he is in opposition but he would obviously see it in government, as did Senator Durack when he was in government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The truth of the matter, as the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) knows, is that his Government believes in running things on the rule of numbers. That is how things are run in this chamber. He knows that the difficulty is not the question that is put. The question can be extremely precise. The difficulty lies with the answer which is given, which can travel all around the question but rarely come to grips with it.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me move on to some other criticisms of this Government's conduct in the area of freedom of information. We again hear the Attorney-General talking about abuses. I say to him, as I said on the last occasion the Bill was before us, that if there are abuses, we should legislate to deal with those abuses. It is not difficult to do so. What this legislation proposes is not to deal with abuses under the Freedom of Information Act but to give to the public servants, as I have said, a series of roadblocks to those genuinely desiring freedom of information.

The Attorney-General referred to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Let me remind the Committee of what the new and increased costs are going to involve. Information from the Department of Finance, not from the Opposition or from anyone outside government, has revealed that, on the basis of the new charges, the average cost of each freedom of information request, with an estimated 11 hours of departmental consultation and decision making-it escapes me how that kind of figure could be justified-is $310. I inquire of the Attorney-General: What is the filing fee for an application to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal? I believe it is $200. I notice that he nods his head; it is $200. If we add $200 to the $310 average charge, we get some idea of the sort of problem we are looking at by itself under the Act, and more when an application is made to the AAT.

I do not wish honourable members to think that the criticisms I make are made simply by me and are not supported by others. I presume that the Attorney-General has heard from the Council of Civil Liberties. I shall read the following passage from a copy of a letter from the Council of Civil Liberties to Senator Chaney of 7 October of this year on the subject of these amendments:

. . . it is the purpose of the law, as disclosed by an examination of its provisions, which displays its vindictive motive and capricious operation. At the moment, economic charges are imposed for the administration of the Act and at the time spent in retrieving documents under the Bill, the Administration charges are increased by 250% (from $12 to $30 per request). The hourly rate for retrieving documents is increased from $12 to $15, and that is probably not objectionable. An additional charge of $20 per hour is, however, imposed in relation to the time spent in deciding upon the request including:
(a) examining documents;
(b) consulting with any person or agency;
(c) copying the documents;
(d) notifying decisions to applicants.

It is easy to see how heavy a burden that can be on those who are genuinely seeking information, who are not seeking to abuse the system, and who are not wealthy media organisations but are simply ordinary Australians who want to use the Act. Let me quote again from that same letter:

. . . the amendments and additions to the charges are capricious and arbitrary. Arbitrary because there are no limits imposed by the Act upon the extent of `consultation' and therefore no measure by which the utility and time of consultation may be objectively judged.
Let me make the point that that is absolutely correct, and therefore consultation and costs effectively remain open-ended. The letter goes on:

Capricious because it places users wholly at the mercy of bureaucrats, over whom they can exercise no control in performing services, however unnecessary and futile, for which they must dearly pay in advance of performance and with no guarantee of results.

There can be no question that that is an accurate statement of the way the Act would have operated but for the efforts of the Opposition. However, we have the question of costs, and costs, as I have said, will price freedom of information out of the hands of ordinary Australians.

I refer the Attorney-General to a letter from the Returned Services League of Australia which was written to an Opposition senator. I presume the Attorney-General is aware of the nature of the concern expressed. I quote:

Because of the nature of Service life, long term members of the ADF must commence second careers in mid working life when they require documentary evidence of their first (military) career to support applications for employment, membership of professional associations etc.
The letter goes on:

It is commonplace in the private sector for ex-employees to be given access to their personal records without charge following termination of their employment. It is submitted that the introduction of these fees will greatly disadvantage ex-service men and women in their second careers, or when seeking compensatory repatriation entitlements.
The letter also states:

. . . the volume of freedom of information enquiries to the Department of Defence, now statistically recorded, appears greater than has really been caused by the introduction of the Freedom of Information legislation. No doubt it is this which, in part, caused the Government to propose charges for the provision of information.

Effectively what has been said is that it was normal for ex-service men and women, before the Freedom of Information Act, to obtain without charge information which they now obtain only under the Act from the Department of Defence, but that, since the introduction of the Freedom of Information Act, that practice has ceased. The Attorney-General will know whether that is correct. If he has not seen the letter I am happy to hand over a copy of it to him so he can note the precise nature of the complaints which are made by the Returned Services League.

I conclude by saying that freedom of information is a public right. The days of secrecy of all decision making have gone, or should have gone. If the Government had been successful in the legislation now before the Committee-if that legislation had not been rejected by the Senate as far as the public servants' roadblocks were concerned-freedom of information would have been greatly diminished. Governments are responsible to people. It is all too frequently forgotten that we represent the people and that we are not simply an island in Australia which is isolated from others and which is not account- able to others. The Opposition is committed to freedom of information. On our return to government in the next 18 months, after this directionless Government has been consigned to the electoral ashcan, we will make sure that the Australian people have freedom of information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that hope springs eternal in the bosom of the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) about getting into government, but if he does-God knows when that will happen-he might have a look at the record of a predecessor of his, Mr Ellicott, who imposed a $200 fee for Administrative Appeals Tribunal applications, not as a penalty but to overcome the problems of what often might be deemed to be, in his terms, `vexatious litigants', a term well known to the honourable gentleman. To put his mind at rest, if the appeal is successful the $200 is refunded. I hope that he takes notice of that.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the honourable gentleman for the letter he handed to me. I will have it investigated. I have not previously seen the letter. I make the point that where anybody is seeking information which relates to the question of what is called hardship, personal affairs, or income support, no fee is charged-that is in the Freedom of Information Act. We are a bit uncertain as to why this letter has been written on the basis that there is some problem there. There is an exemption against fees being charged in those cases. We will have it looked at.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raised the question with you before.

—Yes. It is provided for in the Act and we do not charge. That goes to the whole thrust of this. We all agree with freedom of information. The honourable gentleman is making a case that we are too punitive about this matter. One has to bear in mind that the cost to the taxpayer is $14m and the income we are getting from it is about $60,000. I am not suggesting that we have no reason to debate the matter, but when he presents his argument on the basis that we should be able to provide all this information free of cost he is carrying the brief for the media, for members of parliament or for self-interest groups. He is not talking about individuals in this case.
—I did not say that.
—That is where the big charges are.
—Oh?
—It is; that is shown by the facts. When I give the honourable member examples he does not debate them. He does not mind Mr Newman costing us--
—I said that those cases should be dealt with by specific amendments to remove abuses.
—We have put in these charges so that if information is available people might pay for it. But the honourable member for North Sydney does not mind abuse.
—I will draw an amendment for you.
—Order! The honourable members might talk through the Chair rather than debate across the table.

—The honourable member does not have to draw an amendment for me. I want to make the point that if information is to be made available we will make it available. The honourable gentleman is objecting to people paying a fee. The honourable member wants to put that burden on the rest of the community. That is the difference between us. Under the Opposition's amendments, if they ever came in, the honourable member would not want to give people the information.
—But you are rationing it to the wealthy.

—Are we rationing it to the wealthy? I would not think so. This is the very point we are talking about. We want the wealthy, the media and members of parliament to pay if they make outrageous information requests.
—Three hundred and ten dollars on average for a request.

—I do not know whether that is right. Members of parliament have information made available. The media want information and we want them to pay for it. That is the point. Sometimes members of parliament request information so that they can give it to the media. That is a clever way of the media not having to face up to having to pay for it. The outlay is $14m and the honourable gentleman says that that is because the Public Service is too slow and takes 11 hours to investigate a matter. He asks why that should be so. I am only saying that some of the requests made are very difficult to process so obviously it would take a reasonable amount of time for difficult requests. I want to make it clear that at present the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs is having another look at the Act. I welcome that. The submissions made to it clearly show that there can be more savings. I hope the Opposition will support action on that when the interdepartmental committee report is analysed. In summary, we do not want to continue with the present difficulties. Both sides agree that the information should be made available, but the honourable member for North Sydney and I disagree on who should pay for it.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 October, on motion by Mr West:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Beale had moved by way of amendment:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not opposing the provisions of the Bill, the House condemns the Government for pursuing disastrous economic and taxation policies which have-
(1) created the current housing crisis;
(2) resulted in high levels of interest rates;
(3) reduced the number of dwelling commencements;
(4) reduced the availability, and increased the cost, of rental properties, and
(5) increased the public housing waiting lists'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of the Home Deposit Assistance Amendment Bill. Obviously, the Bill is only a minor procedural Bill to wind up the home deposit assistance scheme. This was a program of the previous Government but this Bill shows the compassionate approach of this Government that even when we have introduced a more generous and more equitable first home owners scheme we have allowed time for the previous scheme to wind up. This Bill gives the House the opportunity to discuss in more detail the housing policy of this Government. It is a record of which the Government can be proud of and of which I personally am very proud, particularly in relation to its impact on the Australian Capital Territory, which is my electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: When this Australian Labor Party Government gained office the housing industry was in appalling shape. Nationally, there was very little growth and the Australian Capital Territory was incredibly depressed. In 1982-83 nationally there were only 105,000 housing commencements. In 1984-85 there was an increase to 152,700. That was a 45 per cent increase on 1982-83, the highest increase since 1973 and a record of which we are very proud. Since then there has been a slight fall-off in demand with slightly reduced activity but we should remember that that is a fall from a very high level of activity. In 1985-86 the level of commencements will be about 136,000, still up 30 per cent on 1982-83. The Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry, headed by Professor Fred Gruen, is predicting 125,000 commencements Australia-wide for 1986-87. So even though the figures are slightly down on last year, we are still seeing a very big increase on the 1982-83 figure of 105,000. Incidentally, the major reason for the decline is a decline of 7,000 in Queensland. Why is that? If any of us watched television last night we would have heard the view of one Queensland industry leader on why there has been such a decline in business activity in Queensland. I think he defined it as the influence of cronyism in Queensland. Obviously, it goes a lot deeper than that-to the general mismanagement of the Queensland economy.

In stark contrast to the Queensland economy is the Australian Capital Territory economy which has seen a fantastic increase in housing activity. Between March 1983 and August 1986, 5,770 houses were completed. That compares with virtually nil activity in 1982-83. The situation in those days when the Opposition was in government was appalling. Alongside the increase in housing activity we have also seen in Canberra a stabilisation of land prices. We are quite unique in that we can control-

TALK.START.PARA: —You can say that again.

—We are doing extremely well, thanks very much. If the Tasmanian economy were doing as well as ours the honourable member could afford to make a comment. Why is he always in the House interjecting on me while I am speaking? In the Australian Capital Territory, where we can control the price of land, there has been a stabilisation of land prices. The previous Government attempted to force up the price of land by restricting the release of land. The decline in the price of land has been one very positive way in which we have been able to keep the price of the house and land package down for the first home buyer. The Indicative Planning Council expects 3,500 houses to be begun this financial year in the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been a number of reasons for the increase in housing activity at the national level. Obviously, there has been a change in economic climate since the Hawke Government took over. One of the major incentives for first home owners, in particular, has been our first home owners scheme. The scheme was introduced in October 1983. It is a much better scheme than the Liberals' home deposit assistance scheme. The Liberals' home deposit assistance scheme involved grants of only $3,500. Our scheme involves grants of up to $6,000 to go towards deposits and reduce interest. People do not have to have the savings records which the Liberals insisted on to get help under their first home owners scheme. Since our program was introduced in October 1983 we have committed nearly $1 billion Australia-wide. Ours is a fantastic record of efforts to help first home buyers. There have been 214,000 successful applicants, which has proved to be a massive boost to the industry Australia-wide and, in particular, to my electorate.

A further boost has been the change in the way the Government is assisting first home buyers, in particular, with the housing package which we introduced in April this year when we took action to assist the housing industry and to protect home loan borrowers. As part of this package we paid a subsidy to banks of around $150m to safeguard the one million borrowers paying an interest rate of 13.5 per cent to the banks. I would like Opposition members, in their replies today, to give a guarantee that they will keep that level of 13.5 per cent to existing borrowers if ever they get into government.

We allowed the banks to lift the rate for new borrowings to 15.5 per cent and we got the banks to agree to lend at least $6 billion in 1986-87 to promote low start loans. Those low start loans are a great initiative for first home buyers and in my electorate people have taken full advantage of them. I congratulate many of the private banks in particular on the imaginative packages they have come up with to assist many of our first home buyers. Since this package came into effect, lending for housing has increased significantly. In the three months to July, house lending was running at an annual rate of $7.5 billion. In August and September bank lending for housing was at least double that in the two months prior to April 1986. So the housing industry is still looking fairly rosy.

One has to consider that we are not looking just at building houses for people to live in; we are also thinking of the incredible flow-on effect that has throughout the industry and the economy generally. In my electorate the stimulus in the housing industry has contributed a great deal to making Canberra the city with the lowest unemployment in Australia. I would like to make some reference to a couple of new initiatives in the housing industry which are having a particular impact in my electorate. One of these is a proposal to try to reduce housing costs. We have what we call a joint venture for more affordable housing. There are two programs in particular in my electorate, one at Isabella Plains and another at Calwell, which are catering for 560 dwellings. This is a co-operative venture between the National Capital Development Commission and the Department of Territories sponsored, of course, by the Federal Government. The objective of this venture is to illustrate to the public and the private sectors how different approaches to engineering and planning requirements can lower production costs while maintaining a quality environment. We are setting up a couple of demonstration models. I hope that honourable members who are interested in the housing area will take the opportunity to look at our building programs at Isabella Plains and Calwell. I would be very happy to assist them. In those areas we have narrow minor access roads and lanes, different types of drainage, reduced building set-backs, battle-axe allotments, lower cost road constructions, narrow frontage allotments and minimised landscaping costs. Within those restrictions, which are making a significant inroad into costs, we are still able to put the houses in a beautiful environment. Land servicing of these areas is currently under way and we hope that in the next 12 months honourable members will be able to see some impact.

I would like to make some comments about the future of the housing industry in the Australian Capital Territory. We are going to move into a new era in the Australian Capital Territory next year. We are about to be aligned with the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. This will bring the Australian Capital Territory a wide range of benefits to public housing, including sound legislative bases, guaranteed minimum funding levels, which will be removed from annual budget processes-that is something we will really welcome here-and access to revolving funds generated by rental home lending and sales activities. That is particularly significant in Canberra because we have not been able to sell off some of the older government houses in the older established parts of Canberra, which are obviously worth quite a lot of money, and recycle those funds into the housing fund.

After these new arrangements come into operation we will be able to do that, and I think that will lead to a great change and innovation in housing funding in the Australian Capital Territory. We will have consistency with arrangements with the States in relation to funding, interest rates, policies and programs and the vesting of overall responsibility for public housing activity in the Commissioner for Housing, subject to the direction of the Minister. Those honourable members who criticise the Australian Capital Territory for the generous treatment it always receives I imagine will also recognise this innovation in housing arrangements for the Australian Capital Territory. I think we will be a lot better off having our housing on a sound financial basis. I congratulate the Government on the contribution it has made to the housing industry in the Australian Capital Territory in particular because I know that through the policies of this Government a lot more people will be housed than was the case under the previous Administration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Friday I stood in this House and condemned this Government for its disgraceful treatment of pensioners, ex-service men and women and war widows. On Tuesday night I stood in this House and criticised this Government for its shameful betrayal of the young people of Australia, particularly the students of Australia, with the introduction of the tertiary fee of $250. Today it is my duty to stand in this House and on behalf of all Australian home owners and prospective home owners to condemn this Government for its betrayal and deception of them with the implementation of its disastrous housing policies.

SPEECH.PARA: The point has to be made from the outset that the Hawke socialist Government has broken its principal housing election promise, and that this year there will be only 122,500 new housing starts instead of the promised-I repeat, promised-142,000. That promise was made in the 1984 Federal election campaign, when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) pointed with pride to the fact that 142,000 new starts had been achieved in 1984 and made a firm commitment in these terms: `My Government will ensure that it is maintained and continued for the next two years.' My colleagues the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), the shadow Minister, and the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), who are both present in the chamber, will recall that the Prime Minister said in 1984 that in the next two years the Government would maintain the level of new housing starts at 142,000. What has the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry told the Government? It has told the Government that it will be struggling to create 122,500 new housing starts. What does that drop of 20,000 new housing starts this year mean? It means that $1 billion-I repeat, $1 billion, $1,000m-will be lost in activity in the housing industry this year. More importantly, it means that 30,000 building industry jobs are now on the line and will almost certainly be lost. The job loss formula applied to a drop of $1 billion and a cutback of 20,000 new housing starts means that 30,000 men and women currently employed in the housing industry know that by this time next year they will not have their jobs.

This is a shocking and disgraceful betrayal and deception of the industry and in particular it is a shocking and disgraceful betrayal and deception of the prospective home owners of Australia, and that means particularly the young married couples to whom the dream of owning a home has become a nightmare under the disgraceful policies of the Hawke socialist Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Interest rates.

—I thank the honourable member for his reference to interest rates. I was about to say that the situation has been aggravated by deliberate Government policies. Let me mention just three. Firstly, we have high interest rates in Australia today as a result of a deliberate Government economic policy. Let us not beat around the bush. It is the policy of this Government to keep interest rates up for the purpose of protecting a falling dollar in overseas trade. That is the fundamental reason. This Government has used its great economic powers through the Reserve Bank of Australia to force up interest rates. It is not an accident that interest rates are high in this country. It is the direct result of the deliberate policies of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Secondly, in regard to the capital gains tax, the Government was told over and again that a capital gains tax would have an enormous impact on the housing industry, and it already has. Thirdly, the implications of the quarantining of negative gearing, as I will demonstrate in a moment, have had a most disastrous impact on rental accommodation in this country. The stockpile of rental accommodation in Australia has dried up.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that one of my colleagues from Western Australia on the other side of the House, the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards), is in the chamber. He will be speaking in this debate. He will remember that last year, at the Housing Ministers' Conference in Perth, a paper was presented which demonstrated that, if negative gearing was quarantined, it would lead to a major shortfall in the stockpile of rental accommodation. Of course, we all know that the smaller the stockpile, the higher the premium for rental accommodation, and that is why rentals have soared throughout Australia.

This Government, by deliberate government policy, has created a situation in which 20,000 fewer houses will be built this year than should be built. Worse still, the rental position-the accommodation for those who have to rent houses, flats and units-has become critical. Let me give two examples. Residential rents in Sydney have soared by 20 per cent so far this year, and a further 10 per cent hike is predicted before the end of the year. This is not something that has crept up on the Government. It will surprise some members in this chamber, and no doubt some people outside the chamber, that I commend the New South Wales Minister for Housing, the Hon. Frank Walker, who predicted that this would happen 12 months ago. Whether one likes him or not, one has to give Mr Walker full marks for consistency because he predicted this more than 12 months ago. He repeated his comments publicly at the Australian Labor Party National Conference in Hobart. Again, only one week ago he made the point that deliberate policies of the Hawke socialist Government have led to higher interest rates, higher rentals and a diminishing of the stockpile of accommodation.

In June 1985, in the city of Hobart, the rental cost for a two-bedroom unfurnished unit was $86.30. The same unit now costs $103 a week, and that is a massive increase of 19.8 per cent. The honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) and I have assiduously attended to housing matters in our electorates. I do not know what the practice of most Federal members is. I know that the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) does as we do. If we get a request from a constituent on a State housing matter, we make representations. I am told that some members say: `No, go and see a State member because it is a State matter'. But we make representations. In fact, the Department of Housing in Tasmania would confirm that, between us, the honourable member for Franklin and I would handle 75 per cent of the representations made through a parliamentary office with respect to rental accommodation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Better than what that rotten editorial said about us.

—The honourable member mentions a sore point. We did receive, unfortunately, a pretty rough deal in an editorial in the Sunday Tasmanian last week. I say in passing that we can live with that. A prophet is never honoured in his own land. Unfortunately, the Sunday Tasmanian, very unfairly and unjustly, castigated the honourable member for Franklin and me. But I believe in the judgment of the real people.
—You are there to serve the people.

—We are there to serve the people, as the shadow Minister says. Furthermore, we do it on the basis that the Housing Department knows that what we put in our representations is true and correct. If we believe the application is premature, we both have the courage to say to the constituent: `It is better if you wait for three or four months'. So the Housing Department knows that when we say it is urgent, it is urgent. When we say it is special, it is special. Our achievement rate or our strike rate, in cricketing terms, has been exceptionally high-probably in excess of 90 per cent. That is not an advertisement because, quite frankly, with up to 43 constituents in our offices each day when we are in Hobart, I am sure that the honourable member for Franklin and I are not asking for more customers. But we do make the point that we give service.

SPEECH.PARA: With the rental position totally out of control, with the home building position in chaos, with 20,000 fewer houses to be built in Australia this year than should have been built, with $1 billion taken out of the housing industry, and with union secretaries and organisers in the building industry confirming that between 20,000 and 30,000 building industry jobs are now on the line and likely to disappear, is it any surprise that I now announce that the honourable member for Franklin and I have made a firm policy decision that housing will be a key election issue in the electorates of Denison and Franklin when the next Federal poll is held?

TALK.START.PARA: —Have we got any candidates against us yet?

—They are struggling at the moment. Let us assume that the Government trots up somebody: Five times running it has been predicted that we would lose our seats and six times running we have held our seats. The honourable member for Franklin and I will make housing a key issue in Denison and Franklin at the next Federal poll. We are particularly concerned about the housing situation of the poor and of young married couples and, at the other end of the scale, the housing situation of the elderly. As chairman of the Opposition task force on the elderly the honourable member for Franklin is working assiduously in respect of the housing problems of our aged. The grandparents of Australia have received a rotten deal in housing from this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We deal with ordinary people in our elect- orates. I acknowledge that the honourable member for Stirling, who is about to speak, also deals with ordinary people. When it comes down to reality, the right of an Australian to own a home is a fundamental one. We reject the proposition that people owning their own homes are, as was said by one of the leaders of the Australian Labor Party many years ago, a bunch of little capitalists. We want to see home building zoom in this country; we want to see interest rates kept down; we want to see a situation in which the Government gets its act together. Time is running out for this Government. It is on its last legs. But even in a mini-Budget next year the Government could inject into the housing industry a capacity to put roofs over the heads of decent Australians who otherwise will be sleeping out. I say in all humility that I think the housing issue will be one of the key issues in the next Federal election campaign. It is an issue upon which the Government will be judged very harshly by an Australian people which has had a gutful of the Hawke socialist Government and will throw it out of office at the first available opportunity through the democratic process of the ballot box.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) spoke about the level of housing activity and declining interest rates. We on this side of the House hold very high in our objectives housing activity and declining interest rates. I suggest that the honourable member for Denison give the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) a prod because it is his hope that interest rates remain high and that economic activity remains low so that he will be forced into government. I am confident that interest rates will trend down in late 1987 and that economic activity will recover. However, I think we both share the view that housing is very fundamental to the welfare of the Australian community. It is fundamental in terms of both the social objective of getting people into homes and the economic objective of creating jobs and ensuring profitability in industry. I do not think that is a matter with which either side of this chamber would disagree, in acknowledging the remarks of the honourable member for Denison.

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks back over the period we have been in government one sees that our record has been very impressive in terms of housing commencements. In a moment I want to address myself to one or two difficulties about interest rates and the declining housing commencement activity in recent times. However, if one looks at the overall picture and compares the 105,000 housing commencements in the last year of the Fraser Government with the 135,000 housing commencements in our first year in office one sees that the comparison is favourable.

The honourable member for Denison said that the Indicative Planning Council was talking about a housing commencement rate of 122,500. That is quite right. It has revised its estimate down from 130,000. It is fair to say in this debate that there are a couple of reasons for that. One is the higher interest rates and the other is that there has been some resistance in certain markets. We need to look at that resistance, and I propose to do that.

Western Australia is probably more fortunate than most States because not only has it had reasonably high levels of housing activity but also its commercial building sector has been very buoyant. Obviously tourism aspects are involved. The State Government deserves some recognition because it performs its role very well. I think there has been a Federal Government involvement as well. I make those couple of remarks in a sense to respond to the honourable member for Denison and to put a perspective, as I see it, on the housing picture. Obviously, as always, it is a mixed picture. For example, the current level of housing activity in Western Australia is very good. The level of commencements is good. One the other hand, there is some concern about interest rates.

I say to the honourable member for Denison and the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) that the Opposition will face a major difficulty in that it has yet to come up with a comprehensive housing policy. I think that is something that will trouble the Opposition in the run-up to the next election. The absence of a major housing policy is a major difficulty that confronts the Opposition. Another difficulty that confronts the Opposition-I want to make this very clear-is the question of the 13.5 per cent housing interest rate ceiling. It is the view of the Government that the 13.5 per cent housing interest rate ceiling will remain in place. I reassure people listening to this debate who have a bank loan that that is the commitment of this Government. The Opposition is very uncertain about this matter. The more right wing elements of the Opposition want to deregulate interest rates completely. Very clearly, if that happened the banks would increase housing interest rates. We are not prepared to accept that. We believe that the housing interest rate ceiling should remain in place. Very clearly, it will remain in place while we are in government. I give that assurance to people.

I also want to pick up the point that it is very unfair of the savings banks to be putting pressure on this Government and to be debating in the community the need to remove that ceiling when we look at the fact that the Commonwealth Bank recently recorded a pre-tax profit of $445.5m-up from $359.5m. It is very clear that this banking organisation is doing very well. I reiterate that the pre-tax profit was $445.5m. The after-tax profit of the Commonwealth Bank was up 91 per cent from $127.8m to $244.4m. Very clearly, that banking group has done very well as a result of our current economic management and policy. We are pleased about that. But I think the other side of that cannot expect to put pressure on this Government to lift the ceiling on housing mortgage interest rates. It is not on as far as we are concerned. We believe that the 13.5 per cent ceiling on existing rates should stay and will stay.

It is very important that we look at the impact of interest rates. In this respect, I am very encouraged by the figures that were reported yesterday in the financial Press. The official cash rate was 16 per cent, traded down to 15.5 per cent. The unofficial market for cash was down from 16.5 per cent to 16.15 per cent. The 24-hour cash market held steady at 16.5 per cent. However, the quotation for 90-day bills was down to 16.5 per cent from 16.75 per cent. The 15 October quotation for the Australian merchant bankers bill rate was 17.44 per cent and the 22 October quotation was 17.31 per cent. The authorised dealers bank bill rate was 16.95 per cent for 15 October and 16.45 per cent for 22 October. So the closing market rates yesterday show that there is a trend down.

I think in early 1987 we can expect to see some outcomes of this Government's economic policy. This is showing up at the moment in terms of dollar rates and the value of the dollar. The easing of the interest rates during 1987 will have a positive impact on the housing sector. This is something that I am very keen to see in my own electorate of Stirling in terms of the level of commencements and in terms of the level of obligation of people repaying housing loans. It is fair to say that those are areas for concern.

It is interesting to compare the Government's policy on housing with that of the Opposition. First of all, the Opposition does not have a comprehensive policy on housing. Secondly, if we reflect on what happened when the Opposition was in government, we remember that its record is a sorry one. Under the previous Government, housing commencements fell to 105,000, which was a 20-year low. The Hawke Government in its first year lifted that figure to 135,000. During the term of the Hawke Government we have seen a peak of 155,000 commencements, and that is a very favourable turnaround. The great area of concern amongst people in the community is that the Opposition will not come clean on whether it will deregulate housing mortgage interest rates. I said earlier that we will not. The Opposition wishes to do so in respect of the banking sector. If that uncertainty persists I think the Opposition will have a lot to answer for in respect of its economic policies.

I turn briefly to a couple of areas that I believe need addressing by the Government. I think we can look forward to changes in the home owners scheme, which is an important area of consideration. One could make a case for the income limit for the first home owners scheme to be increased and then indexed, because that would be an important step in restoring it to its buying power. We see that as being very important. I acknowledge the participation of the Master Builders Association of Australia and its chief economist, Gavan Forster, in discussions we held recently. I believe some sensible adjustments could be made to that scheme.

The other area which I believe deserves consideration and which would mobilise capital for housing is the possibility of introducing granny bonds, under which would attract a reasonable level of interest would be paid to people, usually of mature age, who wish to invest in those but who at the same time would not have to declare the income from those bonds for pension purposes. As far as pension arrangements would be concerned, the bonds would be income test free. Pensioners and superannuitants often have sums of money that could well be mobilised by providing deposits for housing. If we were able to pay a nominal interest rate of 8 or 9 per cent and, as an added incentive, that interest was classed as not being part of the income test for either pensioners of superannuitants, we would be availing ourselves of a substantial amount of funds which could be directed to housing. The availability of granny bonds as a source of funding for housing is something that we could look at down the track.

Let us look at this Government's performance in the housing area and compare it with the situation we inherited, of a commencement rate of 105,000, which was socially unacceptable because people did not have access to housing. It was economically unacceptable because of the resultant unemployment and declining profitability. This Government turned that situation around in its first year and brought commencements up to 135,000. I believe we have a very impressive record in housing commencements and I think the community recognises that. It also recognises that in the current climate of declining commodity prices and a threatened Australian dollar interest rates have been higher than we would have liked and than would otherwise have been necessary because we have been securing stability in the Australian economy. I think people are aware that this government is competent in its economic management. As a result of that competence, in 1987 we will see a restoration of profitability in the housing area and a further easing of interest rates.

I conclude by giving this assurance to the people in the community: This Government's economic policies are comprehensive; they have delivered so far and they will continue to deliver. It is our view that the 13.5 per cent ceiling on housing interest rates will stay in place because it is a very important social and economic objective. I think I can say with confidence that this Government's housing policies have worked and worked very well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially in Western Australia.

—Especially in Western Australia, as my colleague the honourable member for Moore adds. There is every reason why the honourable member for Cowan (Ms Jakobsen), the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard) and I, from Stirling, can look with confidence upon our electorates. The State Government has performed well and the Federal Government's contribution, in our view, has been outstanding. I am pleased to commend this Government's housing policies to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I compliment the previous speaker, the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards). I thought his contribution to this debate on the Home Deposit Assistance Amendment Bill was very well argued and thoughtfully presented. If other members of his Party followed his example we would have a greater and more sincere contribution from that side of the House. I particularly support his suggestion about granny bonds. If he can convince his fellow members, particularly those from Western Australia, perhaps they could act as a catalyst to prompt the Government into taking a decision in line with the view expressed by him.

SPEECH.PARA: In rising on behalf of the Opposition I begin by saying that Australia, as a nation not yet 200 years settled, is a land of migrants. There is still present through history, tradition and folk lore a remembrance of what life was like in our ancestral countries. Most of our migrants were from relatively poor backgrounds where existence and shelter basically depended on the whim of the landlord or master. Few of these people knew the stability of food supply or the security of a roof over their heads. From this insecurity grew a determination by our early settlers to provide for themselves and their families a safeguard against the uncertainties they knew in the old world. Most saw the possibility of purchasing their own land and building their own homes as the sanctuary they sought so eagerly. As a result, Australia became the land of promise, the land of milk and honey, and the place where they could settle without fear or favour.

It is against this background that federally funded home ownership schemes, past and present, have been founded. As a result, Australia once enjoyed the honour of having the largest number of home owners in the world but, sadly, this is no longer the case. High interest rates, uncertainty in the economy, and an inflationary level double and approaching triple that of our major trading partners have taken their toll on families wishing to own their own homes. The dream of security from less than sympathetic or unscrupulous landlords, as in the old country, is quickly fading for our most needy families.

Whilst the Government takes great pleasure and pride in boasting of its first home ownership scheme and its apparent success, it is interesting to note that the $290m allocated in the 1985-86 Budget was not fully taken up. Only $239m was spent, leaving over 12 per cent unused in the Budget allocation to the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West).

If this scheme is as popular and successful as the Minister likes to claim, if the economy is as buoyant as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) like to tell us, why has not all the money been taken up by our lower and middle income families? Why has the Government, if it believes its economic policies are good for home ownership and good for Australia, reduced its budget for housing from $290m in 1985-86 to $209m for 1986-87?

This Labor Government has always uttered what I believe are platitudes about the importance of housing and the construction industry, Yet it clearly does not, by these actions I have enumerated, feel that housing is as vital as we have been led to believe. I come to this conclusion for several reasons. In its May 1983 economic statement, the Government decided to terminate on 1 July the general housing interest income tax rebate scheme available to all home owners paying in excess of 10 per cent on housing loans for their sole or principal residence. It also terminated the housing interest income tax rebate scheme, which provided rebates over five years to first home owners. This action was taken at a time when interest rates were peaking at 14 per cent, a high figure indeed for that time, but still a low figure when compared with modern high interest rates.

Let us look at what this meant in dollar terms to those families trying to put a roof over their heads. In February 1983 the average cost of an established home in Melbourne was $56,000. Interest rates were 13.93 per cent on a mortgage amounting to $42,000 over 25 years. The cost to repay that mortgage was $458 per month, or 30.86 per cent of average weekly earnings. In Sydney in February 1983 the average established home could be had for a mere $80,000, with a $60,000 mortgage and repayments of $654 per month, or 44.09 per cent of average weekly earnings. Let us compare these figures with what we have now, after three and a half years of a so-called caring Labor government. The average home in Melbourne has gone up from $56,000 to almost $84,000 at an interest rate of 15.5 per cent. The redemption and interest payments on a mortgage of nearly $63,000 cost $830 a month, or 44.82 per cent of average weekly earnings.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about capital gains and negative gearing?

—They have to come into it later on. In Sydney, the average established home now costs over $100,000 and carries with it a mortgage of over $75,000. Interest and mortgage repayments amount to almost $1,000 per month, or almost 54 per cent of average weekly earnings. As the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan), the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) and the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) have said, how can the ordinary person working in an ordinary job have any hope of paying back that mortgage? What about the young railway worker who is married-his wife might be working in a medical or scientific laboratory-trying to save to purchase a home. What hope do they have under that type of economic policy?

SPEECH.PARA: It is little wonder our public housing waiting lists are so long and are becoming longer by the day. Queensland, of course, is the exception; it does not have a very long waiting list and people have the opportunity of getting into a house within three weeks of application.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has a National Party government.

—As the honourable member for Lyne said, it has a National Party government. That is a very honest observation. One of the reasons why Queensland has an excellent housing policy is that it has a National Party government. Families simply cannot afford to pay out half of their weekly earnings on mortgage repayments and eat and provide for their children's needs. The Labor Government saw the first home owners scheme as offering a better deal for those in need than this Home Deposit Assistance Act and as an opportunity to reduce unemployment. When that legislation was introduced the then Minister for Housing and Construction, the present Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford), in his second reading speech, promised to index the means test qualifications for those applying for a benefit. I quote from his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: The taxable income limits for those qualifying for this program would be adjusted each year in accordance with movements in average weekly earnings.

In the 1984-85 Budget the Government adjusted the income limits, but it adjusted them downwards instead of taking account of the high inflationary factor that was prevalent in this country. They were not adjusted upwards to keep up with inflation and average weekly earnings as promised, but were adjusted downwards-another broken promise. Not only did it adjust downwards the qualifying figures for this scheme but also, at the same time, it decreased the amount of money that single people and families could receive.

In the case of a single person with no dependants, the income level was halved from $20,000 to $10,000 and the maximum benefit was reduced from $5,000 to $4,000. For a married couple with a joint income, the maximum earnings permissible to receive the full benefit was lowered from $24,300 to $20,000. The maximum grant decreased from $5,000 to $4,000 at a time when people were having trouble even getting a deposit for a home. The cost of housing went up, inflation went up, interest went up and the deposit went down, yet this Government says it is a caring government. The maximum income for a partial grant has remained the same at $27,900, despite higher weekly earnings enjoyed by most of the community. Couples or single parents with dependants fared no better in the 1984-85 adjustments for qualifications and benefits. The base rate for two or more dependants has decreased from $7,000 to $6,000 and for one dependant from $6,500 to $5,500.

This Government's policy on housing was supposed to ensure that housing played a key role in economic recovery and that Australian families had access to adequate housing at a price they could afford. What a farce this policy is when one considers that during the 1985-86 financial year total dwelling commencements reached 136,000 compared with 152,000 the previous year. Reliable sources have indicated to me that the 1986-87 figures could be as low as 125,000 when there is a demand for people to purchase their own homes. Approvals for private sector dwelling units in August-I base this on solid statistics-fell 6.4 per cent, despite reports from major financial institutions of increased lending for housing. The housing industry, as I see it, is bubbling along at the bottom of a trough with no solid upturn in sight.

I take issue with the present and previous Ministers when, in their second reading speeches on the First Home Owners Bill and this Bill, they claimed that it was in a harsh and draconian manner that the coalition Government had terminated the home savings grant scheme. That is simply not true. We announced the home deposit assistance scheme in April 1982 and closed down the home savings grant scheme in August that year. The home savings grant scheme had been established since 1964. It was an initiative of the Menzies Government. It was time to introduce another, more efficient and effective program to assist families.

I conclude on this note, because we do not want any confusion about this at all: I had the honour, as the Minister for Housing in this Parliament, to introduce for the first time ever a scheme which recognised the value of family life and which made a meaningful and significant contribution to allowing people with families to purchase their own homes.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were a successful Minister.

—The honourable member is very kind and courteous. My Government, consisting of the Liberal and National parties, believed that it was appropriate to encourage people with families to purchase their own homes, and to back our propositions and our philosophies with action not just words. We introduced, for the first time ever in a parliament-national or State-extra assistance for families. It is absolutely wrong for the Labor Party to deny that we were the people with the foresight, that we were the people with the honesty of purpose, that we were the people with the sincerity of application who understood the role the family plays in Australian society, and that we were the people who were prepared to give those people some type of assistance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Home Deposit Assistance Amendment Bill, which is designed to terminate the receipt of applications under the Fraser Government's home deposit assistance scheme. So far in this debate we have had some very excellent contributions from honourable members from both sides of the House. As usual, the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh), in his aggressive but genuine way, made his play in this debate. As usual, the contributions from the Opposition were devoid of any substance in the sense that there was nothing concrete, nothing that we could get hold of to say what it would do if it got back to office. We also had a very thoughtful speech from the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards), whose interest in this area is widely known, not only in Western Australia but also in other parts of Australia. He is highly regarded as an expert in the area of housing.

SPEECH.PARA: It should be made clear at the outset that the Fraser Government's scheme applied only to homes purchased between 18 March 1982 and 30 September 1983. That scheme is now effectively obsolete. In 1983 this Government introduced the first home owners scheme, which was aimed at superseding the Fraser Government's scheme. The first home owners scheme has proved to be a much better and a more successful scheme than the one it replaced. At the time of its introduction, the Government gave a firm commitment not to wind up immediately the home deposit assistance scheme. It is now over three years since that scheme was superseded by the first home owners scheme and, rightly, the Government has decided that the time has come to terminate the old scheme.

This Bill provides that 31 December 1986 will be the last day on which an applicant can deliver a valid application under the old scheme. Its effect on those seeking financial assistance for housing will be minimal. As I mentioned earlier, that scheme applied only to homes purchases between 18 March 1982 and 30 September 1983. There are savings, which are largely administrative, in terminating the home deposit assistance scheme. These will amount to only about $150,000 in the first full year. I should have thought that a saving of even $150,000 would please honourable members opposite, particularly the waste watchers. This Government can be proud of its housing record. We have stimulated the housing industry and assisted in creating more jobs. At the same time, we have helped to meet the social needs of those requiring housing.

What was the position when we came to office? There is no doubt that the housing industry was in the doldrums. There were only 105,000 housing commencements in 1982-83-the last year in which the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), then the Treasurer, had the opportunity to damage the country's economy. In 1984-85 commencements increased to a total of 152,700. This was a 45 per cent increase on the 1982-83 figure and the highest total since 1973-74, which, of course, was another vintage year when a Labor government was in office. In 1985-86 there was a fall-off in demand which led to slightly reduced activity. But the 136,000 commencements were still 30 per cent more than the 1982-83 figure. For 1986-87, it has been predicted by the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry that there will be 125,000 commencements. Unfortunately, the major reason for the decline is the reduction by approximately 7,000 in commencements in Queensland. This illustrates the incompetence of the Queensland National Party Government. Its mismanagement of the Queensland economy hopefully will end on Saturday week. Looking at the newspapers today, we find that even within the higher echelons of the National Party strong doubts are emerging about whether that Party can survive on 1 November.

The Government's constructive policies in housing, as I mentioned earlier, have resulted in a significant increase in employment in the housing and construction industry. Over 70,000 more persons are employed in the industry than were employed in it when we took over government. The first home owners scheme is a major element of this Government's housing policy. When it was introduced in October 1983 it met a real need for those on low and average incomes who did not have sufficient capital to put down a deposit for a new house. At that time, applicants for the first home owners scheme could obtain up to $7,000. This amount has now dropped to a maximum of $6,000. Let us compare the first home owners scheme with the Liberals' home deposit assistance scheme. The maximum assistance under the Liberals' scheme was $3,500, compared with the maximum assistance today of $6,000 under FHOS. To get this financial assistance under the Liberals' scheme the applicant or applicants had to have a savings record. The first home owners scheme does not have this restriction.

There is no doubt that FHOS has provided a massive boost to industry. The record is excellent and deserves praise from both sides of the House. Since FHOS was introduced in October 1983, nearly $1 billion has been committed Australia-wide to boost the housing stocks of this country. The 214,000 successful applicants are well satisfied with that scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—As the honourable member for Dobell said, we can say `hear, hear' on behalf of those people who would not have a house if it were not for that scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn briefly to the Opposition's housing policy. As honourable members will recall, earlier this year the Opposition's housing policy was leaked by certain honourable members opposite. There is no doubt about it. It is a Clayton's policy-a policy you have when you have no policy. It showed a clear ignorance of overall housing problems and solutions. Further, it had no costings. It was a negative policy. In the public housing area it proposed the elimination of tied grants. Why do we have tied grants? These grants ensure that the most needy get priority help. Tied grants at the moment go to rental housing for Aboriginals-I assure the House that in my role as Chairman of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs I am only too aware of the real need in that area-crisis accommodation such as women's and youth refuges, and housing provided by local government and community groups for age pensioners and persons facing short term mortgage and rent problems.
