These are the categories of persons who would be severely disadvantaged if tied grants were stopped. In 1985-86 about $140m was paid out in tied grants. The Opposition was also prepared to incorporate the FHOS scheme in public housing funds for the States. That would mean that it would effectively abolish the scheme, because the States would have to decide to help either first home buyers or those who need public housing. There is no doubt in my mind that the Opposition's housing policy-and particularly its public housing policy-would have a severe negative effect on those who need housing. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with a great deal of interest to speak on the Home Deposit Assistance Amendment Bill because I perceive it as being of vital importance to every Australian. In starting, I pay tribute to the contribution of the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh) who spoke for the Opposition before me. His contribution was very worth while. The honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard), in his own charming and inimitable style, made a reasonable contribution. However, I am forced to take issue just a little with the honourable member for Moore who, like all the Government members who are not sitting on the Labor benches at present, apologises for his Government's shortcomings and failure by attacking the Fraser Government. This is becoming stale pastry. Surely they have to get to the point where they can stand on their own feet and take responsibility for their actions, inaction and failure.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Moore said that when the Hawke Labor Government-I would rather call it the Hawke failed Government-came in housing was in the doldrums. He went on to mention that it was a vintage year when Labor was in office. I can tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and the people of Australia who are listening to this broadcast, that 1986 will also be a vintage year for Labor.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very rough red.

—As my colleague says, it will be a very rough red. It will be a year in which the real figures will demonstrate that the housing industry is going out backwards in the public sector. It is a cause of great concern. The honourable member for Moore also referred to housing starts in Queensland and said that the numbers were not increasing; that they had fallen. He blamed the Queensland National Party for being incompetent. When I get down to reading out the accurate figures on the growing waiting lists for public housing-throughout Australia people are in desperate need of housing-we will see that in the three years since the failed Hawke Government came to office, a government which blows its own trumpet endlessly, in only one State in the Commonwealth has the number of people on the waiting list for public housing actually fallen. It will come as no surprise to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, because you are aware of what is happening, to learn that that State is Queensland. As the honourable member for Moore pointed out earlier, an election is going on in Queensland. This is probably why Labor members, in the great bulk of speeches they make in various debates in this place and the other place, attack Queensland. They just want to score little points for the election. After the election, the National Party will be back in government. Labor will do no good at all in the election. Rockdale and Bass Hill in Sydney have pointed the way. Labor will get its next shock, its next tremor, in Queensland on 1 November.

SPEECH.PARA: Housing is of vital importance to every Australian. As the honourable member for Groom said so very well, it is the basis of the family. If one cannot clothe, feed and house one's family one is in great trouble. I would like to refer to some very appropriate figures. In June 1983, slightly after the failed, trumpet-blowing Hawke Government came into power, the number of people on the waiting list for public housing was 125,449. By the end of June 1986 it had grown to 149,288. An additional 23,839 people had been forced on to the waiting list.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—It is a great shame. The Hawke Labor Government has been in power for only three years but what a disastrous three years it has been. We have had the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax, the abolition or quarantining of negative gearing. The waiting list for public housing in Australia has grown, in those three disastrous years, by 23,839-up by 19 per cent.
—Particularly in New South Wales.

—Yes. Let us examine what is happening in the Labor-governed States. I have just cited the figures for the whole of Australia. Let us consider New South Wales, the governmental jewel in the crown of Labor, ruled for 10 years by a gentleman called Nifty. Let us take the three years of Labor government in Canberra, allied with the same three years of Labor government in New South Wales. In June 1983 the number on the waiting list for public housing in New South Wales was 51,432. That figure had jumped, three years later, to 57,437. An additional 6,005 families were waiting for public housing-a jump of 11.6 per cent. But let us not get too excited about New South Wales. After all, the figure for New South Wales has gone up by only 11.6 per cent. Let us consider Victoria, another Labor-governed State. In June 1983 the number of applicants on the public housing waiting list in Victoria was 17,718. Three years later the number was a massive 32,644-a jump of 14,926 in three years with Labor at the helm. That is a jump of 84.2 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us come back to Queensland. It is very popular with Government members to attack Queensland. They enjoy it. They have to do something. In June 1983 in Queensland the number of people on the waiting list for public housing was 10,238. It was down, by June 1986, three years later, to 9,044, a fall of 1,194, or 11.6 per cent. That is exactly the same percentage by which the waiting list has risen in New South Wales. The people of Australia are not fools. They will not continue to be conned by the nonsense that is being put out about Queensland and Australia by the Hawke Labor Government. Let us consider Western Australia, another Labor State. Honourable members will not be surprised to know that its record is pretty crook, too. In June 1983 there were 8,243 people on the waiting list for public housing. Three years later, under Labor, there were 11,190-a jump of 2,947.

TALK.START.PARA: —They must expect people to live in tents.

—Those feral women outside Parliament House are living in tents; they should be shifted. The increase in the number of people on the waiting list for public housing for Western Australia is 36 per cent, and Western Australia is another Labor State. How about South Australia? Three years ago the number of people on the public housing waiting list in South Australia was 28,774. In June 1986 it was 39,500-a jump of 10,726, or 37.2 per cent. How can honourable members opposite talk about their good government? They can be selective and choose their own indicators, but I am talking about the people whom they, the `workers friends', say they are there to help-the poor people. We in the National Party and our Liberal Party colleagues care. Honourable members opposite have lost sight of poor people. They can talk about housing starts; they are for people who have the money. But let us talk about the people who do not have the money to build their own homes, the disadvantaged people who are on public housing waiting lists. The statistics I have cited come from the Parliamentary Library. They are irrefutable and are a great indicator on what is happening in the vital area of housing under the Labor Government. In Tasmania, ruled by a Liberal government, the number of people on the public housing waiting list has risen by only 347.
—Because we have been squeezed by the Federal Government.

—Of course Tasmania has. The upshot of all this is inescapable. The people who really need housing are being killed by the shortage of funds for public housing. Others who might be able to afford to buy or build their own houses are being killed by the Government's interest rates, and even by the capital gains tax. Throughout Australia there are many young builders, hard-working men who, to make a start for their families, build a house. When they sell it they make a bit of money on it and build another one. That is how they get a start at being free enterprise people-by being productive. These people will be absolutely killed by the Government's capital gains tax, but the Government probably has not thought of that.
—And negative gearing.
—The effect on rentals of the negative gearing provisions will be absolutely frightful.
—Do you really believe that?
—Anybody with any sense believes it. In concluding--
—Not yet.

—I will do my best for the honourable member. I return to the figures which show the growth in the number of people on the public housing waiting lists in the Labor States. In New South Wales the figure is up by 11.6 per cent. In Victoria it is up by an amazing 84.2 per cent.
—Over what period is that?

—Three years. In Western Australia the figure is up by 36 per cent. In South Australia it is up by 37.2 per cent. In Queensland, which has a National Party Government with a balanced Budget, the figure has actually fallen by 11.6 per cent. That speaks volumes for good government and good management-which will continue after the Queensland State election.

—I rise on a point of order. During the concluding remarks of the honour- able member for Cowper-it was an excellent speech-the honourable member for Bendigo suggested that he continue. Would it be in order to grant him an extension?
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member for Groom will resume his seat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to speak in this debate. I must say that there have been a number of good contributions in this debate from many honourable members. I say at the outset that this Government is proud of its housing record. We are proud of what we have achieved in the 3 1/2 years we have been in government in terms of overall levels of activity in the housing industry, of providing jobs and of meeting social needs. Housing is crucial in terms of creating jobs and meeting very important social needs in our community.

SPEECH.PARA: The point was made earlier in an excellent contribution by the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard) that when we won government in March 1983 we inherited a housing industry which was in very poor shape-desperate shape. Total housing commencements in 1982-83 were only a little over 100,000 and for an economy and nation as large as ours that is a very poor level. To illustrate how poor that level of 105,000 commencements in the last year of the Fraser Government was, we need to compare it with what we were able to achieve only three years later in 1984-85, when more than 150,000 houses were started around Australia. That really was a dramatic increase. It was a 50 per cent increase in just that two to three year period. That is our record. I think it is important to emphasise when we look at the overall housing industry that we have been successful both in the private sector and in the public sector. Private sector dwelling commencements have been particularly strong and there has also been strong growth in the public sector, where, through the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, we have provided significant increases in funds for public housing. That is our record to date.

Many members of this House will recall that in April this year the Government took further action in the form of its housing industry package to ensure that our solid performance in the housing industry was able to continue for many years. Part of that package was to provide a subsidy to the banks of $150m to allow them to continue borrowing and lending at very high rates. With that subsidy we obtained agreement from the banks that they would lend at least $6 billion in 1986-87 as well as promoting the low start loans, which are so important to many people in our community who frequently buy their homes when they are young, when their income earning capacity is not high and when they are starting a young family. The low start loans have been very successful in that regard. The package we introduced in April has enjoyed a considerable degree of success. Home lending has continued to remain very strong and it looks as though in the financial year 1986-87 we will have 125,000 to 135,000 new housing starts. That is a very steady level of housing commencements.

There have been some suggestions recently that the Government would be asked to lift the 13 1/2 per cent ceiling on interest rates for existing home buyers. I want to make a few comments about that. I do not think there is any need at all to increase that ceiling. Lending is currently very strong. Deposit growth with the banks is still quite satisfactory. Indeed, the annual rate to July this year was more than 10 per cent over that of the previous year. We also have in place good arrangements in terms of fiscal policy and wages policy which should ensure that the pressure on interest rates is reduced as we head through the year and should provide the opportunity for good reductions in interest rates, particularly housing interest rates, early in the 1987 calendar year.

The Home Deposit Assistance Amendment Bill 1986 is more directly about assistance to first home buyers, but in that sense it affects the whole of the building industry. The Government's first home owners scheme has been remarkably successful. It is continuing in this Budget. Since its inception in October 1983 more than 200,000 first home owners have been assisted with grants of up to $6,000. We have paid out almost $1 billion. It has provided a boost to the building industry and it has given enormous assistance to many first home buyers who otherwise would not have been able to buy their first home and would now be on the private rental market bidding up the price of rents.

I will comment on a couple of points made in this debate. The honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) made some points about waiting lists, interest rates and home lending. He produced statistics which he said reflected waiting lists in States around Australia. I tend to think of the statistics he produced in terms of that old expression about lies, damned lies and statistics, because the fact is that under the 3 1/2 years of this Government overall housing commencements have been much higher than in the previous three years. Overall commencements in the private sector have shown very good growth and the increase in funds provided for public housing under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement is quite astronomical compared with what was provided under the Liberal Government. The question which has to be asked in respect of waiting lists is what would occur in the States if the Liberal policies on housing were ever introduced. The simple answer to that question is that we could undoubtedly predict that within the space of two to three years housing waiting lists for public housing throughout Australia would at least double. There is no doubt that under Liberal housing policies the waiting lists for public housing would double in the first two years.

Opposition members in their contributions to this debate have talked about housing in general terms but have neglected in any sense at all to talk about what a Liberal government would do for the housing industry if it were ever elected to office. In May this year the Opposition's draft housing policy was leaked-a common phenomenon nowadays. I see that the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), is in the House. It was a vacuous and scrappy document. It contained no vision for the future and no commitment to anybody in need in our community and, above all, it was typical of the free market rationalist approach which is now becoming such a strong hallmark of Opposition policies.

Housing is crucial to Australians. It is crucial to Australian families. It is crucial to Australians who are in need and to elderly people who look for assistance in buying elderly persons' units. Housing has a very wide embrace throughout our community. The Liberal's policy was remarkably vague on the question of the first home owners scheme. It suggested that grants for the first home owners scheme might be tied up in housing grants that go to the States and that it would be up to individual States to offer that scheme in the future if they wanted to do so. Let me make it quite clear that this Government intends to maintain the first home owners scheme. we have assisted more than 200,000 first home buyers with that scheme with grants of up to $6,000 and we intend to keep the scheme in the future because we think it assists Australians who deserve assistance in buying their first home.

On the question of public housing I simply say to those in the House and to those listening to the broadcast that people in the community who are in need of public housing, for whatever reason, would do well to study the record of the Fraser Liberal Government, because it absolutely slashed and decimated funding for public housing. Indeed, when Malcolm Fraser left office in 1983, he was spending well under half, in real terms, of what Gough Whitlam had been spending on public housing when he left office in 1975. To those people on public housing waiting lists I simply say that our policies are addressing the problem of the length of the waiting lists. In our three and a half years in government we have made remarkable achievements in housing commencements in both the private and the public sectors. I am genuinely concerned about what would happen to those people on waiting lists were a Liberal government ever to be re-elected to office. Have no doubt about it, there is no question that public housing waiting lists would double in the first two years of office of a Liberal government, and that would be outrageous.

I turn to interest rates and home lending. These were raised in debate by the honourable member for Cowper. In the last three years of the Liberal Government 735,000 homes were commenced around Australia. In the first three years of this Government 914,000 homes were commenced. So on any assessment or comparison of our record on home lending and home constructions, this Government's record is second to none. It is certainly vastly superior to that of the Fraser Government. The yearly average of home loans under this Government has been 305,000; under the Liberals it was 245,000. We are well ahead there. In money terms, something like $21 billion has been lent for housing under this Government's policies compared with $11 billion during the last three years of the Fraser Government. On the question of interest rates, I think we need to understand that it was the Liberals in 1982 who increased the housing interest rate by two percentage points to 13 1/2 per cent. Also, under the former Government the 10-year bond rate was a massive 16.4 per cent in June 1982. It is now 13 1/2 per cent under this government. Yet the Opposition piously lectures us on interest rates. In 1982 under the Fraser Liberal Government-the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Deakin, who is in the House, knows this very well-90-day bank bills peaked at more than 20 per cent. They are now down to 16.7 per cent. In the Australian Financial Review today there are further indications that the 90-day bank bill rate will fall even further.

My time has almost expired. In conclusion, I simply say that this Government has an excellent record in housing. It is manifest in my electorate of Bendigo, where more than 1,600 first home buyers have received assistance under the first home owners scheme. There has been a dramatic increase in funding for public housing in my electorate. For instance, in Bendigo in 1981-82, under the Fraser Government, 41 public housing dwellings were commenced; in 1984-85, under this Government, there were more than 111 commencements in the public housing sector. The rate was virtually three times as high, an increase of more than 200 per cent. The Bendigo electorate has been well supported by special programs such as the local government and community housing program. A number of local governments showing a great deal of initiative-councils such as Eaglehawk and Marong-have combined with the Federal Government to ensure that housing is made available to people in need. In the area of real need, crisis housing, this Government's policies have produced the goods in Bendigo, where organisations such as the Salvation Army have been assisted with funding to provide emergency accommodation, meeting a need in my electorate, I support the legislation and am proud to support this Government's housing achievements and the work of an excellent Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the House has witnessed Australian Labor Party members of the Parliament describing to the people of Australia what an excellent track record this Government has in terms of housing and rental accommodation being provided to all Australians. That is a load of drivel. I will substantiate that claim by quoting people who really have their fingers on the pulse of housing and rental accommodation in Australia. I quote this statement made on 15 October:

SPEECH.PARA: There is a crisis in the accommodation market . . . of the private rental markets and our housing markets in this country. That is a fact of life, that anyone in politics knows.

The gentleman who said that is none other than the Labor Minister for Housing in the New South Wales Parliament, Frank Walker. He has been shedding light on the true situation in housing and rental accommodation not only in New South Wales but throughout Australia. Mr Deputy Speaker, I can assure you that the crisis Frank Walker spoke of in New South Wales applies right across this country. Who is to blame for it? None other than the Labor Government here in Canberra. To explain and substantiate that claim I will quote further from the New South Wales Minister for Housing. He talked particularly about the high cost of rents in New South Wales. He said:

The parlous state of the private rental market in New South Wales is well-known to you all. Rents in Sydney have reached an all time high after 18 months of rapid rises and the shortage of rental accommodation is worsening as owners abandon real estate in favour of other investments.

I emphasise that statement because that abandonment of real estate as an investment has come about because of this Government and its interest rate policies. Interest rates are one of the great causes of the high costs of housing and rental accommodation in Australia. I once again quote Frank Walker, the Minister for Housing in the New South Wales Parliament. He talked about why interest rates are so crucial to the housing and rental accommodation crisis in Australia today. He said:

Continued high interest rates have had a major impact in substantially reducing housing affordability. Repayments on an average loan have increased by one quarter over the course of the last financial year. The high cost of housing finance remains the prime obstacle to home ownership for most low and middle income earners, and affordability is the name of the game.

So Frank Walker is telling us that interest rates are one of the prime causes of the crisis in housing and rental accommodation. Who is to blame for those high interest rates? None other than the Federal Government. Once again I quote Frank Walker, the fountain of truth in all things to do with housing. In a major statement he made in the last few weeks he said:
To attract higher levels of capital inflow, the Government imposed a tight monetary policy which resulted in record real levels of interest rates.
Mr Walker continued:
As the most interest rate sensitive of our industries, housing suffered most by this.

Other policies of the Federal Government have contributed to housing and rental accommodation problems in the last year or two. In legislation over the last 12 months the Government has introduced a capital gains tax and removed tax deductions on negative gearing. I again quote Mr Frank Walker in his statement of 15 October:

But there was another decision that affected the building industry. And that was the decision on income taxation. There was a change in our income taxation laws and the negative gearing that was given to landlords and encouraged investors in the private rental market, was taken away.

Mr Walker was clearly saying that the latest changes this Government has made to the taxation laws are causing problems in housing and rental accommodation in Australia today. Of course, one point he has neglected to make in his statements lately is that an additional factor in the housing crisis is the existing and proposed punitive landlord and tenant laws in New South Wales and all the other Labor States of Australia.

How bad is the situation in Australia? How badly affected is the rental market as a result of this Government's activities? In Sydney it is expected that in this calendar year the cost of rental accommodation will increase by 30 per cent. On the other side of the country, in Perth, rent for a three-bedroom average sort of home increased by 52 per cent between June 1985 and June 1986. There has been an increase of 52 per cent in Perth and 30 per cent in Sydney. That is as a result of what this Government is doing by way of its taxation laws and monetary policies. This Government is deliberately jacking up interest rates. Frank Walker has accurately described what it is doing. It is now costing 25 per cent more to repay housing loans than it did in the last couple of years. It is a known fact that people who obtained finance for housing during 1985-86 are now paying 25 per cent more in order to meet their commitments.

It is also interesting to look at the cost of rental accommodation as a proportion of one's income to determine how bad the housing crisis in Australia has become. I asked the Parliamentary Library in the last few days to tell me what percentage of a person's income is now spent on providing him with standard or average rental accommodation in Australia. The Library produced these statistics: In 1974-75 average rental accommodation cost a person 12.46 per cent of his income; in 1975-76 the figure rose to 13.83 per cent; and by 1984 the figure had risen to 15.16 per cent. So, in 10 years, the outlay for rental accommodation has risen from 12 and a bit per cent to 15 and a bit per cent of a person's income.

If honourable members want to find out how much it costs to purchase a house as a proportion of one's income, it is interesting to ask the Library to produce the facts. I have done so, and these are the figures it has provided to me: In 1978-79 it cost 4.4 times one's average annual income to purchase the average home; in 1981-82 it cost five times the average annual income to purchase the average home; and in 1984 it cost 6.9 times average annual income to purchase the average home. So it is costing 50 per cent more in real terms to purchase a home today than it did a few years ago. The situation, rather than getting better, is getting worse. As I mentioned earlier, rent now takes a bigger slice of one's pay packet every week. It now takes 50 per cent longer to save to purchase the average home. Fewer people are now able to afford a home than was the case only a few years ago.

The practices of this Government and the unions, particularly the Builders Labourers Federation, will create, and have already started to create, a generation of Australians who will expect only to be able to live in accommodation such as caravans. That is all that people are able to afford these days. The reason that that is the case is that this Government, through its monetary policies, has increased interest rates. This Government, through its taxation policies, has introduced capital gains taxes and negative gearing taxes. Throughout the Labor States of Australia there are punitive landlord and tenant Acts which discourage people from investing in rental accommodation. The Government, through its taxation laws and monetary policies, has effectively driven the investor out of the rental market. These policies are making it impossible for ordinary people to afford to build a home.

In my electorate, for example, it is interesting to see how bad the situation is. In Cowra, a town of 8,000 people, in May this year, 118 people had applied for public housing. In this town 188 groups of people are already living in Housing Commission homes. In Nowra the situation is far worse. There are 327 groups of people who have received approval to move into Housing Commission accommodation, but who have not yet moved into it. Another 122 people are waiting for approval. In Goulburn, about 196 groups of people are waiting for Housing Commission accommodation. These Housing Commission waiting lists would be longer than they already are if it were not for the ridiculously low income levels at which eligibility for Housing Commission homes cuts off. In the case of a single person, eligibility cuts out at an income of $201 a week and for a married couple it cuts out at $250 a week. That, of course, is just too low by today's standards.

Housing Commission waiting lists, in my view, do not show the true position of the need for public housing in Australia. Last week I conducted a very quick survey of the real estate agents in my electorate. It was interesting to hear their comments. In Goulburn, for example, the comments generally were that there was very little rental accommodation and the cost of rent for existing accommodation had increased by as much as $10 a week in the last few months. In the Shoalhaven area very little rental accommodation is available. In Cowra, there is very little rental accommodation and rental costs for existing accommodation have increased by as much as 12 to 15 per cent in the last 12 months. In fact, one agent described the availability of rental accommodation as desperate. In Young, the real estate agents said that many families were on waiting lists for rental accommodation. Rents have gone up in the last 12 months so that landlords can afford just to break even on their investments. One of the agents even mentioned that landlords are now getting out of the residential property market.

This Government must act. This Government must be prepared to encourage domestic investment. It must be prepared, right across Australia, to encourage the abolition of the punitive landlord and tenant Acts. It must be prepared to axe the capital gains tax, the negative gearing tax and the fringe benefits tax. The Government should not underestimate the impact of the fringe benefits tax on the housing crisis in Australia. The Government must reduce interest rates. Otherwise, instead of people throughout the country having a home which they can call a home-that is, a nice, three or four bedroom brick home, which we were all brought up to believe was a typical home-they will have a trailer park home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure for me to follow the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards), the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard) and the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) in this debate on the Home Deposit Assistance Amendment Bill 1986. I would also like to thank the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh) for his contribution. The honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) cited statistics, as was mentioned by the honourable member for Bendigo, in an endeavour to show the relative inefficiency of Labor State governments to provide public housing. I point out to the honourable member for Cowper, although he is not in the chamber at the moment, that he seems to be unaware of changes in eligibility and application criteria in recent times which enable single people to apply for State housing assistance. From his statistics one could draw the conclusion that people in Tasmania and Queensland either are not single or are leaving those States in droves to go to the States in which Labor governments prevail. However, I will return to the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a machinery Bill of the most necessary kind. It will bring about the end of a piece of legislation which has no further use but which continues to cause unnecessary work and recording, as well as associated administrative costs. Its purpose is to provide an end date for the lodgment of applications under the Home Deposit Assistance Act 1982 and to provide that the Minister need not report on the operation of that Act after 30 June. As most honourable members will be aware, the home deposit assistance scheme was introduced by the Fraser Government in 1982. It provided up to $3,500 to people who bought homes between 18 March 1982 and 30 September 1983. However, it was superseded by the first home owners scheme, which is acknowledged to be a vastly superior way of assisting families with their home ownership aspirations, providing, as it did originally, a $7,000 grant for assistance with deposits or mortgage repayments, and subsequently a $6,000 grant.

At that time the Government agreed to allow a reasonable period for eligible people to continue to apply for home deposit assistance under the old Act of 1982. Accordingly, more than two years later, the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) has indicated that the home deposit assistance scheme will be discontinued at the end of this year. Only a small number of late applications have been received during the past 12 months. If honourable members opposite view the position objectively, which I am sure they are capable of doing, they will agree that three years is a reasonable period for the limited number of people who may be eligible under the old scheme to have availed themselves of it. If any genuine applicants still remain they have until 31 December to lodge their claim.

I think it bears repeating that the scheme we are discussing applies only to homes purchased between 18 March 1982 and 30 September 1983; it is effectively obsolete. Its demise is even more logical when seen in the context of the first home owners scheme which superseded it. I remind honourable members that $210m has been allocated to the first home owners scheme for 1986-87 and, as a result, 41,500 successful low and middle income earners will have been able to acquire homes. By the end of the 1986-87 financial year the total number of successful applicants will have risen to 245,000 since the inception of the scheme in 1983.

In my electorate of Cowan, which has a significant amount of housing construction, the first home owners scheme has been very successful. The select construction concept of the Western Australian Government has also considerably extended the scheme's applicability to new home builders and increased the employment potential of the first home owners scheme as a result. Regrettably from my point of view it has not been possible to extend the first home owners scheme to some people who have been in a home ownership situation previously from which they have derived no apparent benefit. A constituent of mine has been rendered ineligible for the scheme because his wife had been married before and been a joint owner of a home in the course of that previous relationship. Unfortunately at the present time this previous part ownership has to be taken into account even though my constituent's wife had derived no real, lasting or capital benefit from it.

Like other members on this side of the House, I handle a large number of State Housing Commission inquiries through my office even though they may be technically referred to a member of the State Parliament. It is important that Federal members also be kept aware of the housing needs of their constituents who cannot afford to either purchase or privately rent a home. Our Government has a long-standing and well-recognised commitment to the provision of adequate public housing. The provision of this type of housing assists those people in poverty or conditions bordering upon it. We have also extended rental assistance to unemployed people in private rental accommodation.

As commented on by the honourable member for Stirling, housing costs are cheaper in Western Australia than in most other States. This is reflected in the level of home ownership and in access to the first home owners scheme. Like him, I reiterate my personal commitment to the retention of the 13.5 per cent housing interest rate ceiling on existing home loans.

Contrary to the claims of the Opposition, the Federal Government is not committed to a high interest rate policy. We understand that rising interest rates affect the ability of home purchasers to keep up with their mortgage repayments as well as reducing the possibility for potential home buyers to build or buy a home over the longer term. However, housing, or the lack of it, is undoubtedly a contributor to poverty. As a result it has been argued quite successfully in some academic papers that an after-housing poverty measurement should be adopted. It is claimed that the after-housing poverty line is a much more sensitive measure than its before-housing counterpart, acknowledging the effect of home ownership as a form of wealth.

This Government is committed to alleviating housing problems. We will continue to assist home buyers and people in need of public housing. The Western Australian Labor Government has made particular provision for people in public housing to make the transition to home ownership through the State Housing Commission or Homeswest. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard three tables which relate to the after-housing poverty to which I referred earlier. They cannot be read.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The tables are drawn from an article in the Australian Quarterly of Autumn 1986. I believe that they may help some other members understand the reason for the argument in favour of adopting a measure relating to after-housing measurement of poverty. What would a Liberal government do about housing? Nothing! Under a Liberal government public housing would fall off the end of the earth. Private housing would be unaffordable for middle-income earners. I congratulate the Minister upon his commitment to his portfolio and upon his commitment to public housing. I commend him also for his endeavours to maximise assistance to first home buyers in this country and in my electorate of Cowan in particular.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Home Deposit Assistance Amendment Bill sets out to establish a final date of 31 December 1986 for the lodgment of an application under the now phased-out Home Deposit Assistance Act 1982. It also requires me, as Minister, to report to the Parliament on the administration of that Act for one more year, the 1986-87 financial year. It is a fairly simple Bill and, of course, honourable members on both sides of the House have taken the opportunity-as I think is quite proper-to develop the debate into a more wide-ranging one on housing policy and programs generally. In that context, the Opposition has seen fit to seek to amend the motion for the second reading. It is an amendment that the Government emphatically rejects. I just want briefly to give the House some of the reasons why the Government rejects it and in so doing I will cover some of the points raised during the debate by the Opposition housing spokesman, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale).

SPEECH.PARA: Our first home owners assistance scheme is infinitely superior to the former Government's scheme, which it replaces. To begin with, the first home owners scheme makes available both a lump sum and an interest bill subsidy, whereas the old home deposit assistance scheme only made available a lump sum. The first home owners scheme has been hailed by first home seekers, industry organisations, trade unions and lending institutions as the most successful home ownership assistance program ever seen in this country. To date, some 215,000 Australian households have benefited by way of a lump sum and/or interest subsidy, and almost $1,000m has been paid out or is committed under the scheme. Of course, that is not the end of it and we expect that about $210m will be allocated under it during this financial year. So much for the first home owners scheme. FHOS lives, FHOS continues, FHOS is infinitely superior to its predecessor. As far as industry performance is concerned, Mr Speaker--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman is very generous but Deputy Speaker will do fine, thank you.

—I apologise, Mr Deputy Speaker. Let us just look at the state of the industry. In each of the three years that this Government has been in office-having in mind also the expectations for this year-housing commencements have far exceeded those achieved during the last year in office of the previous Government. That Government achieved only 105,000 starts in that year. In contrast, in every year since, culminating in 1984-85, when it achieved 153,000 starts, the Hawke Labor Government has achieved far more housing starts than did the previous Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), in responding to the motion for the second reading, covered the issue of employment in Australia and in the housing and construction industry generally. I will just give the House the figures. Back in the middle of 1983, 387,000 persons were employed in the housing and construction industry. Currently 490,000 are so employed; that is, over 100,000 more people are employed in the housing and construction industry than were so employed when this Government attained office. Those figures speak for themselves.

I turn now, very briefly, to the issue of Federal funding of public housing. This year funding by Federal and State governments combined for public housing, for the acquisition of rental accommodation and for the subsidisation of assisted loans to low income earners through the co-operative societies, the State banks and other lending instrumentalities that the State governments wish to use, will total almost $2 billion. The results are evident in the figures. I wish to refer to the record in 1982-83 of the former Government. I am sure that the honourable member for Deakin would rather not be associated with the housing performance of that Government, but he cannot escape it because its record in public housing was very poor and very bad indeed. Of course, his latest policy is, by abolishing pensioner assistance and Aboriginal rental assistance programs, to slash savagely funding for public housing. I do not want to digress too far. I was pointing out that, as a result of increased funding through direct grants and cheap loans under State borrowing programs at the concessional interest rate of 41/2 per cent, the Federal Government and the States are going to spend some $2,000m on public housing assistance in this financial year. In addition to allowing 14,000 to 15,000 low interest loans to be made available, Federal and State funding of public housing, this will also enable about 22,500 new commencements to occur. Rental acquisitions this year should increase by about 18,000. That represents more than double the number of yearly acquisitions-or add-ons to the national stock-that the former Government achieved in 1982-83. The Labor Government has doubled the number of annual acquisitions to the national rental housing stock. That is a mighty performance in anyone's language.
I turn now to the issue of the private rental market, which has attracted some publicity recently and which the Opposition spokesman mentioned in his speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you agree with Frank Walker?

—I am perfectly well aware of the nature of the remarks made by the New South Wales Minister for Housing. Regarding what Frank Walker had to say about negative gearing, I simply say this: It is the policy of the Opposition, not of the Government, to restore the tax rorts which were inherent in the old system of allowing tax write-offs to the extent of the full interest bill being offset against all income. We do not allow that any more and do not apologise for our decision in that regard. If the New South Wales State Labor Government and its Minister wish to embrace such tax avoidance measures as were evident in the policy of the former Federal Government it is on the State Government's shoulders, not mine. We will not return to that situation. Let us just have a look at the figures. Without decrying the tightness of the private rental market, without wishing to minimise the fact that that rental market is tight in two cities, Sydney and Perth-there are specific reasons why it is tight in Perth-I should point out that, according to the latest report of the Real Estate Institute of Australia regarding vacancy rates in the private rental market, only in the cities of Sydney and Perth is the vacancy rate tighter than it was four years ago, in September 1982. Let me compare some figures. Melbourne, in September 1982, had a vacancy rate, according to the Real Estate Institute of Australia quarterly report, of 1.4 per cent. Today its rate is 1.8 per cent. In Brisbane at that time the rate was 0.8 per cent; today it is 4.5 per cent. If honourable members opposite want to say that the result of the policy changes on negative gearing has been to create a vacancy tightness in Sydney and in Perth, I say to them that it was certainly not a good result that the outcome of the tax rorting, tax avoidance policies which existed in the period to September 1982 created vacancy rates in Brisbane and Melbourne of 0.8 and 1.4 per cent respectively. I understand also that some figures were given regarding the alleged blowout in rentals in the private market of the major cities. Some very extravagant figures, up to 25 and 30 per cent, were mentioned. There has been a slight increase in rental charges, but to nowhere near the extent indicated by the figures mentioned by the Opposition. The private rental component of the consumer price index increased by 10.7 per cent in the year to June 1986. This is to be set beside a CPI rise of 8.4 per cent over the comparable period. So there was a slight disparity, but nothing like the disparity that the honourable member for Deakin claimed during his speech. What the Government has done in this area is introduce a depreciation allowance on new buildings, and that will continue. It has the added advantage of stimulating new construction, rather than speculative activity in the existing market.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the issue, raised by the Opposition, of the availability of finance now compared with its availability when the former Government was in office. The Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for housing finance extended by all significant lenders have just been released. I do not know whether honourable members opposite are aware of that but they should have a look at the figures. The seasonally adjusted figures for the month of August 1986 show that $992.5m was lent by all lending institutions. That represents an annualised rate of almost $12 billion. Savings banks lent $638m or at an annualised rate of $7.6 billion, which compares with about $2.9 billion during the last year of office of the former Government. I repeat that I would be the first to say, as I have in this House, that the 15.5 per cent rate for new-I stress new-savings bank loans does put some pressure upon the capacity of some lower income earners to afford those loans. I have also pointed to the availability of low start loans and invite the Opposition to join me in publicising the availability of those loans. If more people inquire at the banks as to their availability and take them up it will certainly help the industry. For instance, the Commonwealth Savings Bank has a scheme which offers a starting rate of 9.5 per cent, to be repaid over 15 years at progressively higher repayments. Westpac has a similar scheme with an initial repayment based on an interest rate of 12.5 per cent. The National Australia Bank has a scheme which involves an initial repayment at 10 per cent. The Australia and New Zealand Bank's scheme involves the repayment of 80 per cent of a normal 20-year repayment figure. The State Bank of Victoria offers a 12.5 per cent starting rate, as does the Advance Bank. Significant advantages are available to people under low start loans, if they care to take them up. I have pointed out that the first home owners scheme also offers to low income earners a significant interest rate subsidy that is spread over five years.

Having said all of that, I return to the fundamental issue-the economic questions that have been raised during this debate. It is true to say that the future of interest rates will determine the immediate and intermediate future of the housing industry. I point out to the honourable member for Deakin, who sagely nods his head in agreement, that short term bill rates reached an all-time high in June 1982, and that the current trend is for short term interest rates to head downwards. Currently, 90-day bank bill rates are about 16.5 per cent and, as I have said before, that will soon be reflected in a drop in cash management trust rates, the rates that in the main compete with those for savings banks deposits. We have in place fiscal policies which will be conducive to a reduction in short term interest rates. For instance, the Budget deficit was reduced by 38 per cent this year. (Quorum formed). As I was saying before that diversion, this Government has in place the fiscal policies to ensure that the current downward trend in short term business rates will continue. The Budget deficit has been reduced by 38 per cent, a domestic surplus level of $0.8 billion has been established and the public sector borrowing requirement has been reduced to 4.4 per cent of gross domestic product. All this is conducive to a downward trend in short term interest rates. On top of that over recent days, as everyone knows, the Australian dollar has firmed considerably and remains stable, so conditions are in place which will permit the lowering of short term interest rates, which in turn should benefit the housing industry over the next few quarters.

The last point that I want to take up is the Opposition's assertion that the former Government ran low-tax policies. I simply point to the tables on income tax that were introduced as part of the 1982 Budget-the last presented by the former Government under which a person earning less than $35,788 was subjected to a taxation rate of 46c in the dollar.

DEBATE.TITLE: NURSING HOMES AND HOSTELS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 October, on motion by Mr Howe:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say at the outset that the Opposition does not oppose the Bill, notwithstanding that it has certain concerns about the Government's policy on care for the aged and will be moving an amendment at the Committee stage to certain detail and machinery provisions of the measure. It is very timely that the Bill should come before the Parliament now because in the nursing homes of New South Wales, and shortly Australia, we will see a general crisis emerging-mainly because this Government's rhetoric has not been turned into action. Care for the aged in this community is something with which we should all be very, very much concerned. We all have parents. We all face the inevitability of old age. With that old age comes a concern for our security and for our capacity to deal with our rapidly changing community. This Government, because it has failed to translate its rhetoric into effective policy, has in New South Wales caused considerable trauma, suffering and worry for many residents of nursing homes. This trauma arises because the Government is unaware of, or is unconcerned about, the consequences of its actions.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of an increase in wage rates for nurses, as well as in the overall cost of operating nursing homes, a general increase in fees was granted. The minimum fee increase was $5.10 per day, which meant that for all nursing homes in New South Wales there was a $35.70 per patient per week increase in fees. For those who are not aware of the funding arrangements for nursing home care, it is important to understand that the cost of paying for nursing home care is met by, first, the contribution on the part of the patients themselves, generally through pension or rental assistance when available and, second the Commonwealth bed subsidy. What has happened, because of this Government's policy, is that the approved fees charged by nursing homes have gone up. But nothing has been done about the level of pension paid to many of the residents in those homes and no decision has been taken on the Commonwealth bed subsidy. The consequence of that inaction has been that a considerable gap, has developed between the income available to the nursing home through the bed subsidy and the contribution made by the patient or resident-through pension and/or rent subsidy if available-and the cost of providing the accommodation. In some cases that differential has widened to the extent, I am told, of $80 a week. In one case, because of the type of care provided it has gone even higher.

The problem that this Government must really come to terms with is that we are dealing with people. We are not dealing with the administrative convenience of the bureaucracy. We are not dealing with the scheduling convenience of the Cabinet. I am aware that there is a proposal from the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) to Cabinet seeking a review of the Commonwealth Government contribution to the bed subsidy, but I am told that that is not going to be considered until next week. The approval for fee increases took place, in most cases, on either 1 October or 15 October. Before a decision is taken there will be a considerable period during which a large number of elderly Australians will be insecure as to their status in the community and the future of their accommodation. Of course we have no guarantee of the decision that Cabinet will make. I believe that it is about time that the Government actually recognised the consequences of its actions and translated its rhetoric about concern, about commitment to welfare, into effective welfare policies, into an administrative policy that did not cause hardship. This, of course, is not the first time that this gap has arisen. In my experience as a member of parliament the problem has arisen on an annual basis. This year it is exacerbated because of the size of the fee increases approved but to my knowledge there has been no attempt by the Government to synchronise the increase in pensions through consumer price index adjustment, the approval dates for nursing home fee increases and the review of the bed subsidy. There is always a period in which people are concerned about their ability to meet the gap between the funds available to them, both directly and indirectly, and the charges imposed upon them by the source of their accommodation. This Government, in campaigning for office, talked about an Office of Aged Care. It was very tardy in implementing that promise. The Government having implemented that Office, at this stage, I see no evidence of its being effective in developing a more practical and more humane set of policies for the aged in our community. Quite frankly, I see no evidence of a concern to consider the interaction of the various welfare policies that affect the aged in our community. There is no concern to understand the interaction of such political decisions as the implementation of the assets test, the withdrawal of income concession averaging provisions or even the deferral of the CPI adjustments to pensions or the impact that this will have on those in our community who are perhaps the least able to cope with these changes-that is, the residents of nursing homes.

As I have said, the Opposition does not oppose the Bill. We believe that in general terms it is a move in the right direction. We are concerned that greater emphasis should be placed on alternative care facilities for the aged in our community. There has been a general policy on the part of all recent governments that 70 per cent of residents in approved accommodation institutions should be able to meet the cost of accommodation with seven-eighths of their age pension and rent assistance, if payable. I believe that there is a need for a firm statement by this Government of its commitment to a continuation of this policy and a recognition that there needs to be administrative change as to the details of the way in which the components of that policy interact. We cannot afford in the future to have unpredictable periods during which a gap obtains. We cannot afford to allow that gap to blow out for periods of time without having an underpinning policy which provides security for those residents.

It is important to understand the significance of the cost to the Commonwealth Government of providing aged accommodation. I am told that 55 per cent of the Department of Community Services' annual costs are accounted for by the provision of accommodation assistance and subsidies for the aged of Australia. Those subsidies are of benefit to a relatively small number of aged Australians. Most elderly Australians still live independently. Of those aged between 65 and 74, 1.5 per cent benefit from these subsidies; of those aged 75 to 84, 8.5 per cent benefit; and of those 85 and older, 36 per cent benefit. There are still a large number of Australians who are independent. It is for those Australians that we should be looking towards developing a more creative, more imaginative and more diverse system of accommodation support. There are a number of options available. These were considered in a review of accommodation available to aged Australians recently commissioned by the Government. In general terms we have no argument with the results of that study.

In his second reading speech, the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), speaking on behalf of his colleague in the other place, indicated that the basic philosophical goals of the Government in this area were fourfold. The first was that aged and disabled people should, as far as possible, be supported in their own homes and in their own communities. That is an objective that we support. The second was that aged and disabled people should be supported by residential services only where other support systems were not appropriate to meeting their needs. We have no argument with that objective at all. The third was that services should be provided in an atmosphere which promoted, and using processes which promoted, as far as possible rehabilitation and restoration of function. It was stated that the manner in which services were provided should develop and enhance personal freedom and the independent functioning of all residents. We wholeheartedly support that objective also. The fourth was that services should be based on a recognition that, for many, being discharged to a residential service that provided a less intensive form of care, or to a community-based support service, would be a possible and desirable outcome. That, of course, is a laudable objective and has the total support of the Opposition. We are also generally in agreement with the approach of the Government in terms of the principles underpinning its planning in this area. In his second reading speech the Minister said that the processes underlying the development of the Government's policies in these matters would include:
(i) the requirement for flexible planning, which provides for monitoring, evaluation and changes where necessary, including more integration with community services;
(ii) a publicised and better resourced hostel sector so that hostels can care for increasingly dependent aged people;
(iii) the extension of residential care services beyond hostels to other forms of accommodation such as group housing arrangements;

We support that and would add that we believe that those Australians who wish to live independently in their later years should have the capacity to do so provided, of course, that they also bear the financial responsibility for living outside any government approved system. The Minister continued:
(iv) the expansion of community services to assist those elderly people most at risk of premature and inappropriate institutionalisation . . .
That, of course, is a most important consideration and of great concern to many old people. The final principle laid down was:
(v) the importance of carefully developing the process of assessment so that it will gain support from consumers, professionals and service providers.

That, of course, is also very important because we cannot have a system that is not supported by those who are part of the system. Mr Deputy Speaker, it concerns me that the Government has moved in these directions. Previously in this place we have considered legislation known as the Home and Community Care Act. It was designed to provide additional financial facilities for the care of people outside of institutional care facilities. The Opposition at the time supported that legislation. We have, however, been concerned to see that its implementation has been far from perfect and that the objectives of the Government have not been achieved. We are concerned also that part of the problem in achieving those objectives relates to the attitudes of State governments. We are also concerned that perhaps those attitudes reflect the parochial nature of State governments and a determination on the part of those governments to persist with their own policies notwithstanding the Federal Government's contribution by way of finance. We believe that it is necessary to persist with that direction of policy development and would encourage the Government to do so at every opportunity and in the strongest possible terms.

Turning now to the provisions of the Bill itself, as I said, we on this side do not oppose it. In general terms we agree with the principles that underlie it. However, as with many pieces of Labor Government legislation we are concerned about the detail of the way in which it intends to implement the proposals. We are concerned that the proposals are perhaps a little centralised, provide perhaps too much power in the hands of the Minister and, in one particular area in respect of which we will be proposing an amendment later in this debate, give the Minister absolute discretion. We believe that in that particular case it is appropriate for the matter to be brought before the Parliament and for the Parliament to have power of disallowance if that is considered appropriate.

This Bill has a number of parts. Part I is a preliminary and introductory passage. Part II amends the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act. It affords the Minister discretion to give up to 100 per cent, instead of 80 per cent, of capital funding for financially disadvantaged groups. That, of course, has the effect of eliminating the need for a matching grant. In the circumstances in which I believe the Minister intends to use that discretion we believe that it is an appropriate change and we support it. However, we do believe that there is a need for the Parliament to have the power of disallowance concerning such proposals. It also increases funding for people receiving hostel care services, personal care services and respite care services in hostels. Parts III and IV amend the National Health Act and the Nursing Homes Assistance Act respectively. Control of the growth of the number of nursing home beds is obtained by allowing the Minister to specify a maximum of subsidised beds in each State and Territory, and region of a State or Territory.

That is one example of our concern about the specific provisions or approaches that the Labor Government adopts in regard to legislation of this type. There is a tendency to centralise such power in the hands of the Minister. Notwithstanding our recognition of the need to have overall planning control, we believe that it is important for there to be countervailing balances to ensure that the needs of regions are truly met and there is an appropriate recognition of the competing demands of the various regions. Australia, as is well known to all members of this place, is a very large and diverse country. Our demographic pattern has aberrations. Some regions have much higher numbers of aged people than do others. To be frank about it, from time to time differences in priorities arise out of the political circumstances of the time. For that reason we believe that there is a need for a public decision-making process and a capacity in the Parliament to examine the basis of the Minister's decisions in allocating facilities throughout Australia. I do not believe that there can be any real argument against the provision of public information regarding this particular process. In my own region, that of the far north coast of New South Wales, we have a higher than normal number of aged people. We have fewer than the necessary number of aged care facilities. That particular situation should and must be rectified. As honourable members know, I represent the National Party and Australia currently has a Labor Government in power. I would hope that we would have a process of decision-making that would assure all of the people of Australia that political considerations would not be involved in determining the allocation of resources throughout the country. I cite that merely as an example of the need to reassure all Australians that determining aged care policy in Australia occurs on a non-party political basis. I personally believe that it is something that is beyond party politics and that there is a need for a genuine bipartisan approach to the decision-making process concerning it.

The other provisions of Parts III and IV allow the Minister to specify, on the basis of advice from the aged care advisory committees, which regions should be allocated special needs beds; to set a maximum of such beds in a State and Territory; to approve a nursing home, firstly, in principle and, secondly, as to the premises themselves after construction; to revoke approval for a nursing home which does not comply with the conditions specified. That is, of course, a most important power. These provisions also enable the Minister to specify who will be allowed to occupy special needs beds; and, finally, to alter from time to time the conditions applicable to a nursing home. With reference to the concerns that I have expressed, we have no argument in general terms with that particular process. We believe that, used properly, it will promote better aged care and enable all Australians to have confidence in their future and a belief that in their old age appropriate accommodation will be available to them at an affordable cost. As I have mentioned, I am concerned that there does not seem to be on the part of the Government a preparedness to examine the interaction of the social welfare policies that exist from time to time. I believe that it is appropriate to continue in the direction of changing the emphasis from the provision of nursing home beds to the other options that are available to care for people. Those options, of course, include such things as self-care units and hostel care. I am, however, concerned that we do not see public debate occurring about the method of allocating government finance in this particular area.

Perhaps I could take a moment to examine the principles underlying the provision of the bed subsidy. There is general agreement in Australia that our welfare system should be needs-based. Once a nursing home bed is approved, the Commonwealth bed subsidy continues to be paid on that bed irrespective of the person who occupies it. There is, I believe, a need to consider, first of all, the person's need to occupy the bed and, secondly, that person's financial situation. We could have a situation where there was a continuing demand for fairly scarce Commonwealth resources in this area because of a failure to adjust the underlying principles of aged care financial assistance. It would be appropriate in my view to ensure that there was a consistent philosophy underlying our welfare system, to ensure that the limited resources available, both directly through the Department of Social Security and by way of program assistance through the Department of Community Services, were allocated on the same basis. There should be, I believe, confidence on the part of all those Australians who are interested, both personally and on behalf of members of their family, that there will continue to be a consistent policy in this area.

The Opposition does not regard this as a controversial Bill. It has our support. We have certain reservations about the implementation of the policy and will propose an amendment at the Committee stage. On that basis I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to support the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill I do so with a good deal of enthusiasm. This is the first piece of legislation, I think it is fair to say, since the days of the Menzies Government, that has really shaken up the underlying principles on which our nursing homes and hostels are administered and I think that it is probably long overdue. The system that was established after the war and in the 1950s has really just been allowed to grow like Topsy with only limited adjustments over the years. The review that the Government has undertaken, which led to this legislation, undoubtedly was long overdue and will ensure that proper parameters for the aged care system in this country will be laid down and developed over the ensuing few years. I want at the outset to comment on a couple of things that the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) had to say. I share to some extent his concern about ensuring that the various regions of this nation are properly equipped with nursing home beds and hostels, but I must say that I was a bit surprised at his comment, that he was concerned that his own electorate, and the area of the north coast and the northern regions of New South Wales generally, were not adequately equipped with nursing home beds. I would have thought that he, as a National Party member, would be only too aware of the fact that the north coast and northern areas of New South Wales have, for a generation and longer, been represented in this place by National Party members-Mr Sinclair, Mr Anthony and various others. If there is anybody to blame for the fact that that area of the nation lacks nursing home beds and hostels, quite clearly it must be sheeted home to National Party representation over the last generation. There is no doubt that if those honourable members had been doing their jobs adequately the situation that he complains of would not exist.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, this is an important piece of legislation and one which is going to ensure that aged care in this country will be adequate and responsive to the needs that are obviously going to develop over the next few years, as the population ages. There is an obvious imbalance in the way in which Government resources are directed towards providing the assistance required by our senior citizens. This manifests itself in a number of ways and is the result of many factors. Briefly these are as follows: There is a geographical imbalance, as to where nursing homes are situated. In most cases they are in the wealthy areas and, although this is a generalisation, if we refer to the cities of the nation we find that the vast majority of nursing home beds are to be found in the eastern suburbs-the eastern suburbs of Melbourne; the eastern suburbs of Sydney; the eastern suburbs of Adelaide and the eastern suburbs of Brisbane. The system as it exists promotes an uncontrolled growth of highly institutionalised and expensive care which is not always consistent with the needs or wishes of aged people. If I could just comment on that for a moment, one only has to go to nursing homes, as I do frequently in my electorate, to see many people who really do not need to be there particularly but who, because of their fear for the future, have sought nursing homes beds-or their families have sought them-when they have been available. They feared that a bed may not be available later when the need for one became more acute. A further factor is that the expense of providing institutionalised aged care has meant that the poorer sections of the community have been quite severely disadvantaged. If, in the Adelaide metropolitan area, we go to the area of Elizabeth, we find that virtually no nursing home beds exist. The newer working class areas are very poorly serviced with such beds. To some extent there has been a legitimate argument that those beds have not been needed so much there because the age of the population has been lower, but that situation is rapidly changing. The institutionalised structures have been tending to establish nursing homes beds in the more well-to-do areas where there are already community groups operating nursing homes with a capacity to continue to expand the number of beds that they operate, simply because of the fact that they are able to generate funds.

Since coming to office, the Government has been very concerned to redress the imbalances and the inequalities that the factors I have mentioned have produced. In particular the review of nursing homes and hostels was undertaken to enable the Government to get high quality information and advice on the problems of aged care throughout the nation. One problem is that we have had very little information with which to plan for the future of aged care provision. We know more about the animal population of this country than we do about the numbers, problems, and whereabouts of our senior citizens. I believe that is a great condemnation of the way in which we have treated our senior citizens. The review's recommendations were very well received. Consequently, the Government has decided to move quickly to implement its decisions, which are consistent with the recommendations that were made. This Bill, in the Budget context, is the first in a series of pieces of legislation which will be introduced over the next 12 months to give effect to the recommendations contained in the review.

Just what did the review recommend? First, it suggested that there needed to be a move away from intensive, institutionalised care to home and community care. This means a move from high cost nursing home provision to the more flexible, more human, and more cost-efficient care, such as hostels, home care, and special services for special groups in the community. Second, it found that nursing homes were outrageously expensive to run. The aging of our population means that the costs associated with the existing provision are going to increase markedly and rapidly. It will be impossible for any Government to maintain the existing level of expenditure into the medium term. At the moment we are spending over $1,000m each year on nursing home recurrent subsidies. We spend only $100m on home and community care programs. Most aged people want to live at home and in fact most do. Only 7 per cent of our senior citizens live in nursing homes. The other 93 per cent live at home, or in other circumstances. The imbalance here is patently obvious. We are spending $1,000m, or one billion dollars, each year on 7 per cent of the aged population, and only $100m on the remaining 93 per cent. This can hardly be said to be equitable.

To return to the main features of the system as it stands, there is no incentive at present to prevent the uncontrolled growth of nursing home beds. In fact the system is working as a positive incentive for get rich quick merchants to rip off both the old and the Government. There is no doubt that this has occurred. We have only to look at a number of the reports that have circulated to know that the conditions in some nursing homes are absolutely disgraceful, leaving those who are inmates-since there is no other word to describe people while in such institutions-with little or no dignity, with little or no comfort, and with little or no respect. I am pleased to say, Mr Deputy Speaker, that in my electorate the nursing homes are of a very high quality-all in quite new buildings, in pleasant surroundings and have staff, as I have found on my visits, who treat patients and residents with the greatest of care, love, and attention. But, as we know from many of the reports that have submitted by both the Commonwealth Government and the State governments, that is not the situation throughout the nation. The fact is, however, that the current system acts to encourage uncontrolled growth and means that the few who have access to nursing homes have an easier time of it than they might otherwise have. Secondly, Australia has a very good provision of beds in nursing homes and hostels. It has more than 100 beds per thousand people over the age of 70, which is the target that has been set. In a community where most senior citizens have expressed a preference for living in their own homes, or with their families, a system which encourages uncontrolled growth above the target, with the increased expenditure that this will involve, cannot be justified on either economic or social grounds. The Government, in accepting the recommendations of the review, is planning to change the mix in the provision of beds for institutional care. This change will not be disruptive and will not be rapid. It will occur in a planned and sensitive way over the next 20 to 25 years. In effect, the mix of beds will be reversed from 60 to 70 per cent in nursing homes and only 30 to 40 per cent in hostels to about 70 per cent in hostels and only 30 per cent in nursing homes. This is consistent with wide-ranging views on the provision of aged care and will promote non-institutionalised and sensitive care for the elderly. It is, of course, also economically responsible.

Under the legislation that the Government is introducing the new target will be achieved by funding the growth in beds, as required, at a 90 per cent level in hostels and only a 10 per cent level in nursing homes. At the same time the Government will significantly increase the capital expenditure for hostels. In order further to assist hostels, which will be taking increasingly frail people, the Government has decided to index the hostel subsidy each November and from May 1987 there will be a real increase in the weekly subsidy per person to be paid to hostels for aged care. This is one initiative in the new scheme which the legislation will introduce which I particularly welcome.
