The feature that I am particularly pleased about is the recognition that poorer and disadvantaged groups in our community, such as Aboriginal Australians, some ethnic groups and other low income groups, have been quite severely discriminated against by the system as it operates at present. Under the new arrangements the Government has decided to increase the capital subsidies to help such community groups with special needs and will provide up to 100 per cent of capital funds to provide facilities for the care of their aged people. I am confident that this will be a significant advance which is going to be of tremendous advantage and assistance to a large group of people who have previously found great difficulty in obtaining nursing home and hostel beds. I am especially pleased about it because I have a case in my electorate which has been of concern to me for some time. An Italian community group has been endeavouring to expand a nursing home established there but has been unable to do so because it has been unable to raise 20 per cent of the capital costs. This has gone on year after year. They have raised more and more money but because of the increases in building costs the effect has been that every year they have just not been able to meet the 80 per cent requirement. This provision should ensure that they will be able to be funded to meet the need, which the Department of Community Services recognises is present.

In reaching its decisions the Government has consulted widely. A number of factors led it to adopt the changes which this legislation initiates. Those factors were noted by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) in his statement. They were the requirement for flexible planning which provides for monitoring, evaluation and changes where necessary, including more integration with community services; a publicised and better resourced hostel sector so that hostels can care for increasingly dependent aged people; the extension of residential care services beyond hostels to other forms of accommodation such as group housing arrangements; and the need to expand community services to assist those elderly people most at risk of premature and inappropriate institutionalisation. Finally, there was the importance of carefully developing the processes of assessment so that it would gain support from consumers, professionals and service providers. I think those factors are set out very clearly and I support them strongly as the Minister has referred to them, because many of us, I am sure know, of cases of elderly people who, for various reasons, have been encouraged by families, friends or peer group pressure to put their names down to go into nursing homes. When a bed has become available they have in fact gone into the nursing home, found that it was certainly not to their liking and in some cases have actually been able to go back to living independently with a degree of community support. I know one lady in Melbourne who is, I think, about 95 now. She was put into a nursing home about 10 years ago, did not find that it was entirely to her liking, decided that she was not going to be bothered with it any more and found herself a flat. She has been living in that flat and, subsequently, a couple of others-she did not like some of the neighbours and moved again. She is still living independently with community support.

The factors that I have mentioned have had a wide acceptance as guiding principles for the provision of aged care in the community and have formed the basis of the legislation which is now before this House. Their acceptance will overcome the problems which I have already noted-the uncontrolled growth of the nursing home sector, the rip-offs and disgraceful treatment of some of our senior citizens, and the unmanageable increase in expenditure that will be entailed if sensitive and carefully planned changes are not made now. Most importantly, the legislation will allow us to better meet the needs of our aged in a way which will provide them with a high standard of care and services and recognise the independence which they rightfully want to retain. It will allow our senior citizens to live with respect and dignity, as they are entitled to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise to take part in this debate because it is a piece of legislation that touches on a very important subject. There is a lot of debate in the community about how our population is aging. Whilst that is true, it is true largely because of the dramatic drop in the fertility rate in this country since the early 1960s. In fact, had family formation size continued, we might not be seeing an aging of the population. There would, however, have been the same absolute increase in the number of people aged 65 and over. No one should object to that because, after all, we spend an immense amount of resources in medical research so that an ever-increasing proportion of our population can have the joy and pleasure of longer lives.

SPEECH.PARA: What then is important is that during those longer lives, a high percentage of people should be enabled to live in comfort and in circumstances with friends and family, as they would choose. But sadly, for some, it is not just the 7 per cent who happen to be in nursing homes today, as was implied by the honourable member for Makin (Mr Duncan), because that is looking at it on a still photograph basis. Over time, more than 7 per cent of our aged population spend some time, and for some of them long periods of time, in nursing homes. They spend it in nursing homes because their medical condition is such that that is the only way they can live in reasonable comfort.

It is true that in the past, and sometimes still now, people in nursing homes have been and are well enough to live in circumstances where the costs of their care and accommodation are not as high. But contrary to the experience of the honourable member for Makin, mine has been that in visiting nursing homes in my electorate-and mine is next door to his electorate-in recent times it has been very difficult to identify people in nursing homes who, looking at them through a layman's eyes, seem to need that accommodation. I agree that we should keep the number of people in nursing homes at a minimum, because if we can make people comfortable in accommodation where they can care for and look after themselves, they should be able to live in those homely surroundings which we would all prefer to live in. If, as people grow older, they need care and assistance, if we can provide it to them in their own homes so we should. If it cannot be provided to them in their own homes and hostel care is the only alternative, that should be provided.

I felt that the honourable member for Makin was implying that this report was bringing about dramatic changes. I do not think it is. I was interested in the fact that this legislation is based upon a report that said:

Services for aged persons are provided in a framework of a continuum of care. Within this continuum the emphasis should be on maintaining people in their own homes, rather than in institutional or residential care with services matched to care needs.

I guess if one takes the jargon out of that quotation what we are saying is that we should provide the care that people need and only when they need it, for it is what the people want as well as what is sensible in economic terms. But if they need care, care should be available for them.

The same thing has happened with our policies for caring for the aged. They have developed along a continuum and there have been times when the greatest need was to provide independent living units. When that gap was filled, the urgent need was nursing home care. It may be true that in the past, as it will be true now, we tend to get fads and fixations about what is the most important area of need. I urge upon the Government, and upon the departments which administer the Government's policies, that they maintain a balanced approach, a sensitive approach to the needs of people and not, because they have a hang-up about one particular approach, deny people who need other types of care appropriate standards and levels of care.

There is much that can be said in relation to this legislation and I want to spend some time in talking about the needs in the nursing home area. There are, as honourable members would be aware, three types of nursing homes: Those that are known as participating nursing homes run by independent organisations; those that are deficit-funded nursing homes which are provided by non-profit charitable and benevolent organisations; and State government nursing homes. I want to talk, when this debate resumes later today, on the effects of this Government's policies on the patients in those nursing homes because of the high level of insecurity that is being caused to those patients due to the uncertainty that they are confronted with as to the cost they will have to bear in respect of their necessary nursing home care.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It now being 2 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 101.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer him to his promise in the 1984 election campaign.
—Which one?
—The one about inflation. We will come to the other ones later. I quote the Prime Minister:

QUESTION.PARA: We expect inflation will be less than 5 per cent in the year ahead and we are determined to keep it below 5 per cent.

Is it a fact that Australia's inflation rate has increased dramatically since that time and is currently almost 9 per cent? Will the Prime Minister accept that his election commitment on inflation can now be added to his ever increasing list of broken promises?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, the fact is that the--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —When members of the Opposition are in trouble, they always press the giggle button. The fact is that by the beginning of 1985, a year after the last election, this Government had brought down the inflation rate in this country to the figure which the honourable gentleman refers to. So, within the capacity of the policies of this Government, that promise was delivered.
—Ha, ha!

—There goes that giggle button again. It is no substitute for analysis. The fact is that since the end of January 1985, by which time the figure I said in 1984 would be achieved had been achieved, there has been a 35 per cent devaluation of the Australian dollar associated with a massive decline in the terms of trade of which the honourable gentleman should be aware. If he is so economically inept, as well as being economically dishonest, that he says that that will have no impact--
—Order! The Prime Minister will withdraw that remark.
—Well, if he is both--
—Are you going to withdraw it?
—Withdraw the comment, please.

—Yes, I withdraw it, Madam Speaker-of course I do. I rephrase it by saying that, if he adds to his capacity for misrepresentation a monumental incompetence by saying that those externally imposed factors will have no impact upon the Australian internal inflation rate, one can simply be sorry for him.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that, in terms of this Government's policies, in the year after the election we produced the outcome that I promised. We cannot have a 35 per cent depreciation and a massive decline in the terms of trade and expect that there will be no adverse outcome. But the fact is that even with that externally imposed pressure, which has been responsible for this upturn in the inflation rate, this Government still has not managed to achieve the inflation rate which we inherited from the Treasurer under the Fraser Government. The rate of inflation which this Government inherited was 11.2 per cent. The former Treasurer managed to achieve that simply as a result of a combination of his own totally inept and misguided economic policies. He had no wages policy, a fact which he subsequently admitted in a moment of candour. He said: `One of the problems with my administration was that we had no wages policy'. How right he was. Not only did the previous Government have no wages policy but it also had a policy which allowed a wages blow-out in this country of 17 per cent. If one has a policy like that, of course one is going to hand over to an incoming government a rate of 11.2 per cent. We more than halved that in terms of the direct promise that I made to the people of Australia.

With the appropriate fiscal, monetary and wages policies that we have in place, we still have an inflation outcome significantly below that which was the outcome of the honourable member for Bennelong's stewardship of the economic management of this country. If one is going to come into this debate and talk about inflation, one has to have respectable credentials. The honourable gentleman comes to this debate with the worst credentials of any Treasurer in the history of this country. Fancy producing 11.2 per cent inflation as a result of one's own inept economic policies!

The fact is that the market has taken the consumer price index figure for today in its stride. In fact, we have seen, much to the regret of the Opposition, I am sure, that the exchange rate has increased and the dollar has gone over 64c. In other words, the market has taken account of the CPI in terms that I indicated within the last week or so. I indicated the reasons why the CPI in the September quarter would be high and why it would probably continue to be high in the December quarter. It is on track with the forecast in the Budget handed down by the Treasurer. Of course, it is true that in 1987, as I have said, inflation will be trending down. It will be trending down because under this Government we have the right policies in regard to wages, the right budgetary policy and the right policies in regard to the whole fiscal stance that is required in this country. Under the combination of those policies the inflation rate in 1987 will be trending down. I repeat: No man can come into this House when he has inflicted upon Australia an 11.2 per cent inflation rate because he did not have the economic competence, wit or wisdom to have the right policies and criticise this Government, a government which has more than halved that inflation rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Can he inform the House whether all States have shared in the benefits of the Hawke Labor Government's economic policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Griffith for his very penetrating question. It is relevant that the honourable member comes from the State of Queensland. The fact is that most States have done very well indeed as a result of the economic and other policies of this Government. The one notable exception, which the honourable member knows, of course, to his great regret, is the State of Queensland. Queensland is simply in a terrible economic mess. I can only applaud, together, I am sure, with at least all honourable members on this side of the House and half the honourable members on the other side of the House, the statements of Sir Roderick Proctor for his courage and his honesty. We understand that this gentleman is, at least temporarily, a trustee of the National Party of Australia in Queensland. In his attack on cronyism in Queensland, in his devastating statements on the charade which accompanies the tendering process in Queensland, he said that it was obvious before the tendering process was completed who would win. He said it was a charade and went on to talk about the myth of Queensland being a low taxing, free enterprise State. Those statements of a trustee of the National Party simply underlie the horrific state of the Queensland economy under the leadership of the National Party.

ANSWER.PARA: The simple fact is that when the resources boom burst in Queensland, Queensland was simply left high and dry because the Queensland Government, under Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, did not have the semblance of an economy policy to deal with the facts of that case.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Would the Prime Minister stop for a moment? I remind the honourable member for O'Connor of standing order 58, which states:

INTERJECT.PARA: Every Member of the House, when he comes into the Chamber, shall take his seat, and shall not at any time stand in any of the passages or gangways.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, as you pay attention to the Standing Orders, no doubt you will shortly ask the Prime Minister to cut short his tirade.
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. May I suggest to the honourable member for O'Connor that he does not have the right to take the microphone whenever he feels like it.

—The tragedy of the ineptitude of the Queensland Government in the area of economic policy is that Queensland has the lowest living standard of any State of Australia. It has the second highest unemployment rate, and the attempts that have been made to blame that upon an alleged influx of young people into Queensland have been totally demolished by the statistics. Not only has the ineptitude of the Queensland Government had this devastating effect upon the living standards of Queenslanders but it has had a devastating effect on the business community in Queensland. I remind the honourable member who asked me the question that a wave of bankruptcies is sweeping Queensland. The statistics are very simple and tragic for the people of Queensland.
—That is your policies.

—In the last two years there has been a 45 per cent increase in the number of bankruptcies in Queensland. I remind the House and the honourable member in particular that that 45 per cent increase in the last two years is three times the national average. My friend from Tasmania, who always wants to be helpful to me, says that we did it. How did we do it to Queensland, with three times the national average? The responsibility for that disastrous state lies with the Queensland Government and particularly with its Premier. Because the honourable member for Griffith comes from Queensland he would have heard the myth thrown out time after time by the Queensland Premier that Queensland is the low taxing State. Everyone up there knows that that is a myth. Indeed, Sir Roderick Proctor demonstrated that and pointed out the simple fact that an extortion racket is being practised by the Queensland Premier in regard to coal rail freight charges. That particular milch cow is running dry and there has been a massive increase in State and local government charges. I remind the honourable member that in the two years ended June 1986 Brisbane had the highest increase-22 per cent-in State and local government charges of any capital city in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: It would probably be useful for the House, and I think it would be particularly instructive and warming to the honourable member, if I were to repeat to him the latter stages of the interview that Sir Roderick Proctor had last night on the Carleton-Walsh Report, which is very relevant to the question he asked. The journalist said this to Sir Roderick Proctor, a leading businessman and a trustee of the National Party in Queensland:
You're obviously one of the top businessmen in this State. You must meet a lot of other businessmen. Do you find that your sentiments are shared by others?
Sir Roderick Proctor replied:
Yes, I believe that there is fairly widely held concern in business.
The journalist then asked:
Well, why do you think that those people are not prepared to be very vocal with that concern?
That is a good question. Sir Roderick Proctor replied:
Because it could well disadvantage them and the businesses that they run.
Then, of course, the journalist said to him:
But you're doing it.
Sir Roderick Proctor replied:
I'm doing it to a degree because I'm trying to be honest.
The journalist said to this leading businessman who had said that he was trying to be honest:
Is that wise in Queensland?
Sir Roderick Proctor said:
Probably not.

In other words, a leading businessman is saying that he is trying to be honest about the disastrous situation in Queensland, about the cronyism, about the charade of tenders, and he said: `Because I am honest it is probably not good for me'. It is interesting to note that in the midday news today another leading businessman has endorsed the attitude of Sir Roderick Proctor.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Tim Fischer

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. Notwithstanding your comments earlier this week, I draw your attention to Hansard of 12 February 1986, when you said:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Prime Minister will finish his answer.
I submit to you that under standing order 144 the same circumstances apply in this case and you should apply the same dictum.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister is relevant to the question.
—The honourable member will be interested to know that another leading businessman on the midday news today--
—Who is it?

—It is interesting that he is in the shoe industry. He is now putting a boot into Sir Joh. It is Sir Robert Mathers-there are plenty of knights in Queensland, as the honourable member knows-a leading businessman and deputy chairman of the organising committee for the Brisbane Olympic Games bid. The interviewer asked him:

ANSWER.PARA: What's your view on claims made overnight by Sir Roderick?
The answer was:
Yes, good morning Steven, look I might say that I agree wholeheartedly with the sentiments that Sir Roderick expressed.
He was then asked:
But what precisely are the concerns of the businessmen you speak to about the National Party?
Sir Robert replied:
Well, I think the main concern is that the sort of things that Sir Roderick mentioned in his article actually-I think one of the big things is the cronyism.
So there we have it. At last the ineptitude of Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen and his Government is being exposed, and it is being exposed, importantly, by those people who are in the best position to know.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my next question to the Prime Minister by observing that the answer he has just given is about as near as he is going to get to the Queensland election campaign. I refer the Prime Minister to today's shocking inflation rate figures, which reveal that in the September quarter Australia's inflation rate has risen to 8.9 per cent, compared with the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average of only 2.4 per cent; that is, Australia's inflation rate is almost seven percentage points higher than and four times the OECD average. Is it a fact that this is Australia's worst inflation rate performance compared with the OECD average since that body was formed 25 years ago in 1961?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already explained that under the policies of this Government we have succeeded in more than halving the inflation rate we inherited from the Leader of the Opposition when he was Treasurer. We inherited a rate of 11.2 per cent and we have brought that down to a rate which was running at less than 5 per cent. I have explained the externally imposed factors which have been responsible for the increase in the inflation rate in this country and I have explained further that, because we have in place appropriate wages and other elements of economic policy, as we go into 1987 those rates will come down.

ANSWER.PARA: If the Leader of the Opposition wants to make international comparisons, let us make the appropriate economic comparisons so that the people of Australia can judge under which sort of government they would be better off in terms of expectations of inflation. I refer to Budget Paper No. 1, which was handed down by the Treasurer on Budget night. We see there a very significant international comparison of average earnings. I remind the House of the disastrous comparison that existed when the now Leader of the Opposition was responsible for the economic management of this country. He asked about the OECD figures. In 1982 the increase in average earnings for the major OECD trading partners of Australia was 6.5 per cent. Under the stewardship of the honourable member for Bennelong, the then Treasurer of this country, the comparison for Australia was 16.5 per cent. That is what was happening to wages in the OECD major trading partners-6.5 per cent-when, under the policies of the honourable member for Bennelong it was 16.5 per cent.

Under the policies of this Government we have brought that rate down. In 1985 it was 4.6 per cent for the major OECD trading partners and 6.2 per cent in this country. In other words, in terms of those elements of economic policy over which any Australian government has control, the honourable gentleman had us in a position where the increase in Australian earnings was 154 per cent higher than that in the major OECD trading partners. That reflected the area in which the Government of Australia had control and influence. Because this Government has the relevant policies in the monetary area, the fiscal area and the wages area, this country has been able to experience a substantial decline in inflation in terms of relevant domestic Australian policies and it can look forward in 1987 to a significantly declining inflation rate. The only alternative that has been put forward by the Leader of the Opposition is a return to the wages policy which gave this country 1.54 times the rate of increase in earnings in the rest of the OECD countries, which would mean that we would have, under a Howard government, a return to double digit inflation, which is what was handed over to us when we came in and which we more than halved.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Special Minister of State. Has there been any criticism of the one vote one value electoral system? Has the Government received proposals to change the system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —In spite of all the protestations made in 1983 about the new system adopted by this Parliament, my office has received no official submission about changing the system back to the rigged gerrymander that existed in favour of the National Party prior to 1983. It is a matter of some pride to all members, particularly when travelling outside Australia, when asked about our electoral system, to say that we have a totally democratic system of electing people to the House of Representatives in Australia. Some people said that perhaps there might be problems with some of the vast areas serviced by honourable members from both sides of this House. That has not been borne out in practice. This Government has looked after members with vast electorates by providing them with the necessary facilities and staff in order for them to carry out their electoral work effectively. We have some outstanding members in this Parliament looking after electorates-such as the honourable member for Herbert who asked the question, the honourable member for Leichhardt, the honourable member for Grey, the honourable member for Kalgoorlie-and upholding the enormous standards set by people who have represented those districts--
—What about Bob here?

—What is his name? So that has not been borne out in practice. This contrasts sharply and sadly with the position that we as Australians face in trying to explain what is happening in Queensland. The first thing we should say about Queensland is this: Just a couple of weeks ago, when the people throughout Queensland were asked in a public opinion poll about their views on the gerrymander, by a majority of 56 per cent to 20 per cent those who answered the question said that they wanted one vote one value in Queensland. So the voting system will be a very big issue on Saturday week when Queenslanders go to the polls. One can see why. There should be one vote one value in Queensland instead of the zonal gerrymandered system which has been imposed by a group of commissioners whose report was never made public and whose evidence was never made public. The submission from the National Party of Australia was never made public.

ANSWER.PARA: It is a great system up there! Talk about cronies-there are bus loads of them. In the south-eastern zone, instead of having 51 members they should have 58 members under the one vote one value system; the provincial cities should have 14 not 13 members; the western and far western zones should have four, not eight; and the country should have 13, not 17. The members who represent people in the districts where the Bjelke-Petersen people are trying to maintain power should be treated in the same way as we are treating members in similar electorates here: They should be given the necessary facilities to look after the districts. Members of parliament represent people, not sheep and trees, and that ought to be the slogan in Queensland. The Queensland Premier made a speech in Townsville the night before last and this is what he said about electoral voting:

I want to say to you ladies and gentlemen, the north needs a strong voice, not an elimination of members of parliament. You know the suggestion of the other two organisations is a very, very simple arithmetic-can't add it up any other way-doesn't matter what they say about giving you more representation-it doesn't add up-you can't make one and one mean two . . .

It is a funny thing. When Joh was asked what Sir Roderick Proctor's problem was, he said: `I sacked him. He was Chairman of Suncorp and I said to him: ``You're out, you're out, you're 71''.'. We would rather have Sir Roderick at 71 and sane than Sir Joh at 76 and no Dick Emery.

It is pretty obvious what is happening in Queensland. Sir Roderick is a trustee of the National Party-although I notice in the lunch time newspaper reports from Queensland that Sir Robert has sacked him, that Sir Robert Sparkes has moved in and said that, because of his interview last night, he is no longer eligible to be a trustee. How would anyone like to be the trustee of the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation? That would be the big job in Queensland. If one could get in on that, as did Sir Edward Lyons, one could get a $300,000 credit with the Totalizator Administration Board. For $25,000, a little highland fling, to the Bjelke-Petersen Fund one can have breakfast with the Premier. That is another little source of income that works up there. Queenslanders should clean up the electoral system, as the Queesland President of the Liberal Party of Australia, John Moore, has told us, not only because of all the corruption but also because the electoral system itself is so corrupt that it breeds more corruption. Business people think they have to pay into the Bjelke-Petersen Fund to do business in Queensland. The interviewer said last night: `It appears that you have done yourself some damage, Sir Roderick, by speaking out'. Sir Roderick said: `I suppose I have'. There is only one way for the Queenslanders to clean all that up. On Saturday week they should not mess around with a milkshake; if they want to clean up Queensland they have to have a Labor Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer him to the claim made in the first two answers that he has given to me today that the substantial explanation for our falling inflation rate is the recent devaluation of the Australian dollar. Is it a fact that, abstracting from the Australian Statistician's estimate of the contribution to the consumer price index of goods and services wholly or predominantly imported, Australia's annual inflation rate rose from 7.1 per cent in the June quarter to 7.6 per cent in the September quarter? Does the Prime Minister agree that, even allowing for additional one-off effects such as the large rise in fresh fruit and vegetable prices in the September quarter, such a figure still represents an intolerably high inflation rate compared with our major partners? What other excuse can he offer to the Australian public for an inflation rate which, when discounted for devaluation effects, is still four times that of our major trading partners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my answer to this question by reminding the honourable gentleman that he comes to this issue with no credentials at all. He comes to this question as the Treasurer who handed over to the incoming Government an inflation rate of 11.2 per cent, very substantially above the inflation rate at this time and more than twice the inflation rate that this Government had brought about before the onset of depreciation, which began at the end of January 1985. The elements to which the honourable gentleman referred in his question are the direct effects-calculated by the Australian Statistician-of depreciation. They do not pick up the indirect effects of the devaluation.

ANSWER.PARA: Obviously, the figure for this quarter reflects the impact of the Budget decisions, which have been made by the Commonwealth Government and by State governments. Fruit and vegetable prices have also had an impact. The underlying inflation rate that this Government brought down, before the impact of the depreciation, was running at less than 5 per cent. The direct and indirect effects of the very substantial depreciation-in trade weighted terms it has been 34.5 per cent since the end of January 1985-have continued. There has also been an impact from the 10 to 11 per cent depreciation of June and July. I repeat: The policies that this Government has in place in the monetary, fiscal and wages areas will mean that in 1987 we will experience a significant decline in the inflation rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Primary Industry inform the House on the progress being made in statutory marketing reform and relate this to the levels of primary industry regulation in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. I know that he is very interested in statutory marketing authority reform. The Government has introduced model legislation. Gradually we are working through the various primary industries. We now have reform of the meat industry and the Australian Wheat Board, and we have agreement on reform for the wool industry next year. Today or tomorrow I will announce the new composition of the Australian Dairy Corporation and the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation. Today I will introduce legislation on pigs. We have put out a discussion paper on horticulture. As honourable members will know, we are spending $10m as seed money to get a horticultural marketing corporation going.

ANSWER.PARA: Similarly, with respect to research councils, we have put the farmers in the box seat. They are on the selection committee. We now have statutory marketing authorities that are commercially flexible and non-representative but representative of the farmers' interests in a functional sense in terms of the objects and functions of those marketing corporations. The corporations are fully accountable through a range of bodies. They pick up many of the recommendations of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations some years ago. That Committee sat under the chairmanship of Senator Peter Rae. In New South Wales, the Marketing of Primary Products Acts have been reformed. In Victoria there has been much reform of all statutory authorities. By and large, the States are moving to give primary producers boards that can compete more commercially in a very tough marketing environment. The exception to this progress and intelligent approach is in Queensland, which has a corrupt minority Government.
Opposition members-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —The members of the National Party of Australia moan but they should look at a cartoon that I saw this morning. Someone runs into the National Party headquarters saying: `Our support is down to 14 per cent'. The campaign leader says: `Gee whizz, it could be a close thing'. That is about how bad it is. In Queensland there are more boards for primary production than in any other State. The board that ran into trouble recently was the Peanut Marketing Board. Queensland could not run it successfully. There have been dairy scandals in the southern part of the State, particularly in South Brisbane. There is no need for me to repeat all the allegations to the embarrassment of those opposite. They know a lot about them in cockies' corner.

ANSWER.PARA: The industry that is most regulated is the sugar industry. To be serious, it is a great pity that a man of courage, Mr Neil Turner, the Minister for Primary Industries in that State, chose not to run in the current election because he is sick of being stood over by the Queensland Premier. The Queensland Premier was not able to provide any leadership to this industry. He would not let Mr Turner provide any leadership. As a result, the industry effectively lost about $50m worth of assistance-because of the nonsense and delays.

It is no wonder that Sir Roderick Proctor says that Queensland is the most socialised and regulated State. It is only by dint of hard work by Mr Turner, who was so stood over by the Premier that he is not prepared to stand again for Parliament, that we have the Sugar Mill Adjustment Committee. We are trying to get some adjustments to help out mills such as Babinda, in which the honourable member for Leichhardt has a close interest, so that we can do something about mill amalgamation and get the sugar industry in Queensland into better shape. It is terribly important that we do so despite Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen. The only industry in Queensland that is not regulated-it is totally deregulated-is the real estate industry. This is really the heartland of the National Party. If one puts a bit of money in the tin for the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation one will have no problem getting rezoning. That is the reality. The National Party in Queensland is no longer concerned about farmers, marketing or any of this. It is concerned only about its rotten corruption, real estate development and looking after its mates.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to today's inflation figure. Is it a fact that Australia's unit labour costs have risen by 4 per cent per annum over the past three years, a rate four times that of our major trading partners? Is it a fact that had Australia's unit labour cost performance matched that of our major trading partners the Australian dollar would not have needed to have fallen by the same amount and, therefore, the inflationary impact on the consumer price index would not have been as great to secure the exchange rate relativity which now exists? Does the Prime Minister therefore accept that the Government's wages policy and its relative failure compared with the rest of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development area has driven the dollar down further and inflation higher than would otherwise have been necessary under a more responsible policy?
—I am indebted to the honourable member for asking me a question about changes in real unit labour costs.
—No, I didn't.
—It is relevant to it. I will go precisely to what the honourable member asked about. I remind the honourable gentleman at the outset of the figures in the Budget Paper No. 1--
—Those figures are in the Budget Papers. You get to them.

—I will come to them. On page 59 the overall figure for real unit labour costs in the non-farm sector shows that the cumulative fall since 1982-83 has been 7 per cent. I go to changes in real compensation per employee deflated by the private consumption deflator. Let us look at changes in real compensation in the United States of America, Japan, Germany, France, the United Kingdom, Italy and Canada in the period 1983-85. There was an increase of 2 per cent in the United States; an increase of 3.8 per cent in Japan; an increase of 2.5 per cent in Germany; an increase of 2.2 per cent in France; an increase of 6.5 per cent in the United Kingdom; and a decline of 4 per cent in Australia. If the Leader of the Opposition wants to consider what has been achieved in terms of costs in this country compared with what has happened overseas in the period of this Government and in the period of his administration, we are more than happy to make that comparison and examination because it is quite clear that the record under the period of this Government is infinitely better than the record during the period in which the Leader of the Opposition had control of the Australian economy.

—I ask the Minister for Defence: What is the Government doing to ensure that improved housing is provided to Australian defence personnel? Will the Government be taking any notice of the policy of the Opposition spokesman on local government and administrative services that defence housing should be privatised?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the two parts of the honourable member's question, the first thing I ought to point out is that, as a result of decisions in this Budget under this Government, there has been a very substantial increase in the funds made available for defence. This Budget provides some $66m for defence housing, which is up 20 per cent on last year and which is vastly more than the amount spent by the Opposition when in government. In addition, we have decided to place defence housing under a statutory authority. The 22,000 defence houses are to be managed by that authority. That authority will have the ability to trade in those houses and the houses will be significantly upgraded. We recognise two things about defence housing. First, defence housing is a very important condition of service. Serving personnel rely on access to relatively cheap housing in order to sustain their families as they are shifted from post to post, sometimes on far too regular a basis. Nevertheless, it is a very important condition of service.

ANSWER.PARA: The second factor which motivates our policy is acknowledgment of the factor that the Defence Force housing structure is based on operational necessities and that the positioning of houses, even in most of the capital cities, has to be such as to facilitate the effectiveness of the defence forces and the operations of their facilities. So we have decided to keep the defence housing program within a government framework. It is not as though we have not examined some alternatives to that course of action. The housing task force did so. It considered options such as those considered by the honourable member for O'Connor, who is the Opposition spokesman on local government and administrative services.

In statements which the honourable member evidently made last week on this matter he suggested that available for sale was a substantial amount of defence property, including houses. In some areas of defence property, I would agree with the honourable member for O'Connor that there are opportunities for sale. We have done so in this Budget. In making several defence properties available for sale, I have received numerous representations from the Opposition on one or two of them suggesting to me that I ought not. Nevertheless, as a general point, when something like 83 per cent of the properties of the Commonwealth is concerned, from time to time there will naturally be opportunities to relieve oneself of budgetary strain by getting rid of some of them. However, defence force housing is a totally different matter altogether.

Let me tell honourable members this about defence force housing: The implicit subsidy, which is, on average, applicable across the board, is $75 a week. If one were to place defence housing on the open market and lease it out, as suggested by the honourable member for O'Connor, to private enterprise and make anything like a reasonable profit for the people from whom one then leased it back, one would have to find from Commonwealth outlays, or from the defence service personnel, that $75. And that is only an average. In capital cities the effective subsidy is much higher.

One is faced with two alternatives. One alternative would have a very substantial impact on Commonwealth outlays, because the subsidy is now implicit; it is not an explicit subsidy. We build the houses and rent them out to the service personnel. No line appears in the Budget saying: You have to subsidise that to the tune of X-amount. So one alternative would be a substantial increase in defence outlays to pay the person from whom one was leasing those houses, having sold the houses to them in the first place. The other alternative-which is the more likely course to be pursued, because no Defence Minister is going to be able to sustain, in Budget hearings over a period of time with his Cabinet colleagues, a continual payout to private enterprise subsidising service personnel-would be a rise in the cost for service houses, if they go up to the market level, of at least $75 a week. That would be a massive attack on service conditions.

I note that around the Queensland electorate now a considerable amount of propaganda is being put about regarding whether or not this Government has done substantial damage to service conditions. One advertisement which appeared in the electorate of the honourable member for Herbert suggested that we were responsible, for example, for a services pay freeze. As I pointed out here the other day, only one government imposed a pay freeze on the services-and it was not ours. It was our predecessors.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was the Minister?

—The Minister and Treasurer of the time are still in the House. Let them reflect on what might happen in the honourable gentleman's constituency if service personnel in the Townsville area were obliged to find another $75 a week. I see the honourable member for Hughes over there. Let him rock on down to the team at Holsworthy and tell them that they have to pay another $75 a week for their houses. The policy that has come forward from the Opposition in this regard is a totally ill-thought-out policy. If ever implemented-and it never will be-it would pose a substantial threat to service conditions. We have had a thorough examination of what the Opposition's policy would mean and have found that it would be a potential blight on service personnel. It simply does not recognise the fact that service personnel, by virtue of their position, have to be shifted with regularity. They have to anticipate spending their service lives in at least four or five different houses. They have a right to anticipate that the Government will supply them with houses that are suitable to their conditions. They will get those houses under our arrangements. An efficient, effective statutory authority will administer this area in a way which protects their position and serves the interests of the defence forces.

—I ask the Prime Minister: Is it a fact that the average tax rates for a family with a dependent spouse and children and earning, respectively, average weekly earnings, which are currently $465 a week or $24,000 a year, half average weekly earnings or twice average weekly earnings, are all higher now than when the Government was elected and will still be higher even after the so-called tax cuts, if they take effect, in June of next year?
—What about your tax cuts in 1977?

—As the Special Minister of State, by way of interjection, has pointed out, here again is an area to which the Leader of the Opposition comes without any credentials at all. This is the person who perpetrated the greatest fraud upon the Australian taxpayer in the history of this country. He was part of a government which in the 1977 election said: `Here is your fistful of dollars'. It could not wait to get back into government before it said to the taxpayers of Australia: `What a pack of mugs you are'. Whack! It took them back. And the Leader of the Opposition comes here and talks about tax. Let me give the position in regard to average tax rates. In September 1982, the average rate of tax payable on average weekly earnings, without deductions, for all employees was 23 per cent. Then the Government pulled its great rort by blowing out the Budget deficit, which reduced the average tax rate paid on average weekly earnings to 20.9 per cent. As compared with the average rate of tax payable on average weekly earnings of 23 per cent in the period when the honourable member for Bennelong was Treasurer, by December this year the average rate on average weekly earnings will be 19.7 per cent-significantly below the rate of tax payable on average weekly earnings left to us by the former Treasurer.

—Has the Treasurer noted comments by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition which argue for a wage freeze? What effect would such a policy have on the living standards of ordinary Australians? Moreover, how would such a policy be implemented in a deregulated labour market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have noted the statement today by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition on the radio program AM in which he said: `We need a very definite pause in wage increases in this country if we are going to have any hope at all of reviving our trade and reviving our economy in general'. To the question `Does this mean that you are advocating no wage increase at all in 1987?', the Deputy Leader of the Opposition replied: `Yes. I do not believe that the economy can afford it. We need a pause in wages if we are going to recover our economy'. He went on to say: `We need a pause for at least 12 months in wage increases'. This demonstrates the utter confusion of the coalition parties on the principal issue of wages. The Leader of the Opposition is saying that he wants a deregulated labour market with opting out for firms with fewer than 50 people-that is, on a cumulative basis, nearly 1.8 million workers or nearly half of the private sector work force-and his Deputy is saying that we need the most centralised wage outcome of all, a wage pause. In other words, the Opposition wants its cake and to eat it too.

ANSWER.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition, in his last question, asked the Prime Minister about the after tax return to taxpayers. At the same time his Deputy wishes to deny taxpayers a wage increase by introducing a further wage pause. The honourable member for Bennelong has opposed every wage increase since 1977. His Deputy is now arguing for a wage pause-for no increase in wages in 1987-while he asks the Prime Minister questions, with crocodile tears, about the after tax earnings of taxpayers. The Leader of the Opposition says that he wants a deregulated labour market with opting out while his Deputy says that he wants a totally centralised system with a wage pause. Is it any wonder that nobody in the country believes that a coalition government could control inflation?

What a joke it is that today we have had a succession of questions about inflation from the Leader of the Opposition-the high priest of Australian inflation, the wage wrecker-while his Deputy is saying: `We do not have a wages policy or an incomes policy; we want a centralised wage freeze'. The Leader of the Opposition wants opting out for firms that employ fewer than 50 people. The Opposition has no wages policy, no anti-inflation policy, no fiscal policy and no policy on the central tenets of economic policy. It has no wages policy and no fiscal policy. In its fiscal policy there are $5.9 billion of tax promises. It has no idea about how to run a decent monetary policy because it never did. It has nothing to offer on the basic fundamentals of economic policy, yet members of the Opposition ask the Prime Minister and the Government questions about the inflation rate and wages.

Today we have exposed yet again the total confusion and disarray in the Opposition parties on wages policy because the Deputy Leader of the Opposition wants a centralised wage outcome while his Leader wants a decentralised wage outcome. Let all Australians in business and the public understand that these parties have no policies now any more than they did when they were defeated in March 1983. If they were ever to get back on to the treasury bench they would wreck the place like they did in 1983. They would give us another depression like they gave us in 1983. We would be back to high double digit inflation, as we were in 1983, and we would be back to the same destruction and misery we have seen from the former Treasurer as he tried his policies for a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to the annual report of the Steel Industry Authority, which throws serious doubt on the future of the steel industry plan and on long term employment in the industry. Is the Prime Minister aware that the Authority has highlighted: First, a dramatic increase in industrial disputation which, at Port Kembla alone, rose by 680 per cent in the second part of the financial year; secondly, a disturbing decline in productivity; and, thirdly, a continuation of entrenched restrictive work practices? In view of the Authority's prediction that the steel industry will suffer as a result of the predicted declines in the building and construction industries and the motor vehicle industry, I ask: What action will the Government take to alleviate the disturbing findings of the Steel Industry Authority concerning declining productivity, restrictive work practices and increasing industrial disputes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to the honourable member that I have not read the report but I am glad that he has raised the question of the steel industry. I must say that I am absolutely amazed that anyone in the Opposition would raise the question of the steel industry. The facts are that when this Government assumed office there was a very serious question-it was not some hypothetical matter being debated in some far off corner-being debated within the steel industry as to whether it would continue in this country. In other words, after 7 1/2 years of conservative government, those opposite had brought the steel industry to the position where it was being seriously questioned as to whether or not it would be abandoned.

ANSWER.PARA: In the election campaign in February and March 1983 I said on behalf of my Party that an incoming Labor government would not tolerate the disappearance of the steel industry in this country. What did we do? We said that within roughly 100 days we would bring down a steel industry plan. It would not be a plan just imagined here in Canberra; it would be a plan arrived at in consultation with the industry, the employers, the unions and the relevant State governments and which would require an input from all parties. We brought down that steel industry plan. It required an investment by the industry, within a given period, of $800m, as I recall. That figure was easily surpassed. It required a change in work practices by the unions, which occurred. As a direct result of the policies of this Government, in co-operation with all parties in the industry and the relevant State governments, not only did we save the steel industry but also we increased productivity in the industry very substantially, to the point where it was able not only to compete very ably against imports but also to find export markets that it had not achieved before. No one was retrenched in the industry, its employees now have secure jobs and it has a firm hold on the domestic market and a capacity to win export orders overseas. That is the result of this Government bringing in a relevant steel plan in the industry.

If there have been some increases in industrial disputes recently, that is to be regretted, but I believe that, in the atmosphere that has been created by the agreement to undertake an investigation of restrictive work and management practices, any difficulties that have arisen will be dealt with and eliminated and this country will continue to have, under this Government, a viable steel industry-something denied to it under the policies of the coalition Government of the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) resolves that United Nations General Assembly Resolution 3379 (XXX) which equates Zionism with racism-
(a) has been unhelpful in the context of the search for a settlement in the Middle East;
(b) is inconsistent with the Charter of the United Nations;
(c) remains unacceptable as a misrepresentation of Zionism;
(d) has served to escalate religious animosity and incite anti-semitism, and
(2) recommends that the Government lend support to efforts to overturn Resolution 3379 (XXX) in the United Nations.

A motion in identical terms is being introduced in the Senate by my colleague the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). I have moved this motion from a conviction, which I believe will be shared by all Australians who value truth, fairness and tolerance, that the equation of zionism with racism is profoundly wrong, disruptive and unacceptable. United Nations General Assembly Resolution 3379, adopted in 1975, which sought to make this equation, has been regarded by successive Australian governments as unacceptable. In moving this motion in the Parliament the Government hopes for bipartisan support so that the voice of Australia can be added to the voices of others in the international community who wish to see this deeply regrettable expression of United Nations opinion overturned.

To suggest that zionism is racism is, first of all, a blatant distortion of the truth. This is not the place to give a history of the development of zionism. I would, however, refer all honour- able members who wish to inform themselves on this subject to the outstanding address by my colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) to the Zionist Federation of Australia on 13 April under the title: `Israel: A Contemporary Democratic Socialist Perspective'. In that address the Foreign Minister outlined the idealism and the enlightened emancipatory principles which went into the foundation of the state of Israel. As well, he referred to the terrible impact of the Holocaust on the zionist movement. In the month in which the award to Elie Wiesel of the Nobel Peace Prize has reminded us all of the monstrous racial oppression suffered by the Jewish people less than 50 years ago, the characterisation of zionism as racism is a particular offence to decency and to logic, not only to our Jewish community but to all Australians. Apart from its distortion of reality, Resolution 3379 has become an obstacle to the search for a settlement in the Middle East, difficult as that already is. In a region where insecurity and suspicion are strong, where barriers between peoples have proved difficult to break down, it is highly counter-productive to insult the guiding philosophy of a people, especially one whose consciousness has been seared by the scourge of anti-semitism.

Resolution 3379 has not advanced the interests of those who promoted it. It has done nothing to solve the plight of the Palestinian people. Successive Australian governments have believed that there can be no peace in the Middle East until the Palestinian problem is resolved justly and peacefully and with the agreement of all those involved. This Government's support for the overturning of Resolution 3379 is based on our continued desire to see a peaceful, just and lasting solution to the Middle East dispute. Diversions such as Resolution 3379 served only to distract and disrupt efforts towards this end. The resolution has done very real damage to the relations between states. It has also harmed the credibility and reputation of the United Nations. The United Nations was intended to promote peace and harmony between the peoples of the world. It has the primary task of maintaining international peace and also pursues the goal of encouraging respect for human rights. Resolution 3379 was clearly not an attempt to further those purposes and principles. It had the effect of unfairly isolating a member state of the United Nations and, in so doing, was contrary to the spirit of the United Nations Charter.

There is no country which is more committed to upholding the reputation and effectiveness of the United Nations than Australia. Our performance as a member of the Security Council over the past two years is the most recent evidence of this commitment. Along with other countries, we have fought to maintain international support, including, very importantly, financial support, for the United Nations and its specialised agencies-the International Labour Organisation, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation and others. Our task has been made immeasurably more difficult in view of the disaffection felt for the United Nations in recent years by such countries as the United States of America. The passage of Resolution 3379 was an important factor in producing this disaffection.

Over the past two years or so, increasing international attention has been given to the question of removing this unacceptable resolution from the United Nations record. President Chaim Herzog, the widely respected President of Israel, who will pay a state visit to Australia next month, has been a leading figure in this process. The Australian Jewish community has consulted closely with the Government, particularly the Minister for Foreign Affairs, on the matter in recent months in order to determine what influence Australia might bring to bear. Realistically, we must acknowledge that it would be counter-productive to initiate a move in the United Nations at this stage to overturn Resolution 3379. There still would not be the support necessary to ensure the success of such a move. Indeed, the opposite result might be achieved: Countries which may have come to question their original position on the resolution might be forced once again to line up behind it. Nevertheless, the world political climate is changing and there are grounds for belief that an expression of the Australian Parliament's view along the lines I have outlined could contribute to that change.

In taking this step it is, I believe, important to emphasise that the Australian Government's position on the Middle East remains unchanged. As I have indicated, we believe that a resolution of the Palestinian question is central to any Middle East settlement. The Government acknowledges the right of self-determination for the Palestinian people, including the right, if they so choose, to independence and the possibility of establishing their own independent state. We recognise that whatever arrangements are finally settled upon will depend on decisions involving the participation and agreement of all parties concerned. We remain fundamentally committed to the security of Israel and its right to exist within secure and recognised boundaries in accordance with Security Council resolutions 242 and 338. It is in the interests of helping to achieve a peaceful, just and lasting solution to the Middle East dispute, one which has the acceptance of all sides, that I commend the motion I have introduced to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very happy to say on behalf of the Opposition that the motion moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has the total support and endorsement of the Opposition. It can therefore be noted by the public of Australia that there is total, unanimous and bipartisan support within this Parliament for overturning a resolution of the United Nations General Assembly which should never have been passed in the first place. We believe that blatant anti-semitism was enshrined in that resolution. We believe that overturning that resolution is an important milestone along the path of rejecting the anti-Israel stance adopted by those countries which supported the United Nations resolution.

SPEECH.PARA: It is instructive to recall that the General Assembly adopted the resolution describing zionism as a form of racism on 10 November 1975. I am very happy to say that, acting no doubt under the instructions of the Whitlam Government, a vote was cast against that resolution by Australia's representative to the United Nations. Subsequently, the passage of that resolution was condemned by the caretaker Fraser Government between 11 November and 13 December 1975. On the occasion of the resolution, Mr Ralph Harry told the United Nations:

The attempt of the sponsors of draft Resolution III to make such an equation (between Zionism and Racism) is, we believe, a distortion of fact, is unhelpful in the context of the search for a settlement in the Middle East, and raises the very real possibility that it will exacerbate religious animosities in a number of countries.

On that occasion Australia was joined in voting against the resolution by the United States, West European countries, Canada, New Zealand and a number of others. We should recall that those who voted in favour of the resolution included the Soviet Union, Bulgaria, Cuba, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Guyana, Hungary, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Uganda-which was then under the leadership of that great democrat, Idi Amin-Mali and Mozambique. It is worth noting that not one of those countries could be described as remotely resembling a bastion of democracy, freedom or tolerance.

I think that that vote said more about the moral and political decline of the United Nations than it did about the concern of the international community to eradicate or minimise racism. The resolution reflected far more a hatred of Israel as the only democratic and pluralistic society in the Middle East than it did anything else. Chaim Herzog, to whom the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) referred, said at the time that the United Nations was on its way to becoming the world centre of anti-semitism. He stated:
The issue is the continued existence of this organisation, which has been dragged to its lowest point of discredit by a coalition of despotisms and racists.
It is worth recalling what Daniel Moynihan, on behalf of the United States, had to say:

The United States . . . does not acknowledge, it will not abide by, it will never acquiesce in this infamous act . . . The General Assembly today grants symbolic amnesty-and more-to the murderers of the 6,000,000 European Jews. Evil enough itself, but more ominous by far is the realisation that now presses upon us that, if there were no General Assembly, this could never have happened . . . In all our post-war history there has not been another issue which has brought forth such unanimity of American opinion.

The United States Senate expressed its utter opposition, and expressions of revulsion and opposition were made on behalf of other Western countries. It is instructive to recall that Tass, in its commentary on 13 November, claimed that the resolution-and I quote:
. . . constitutes a lawful and just condemnation of . . . an ideology which finds its practical expression in the aggressive, expansionist policy of the ruling circles in Israel . . .

Those were the words of Tass. This is the same nation which has continually refused exit permits to Soviet Jews and has a long history of racial and religious repression. Paul Johnson, the British historian, said of that resolution:

It was true that the [Anti-Zionist] vote was merely on paper. But the real danger of the UN was that paper majorities tended to grow into real policies. The corrupt arithmetic of the General Assembly, where in the seventies could be brought by arms or even by personal bribes to delegates, tended to become imperceptibly the conventional wisdom of society . . .
Tommy Koh, Singapore's Ambassador to the United States, said:

. . . when the Third World or part of it abuses its power in the General Assembly and rams through Resolutions which are untrue or unprincipled or inflammatory, they do tremendous damage to the credibility of the institution.

I say on behalf of the Opposition, in expressing total support for this motion, that if ever a section of the Australian community is entitled to the respect and gratitude of its fellow Australians, it is the Australian Jewish community. The Australian Jewish community has played a very major role in the development, in the enlightenment, and in the moulding of the character and nature of the Australian people. The contribution that members of that community have made to all walks of life, to our cultural and professional existence, to both sides of politics and to the general enlightenment of our people is something which should not go unremarked on an occasion such as this.

The Liberal Party of Australia has a long and proud tradition of supporting the right of Israel to exist within secure, defensible boundaries. Sir Robert Menzies was a proud defender of Israel's right to exist. My predecessor, Malcolm Fraser, won very wide acclaim within the Jewish community for his constant support of the right and the independence of Israel, and for his defence of the contribution that Jewish people had made to the life and work of Australia. We, like the Government, are committed to meaningful negotiations for a just peace in the Middle East. Our commitment to this goal was given practical expression through the former coalition Government's decision to send an Australian contingent to the Sinai peacekeeping force. With the Government, we call on the United Nations to overturn resolution 3379 as a practical step in promoting peace in the troubled Middle East.

In expressing that bipartisan support, I say one other thing to the Prime Minister and the Government. It is ironic that, although bipartisanship does exist regarding this matter, and we on this side of the House-and, I believe, those on the other side-would want that to continue, the Government, I regret to say, has decided to issue a visa to a Mr Abdul Akhbar Muhammad, the National Assistant to Louis Farrakhan, the so-called Minister of the `Nation of Islam' in North America. It is reported that the Farrakhan organisation is funded by the anti-Semitic Gaddafi regime in Libya. Mr Farrakhan has been banned from both Britain and Nigeria. I hope that, in the spirit in which this motion receives unanimous bipartisan support, the Prime Minister will examine again, on behalf of the Government, the circumstances in which this person's arrival in Australia next Monday has been approved by the Government.

I conclude my remarks by expressing, on behalf of the Opposition, to the people of Israel and to those of Jewish persuasion within Australia, not only our unanimous and enthusiastic support for this motion but also our respect and admiration for their contribution to the cause of peace around the world and within our own country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to associate the National Party of Australia with the motion moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and supported by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). The passage of the United Nations resolution 3379 condemning zionism as a form of racism and racial discrimination is steeped in historical irony. The passage of the resolution through the General Assembly of the United Nations actually occurred on the thirty-seventh anniversary of crystal night-that infamous night in 1938 when Hitler's nazis launched their program of death and destruction against Germany's Jews. We know that the ominous tragedy of crystal night ended in the horrors of Auschwitz and the deaths of millions of Jews.

SPEECH.PARA: The United Nations established the state of Israel for the displaced Jewish people. The Soviet Union endorsed, and actually led the move, to see Israel established. The Soviet Union led the passage, unfortunately, of resolution 3379 through the Assembly, with its satellites and client states which were enumerated by the Leader of the Opposition a moment ago. The resolution aims to undermine the moral legitimacy of the State of Israel and, by implication, it attempts to give justification to calls for the dismemberment of the Jewish state. As Daniel Moynihan, the then United States Ambassador to the United Nations, said, shortly after the vote passed the committee stage:

The real problem is very different, and vastly ominous. It is that the United Nations has become a focus of a general assault by the majority of the nations in the world on the principles of liberal democracy which are now found only in a minority of nations, and for that matter a dwindling minority.

It was not zionism that was condemned in the United Nations on Friday, it was Israel; and not the State of Israel nearly so much as the significance of Israel as one of the very few places, outside of western Europe and North America . . . where western democratic principles survive, and of all such places, currently the most exposed . . .

Resolution 3379 was, and is, nothing more than a blatant example of Soviet opportunism, a pandering to and an inciting of Third World interests to win support in the Soviet's campaign against the West. The movers of resolution 3379 have an unenviable record in human rights. They include the Soviet bloc, members of the Third World and the non-aligned movement. There is nothing noble or high minded about this resolution. It was conceived in the minds of a few radical Arabs, nourished by maniacs such as Idi Amin, promoted by the Palestine Liberation Organisation and reluctantly endorsed by many Third World countries which feared the emerging power of the petro-dollar.

The resolution tarnished the founding ideals of the United Nations by substituting political adventurism and snide expedience in the place of ideals favouring human and international equality. The resolution divided the forum to the detriment of other more legitimate campaigns for racial equality, for example, those in southern Africa. By condemning Israel and zionism, the black Africans lost the support of the United States and other Western countries. It distorted the real meaning of dictators, such as Idi Amin, who were able to jump on the anti-zionist bandwagon while butchering thousands of their own people. Tommy T. B. Koh, Singapore's Ambassador to the United Nations-he was quoted by the Leader of the Opposition a moment ago-said:

When the Third World or a part of it abuses power in the General Assembly and rams through resolutions that are untrue or unprincipled or inflammatory, they do tremendous damage to the credibility of the institution.

The role of the United Nations as an international forum where truth and principle underly the resolutions of the international community of nations was the real victim of resolution 3379. I join the Leader of the Opposition in commendation of the contribution by the Jewish community to Australia. Like him, I share concerns that the world should recognise the state of Israel and that peace should be advanced in the Middle East. In those various ambitions the coalition parties support the Government, for we feel that unless there is unanimity in this part of the world the chance of persuading others to set aside their prejudice, to move away from the text of resolution 3379 and to recognise the contribution of the Jewish people to the world will be very slight indeed. The National Party joins the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal Party in supporting the motion moved by the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr COHEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise that there is an agreement that there be a restricted number of speakers and I shall be very brief in my comments. Rather presumptuously perhaps, on behalf of the Jewish people of Australia I think I can congratulate the House on this motion which, I believe, will be passed unanimously. It is a very proud day in this Parliament's record that such a motion will be passed with the support of all members from both sides of the House. When resolution 3379 was passed through the United Nations it was one of the blackest of black days in the history of the United Nations. The resolution, declaring that zionism is racism, is of course quite an outrageous one.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not propose to go into the history of zionism but, very briefly, it was a movement, started in the latter part of last century and inspired by people such as Theodor Herzl and others, to find a home for the Jewish people, who had for 2,000 years since the destruction of the second temple wandered from various parts of the earth without a home of their own, resulting in some of the most horrendous persecutions and culminating in the crime to end all crimes, the Holocaust, which led to the extermination of six million people for no other reason than that they were Jews.

It used to be common in various journals in not so recent times to insult people by calling them zionists. I would be delighted if anybody wanted to insult me by calling me a zionist because I have been one for as long as I have been conscious of the history of the Jewish people and I hope I shall die a zionist. I also want to comment on what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said. I commend him, and agree totally with him that this Parliament has a proud history of support for the state of Israel, tempered, of course, by a just and appropriate concern for the plight of the Palestinian people, through the days of Dr Evatt and the establishment of the state of Israel to Sir Robert Menzies and Malcolm Fraser who, whilst I disagreed with him on almost everything else, I stand in total agreement with on two issues-apartheid and Israel. A few years ago I was proud to attend a meeting in Melbourne of the Melbourne Jewish community where Malcolm Fraser and I addressed some 1,500 people; it is the largest meeting I have ever attended where people actually listened. I agreed totally with everything he did in support of the state of Israel. Of course, that support has continued through our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Leader of the Opposition, and for that I both commend and congratulate them.

In conclusion, I am proud that the motion will be passed because we will be able to show it to the President of the state of Israel, Chaim Herzog, who will be here in a few days time. As honourable members know, like all good Israelis he is an Irishman and is the first President of Israel-in fact the first foreign President-to address the Irish Dail in Gaelic, something I do not think even you, Mr Deputy Speaker, with your background, or the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), would be able to do. Once again, I commend the House and congratulate everybody. I think I can say on behalf of the Jewish people of Australia that this is a very proud day for all of us.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
