-Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker. Very briefly, I was misrepresented by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in Question Time today. The substance of what he said-I will not repeat what he said verbatim-was that I had proposed an irresponsible course on wages policy which was inconsistent with that of my Leader, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That over 67,000 men, women and students enjoy the pursuit of their sport and recreation every year at the Anzac Rifle Range at Malabar and have done so since 1967.

2. The people of Sydney through their membership of 41 clubs headquartered at the Anzac Rifle Range together with a number of other community, school and commercial groups, the police and armed forces will lose this community facility if the Federal Government proceeds to sell the Range to private developers.
3. The Australian Bicentenary Fullbore Rifle Championships are to be conducted at the Anzac Rifle Range in April 1988 as part of the celebration of Australia's Bicentenary.
Your petitioners therefore urge the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to retain the Anzac Rifle Range for the continued use and enjoyment of the people of Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt,Mr John Brown,Mr Cadman,Mr Coleman,Mr Cowan,Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Hodgman,Mr Mountford,Mr Ian Robinson,Mr Ruddock and Mr Sharp.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: ANDREW; CADMAN; CAMERON; EDWARDS; NEHL; RUDDOCK; SHIPTON
PETITION.TITLE: Closure of Post Office Agencies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that many Post Office Agencies are to be closed. They provide a network of offices with postal and agency services to residential areas and small communities.

They serve a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced if forced to travel further to purchase postal items or collect parcels. It would be an unnecessary expense particularly for pensioners without their own transport.

We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer. They are a community centre particularly in country areas and if necessary they should be subsidised to retain them.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of post office agencies and that the network should be extended, with the Agency services they offer expanded.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew,Mr Cadman,Mr Ian Cameron,Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Nehl,Mr Ruddock and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Test Ban Treaty
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia shows that:
in this International Year of Peace, 1986, the world needs a Nuclear Test Moratorium by the United States, the Soviet Union, France and other nuclear-testing powers
that such a moratorium would create a favourable climate and basis for the negotiation of a Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty
that such a Moratorium and Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty would
be the first vital step to nuclear disarmament
impede the development of new nuclear weapons
decrease the reliance upon an unstable nuclear strategy
inhibit the spread of nuclear weapons.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the Australian Government be urged to
1. Use its influence with the United States Government to encourage it to join the moratorium on nuclear testing begun by the Soviet Union on 6 August 1985.
2. Use its influence in all forums to encourage other nuclear nations to join the Nuclear Test Moratorium.
3. Use its influence in all forums to encourage non-nuclear nations to demand the establishment of a nuclear Test Moratorium and Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Kent,Mr Scott and Mr Wright.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that whereas:
They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Give a speedy passage to the Flags Act Amendment Bill which provides that the Australian National Flag can only be changed by a Referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale and Mr Willis.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament Assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

By cutting ESL funding and eliminating funding for community languages and multicultural education you have attacked tens of thousands of Australian children. You have condemned these children with limited English to gross educational inequality and very dim prospects for their future.
On behalf of these children we call on you to remove this new discrimination which your budget has guaranteed by immediately restoring ESL and Multicultural education funding.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Coleman and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned, are seriously concerned about the impact of the Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. It is unjust for any person to be liable for tax on benefits received by another person.
2. Compliance with FBT will increase administrative costs for all employers including Local, State and Federal government departments.
3. FBT is an inefficient tax, which will require the Tax Office to employ an army of bureaucrats.
4. FBT is inequitable because liability arises regardless of capacity to pay.
5. The FBT laws are extremely complex.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax legislation forthwith.
Your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors
2. its capacity to seriously worsen unemployment through the additional costs it imposes
3. its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance

4. in that it may compel many honest and decent citizens to defy the Tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their businesses and the jobs of their employees, thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax legislation forthwith.
Your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986 is having a detrimental effect on the car industry generally in South Australia, and more particularly, on employment in that industry.

2. The Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986 contains many anomalies, inconsistencies and mistakes in drafting and its administrative implementation is an unwarranted burden on Australian business and the Australian taxpayer.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that this House repeal as a matter of utmost urgency this regressive legislation which imposes a disincentive to economic and employment growth, thereby jeopardising the well-being and living standards of all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the Fringe Benefits Tax is an iniquitous and unjust impost which will further damage the Australian economy and further increase costs to employers.
The Tax will:
(1) further increase the level of unemployment;
(2) increase the administrative costs and overheads for business and Government;
(3) particularly disadvantage small businesses and farmers; and
(4) act as a disincentive to those who are the most productive and skilled;
and we the undersigned call upon the Government to immediately repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that:

The Hawke Government's Fringe Benefits Tax is a vicious, punitive tax that unjustly affects employers, will have a major impact on small business and farm profitability, and will result in increased unemployment.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Parliament to:
Repeal the legislation establishing the Fringe Benefits tax.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Kent and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That there is widespread community concern about the proposal to Irradiate Food in Australia.
Your petitioners, most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, should-
(1) Block the introduction of food irradiation into Australia; and
(2) Ban the import of Cobalt-60 and Caesium 137 and Caesium 134 to be used to irradiate food products.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth the legislation to tax fringe benefits in iniquitous, inequitable and unfair.
Your petitioners humbly pray that you do not proceed with the legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that:
We are opposed to the imposition of a Capital Gains Tax.
Your petitioners humbly pray:
that the Honourable House repeal any Act and reject any Bill which imposes this disincentive to economic growth.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs: Wollongong Area Office
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:
that we the citizens of the Illawarra Region condemn the decision to close the Wollongong office of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs
and that we respectfully request that this decision be reversed immediately.
An your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the Bill of Rights is not supported by the people of Australia, and calls on the Government to:
Delay proclamation of the Bill until all matters of contention are settled by national referenda, and that:
(1) Matters of States rights, property rights, rights of the newborn, the right not to belong to unions, among other issues, have not been submitted to the people of Australia to decide, and that;
(2) No Australian Bill of Rights should depend on any foreign convention for its basis in Australian law.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That Labor's capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax, tax on lump sum superannuation and assets test are an unwarranted burden on the people of Australia, have contributed to the national economic crisis and the anomalies in the legislation are causing confusion and anger amongst all sections of the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of Labor's Assets Test, Labor's Capital Gains Tax, Labor's Fringe Benefits Tax and Labor's tax on lump sum superannuation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament House. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforceable rights;
That the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education;
That the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate;
That the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.

Your petitioners humbly pray that you repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Page electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australia by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of State and Local Governments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:

Repeal the Bills of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Overseas Students
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament of Australia assembled.

We, the undersigned express our deepest concern over the government's discriminatory policies on overseas students which were contained in the 1986/87 Federal Budget. We register our strongest outrage and opposition to:
1. The introduction and subsequent increase of overseas students charge imposed on overseas students.
2. The proposed imposition of fees to secondary and TAFE overseas students.
3. The restrictive quota system on the tertiary institutions entry.
4. The heavy-handed deportation of overseas students who fail to pay their fees in time.

The overseas students program is an important education program to promote international goodwill and peace, especially among nations of Asia and Pacific region. The above mentioned policies have adverse effects on the objectives of overseas students program. Your petitioners therefore urge that the overseas students policies in the 1986-87 Budget be immediately reviewed.

PETITION.TITLE: Chernobyl Nuclear Disaster
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of concern to Australian citizens asks that:
1. The Australian Government exert pressure on Moscow to-
(a) Allow the International Atomic Energy Commission full expert investigation of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster and its human consequences;
(b) Allow Australian Ukrainians to send medical aid to family and friends in Soviet Ukraine; and,
(c) Allow free communication between Australian and Soviet Ukrainians.
2. The Australian Government-
(a) Launch a public appeal to help Chernobyl victims;
(b) Support the removal of Russian nuclear weapons out of Ukraine;
(c) Support the decolonization of the USSR so that captive nations like Ukraine and the Baltic states are not exploited for Soviet Russian nuclear purposes.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows:

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Radio Station 3EA
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia of Albanian back-ground respectfully showeth:
We most strongly oppose the use of the `Special Broadcasting Service' and the taxpayers funds for nationalist political purposes.

We are deeply concerned that the existing Albanian program on Radio 3EA Melbourne is not meeting the needs of the community. It is being used against its' interests, as well as the interests of the broader Australian society.
We respectfully believe that such use of public facilities undermines Australian principles of multi-culturalism and has a damaging effect on community relations.

Your petitioners therefore, strongly urge the Government to take immediate action to ensure that the present announcers of the Albanian program are removed and replaced with community representatives.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament Assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:
We the undersigned residents of Australia totally reject any move to cut funding to Australia-wide English as a Second Language programs in schools.
We request that the Australian government restore funding to the 1985 level in the 1986/87 budget.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor government's productivity- superannuation accord with the ACTU and its support of the superannuation claims of the trade union movement will create an imbalance in industrial power and distort the future development of the Australian economy.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject the superannuation claim of the trade union movement, and allow superannuation to develop without trade union domination.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain electors of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Bill of Rights Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Amendment Bill and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill, if passed by the Parliament, will undermine the human and civil rights in Australia; will attack the institution of the family in our country, and will destroy States Rights and the federal nature of our Commonwealth.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:
The Parliament rejects these Bills; abolishes the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and moves to withdraw ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Film Hail Mary
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that:

(a) The film ``Hail Mary'' (i.e. ``Je Vous salue Marie'') has been registered by the Film Censorship Board for public exhibition with a Restricted Classification; and is due to be screened in the forthcoming Sydney Film Festival;
(b) The film is a blasphemous and pornographic attack on Jesus Christ, the Blessed Virgin Mary, Saint Joseph and the Archangel Gabriel, as such it is extremely offensive to the undersigned;
(c) The film therefore breaches regulation 13 (1) of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations.
Your petitioners therefore request that the House of Representatives call upon the Attorney-General, as the Minister responsible, to prevent the exhibition of the film in Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and the future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum. And your petitioners, as is duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Social Justice, Equity and Redistribution of Wealth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned citizens of Australia, hereby petition the Prime Minister as leader of the Australian Labor Party in Government in Australia and humbly showeth that:

The voting public of Australia did in March 1983 and again in December 1984 vote as a majority for the election of a Labor Government who did claim to stand for social justice, equity and redistribution.
That the said voters sincerely believed that a contract was entered into in voting for a Labor Government with democratic socialist principles.

That there is an erosion of support for the pensioners, the unemployed, the aged, the sick and the working class of Australia, while the lot of the privileged class, the banks, the oil companies, and the money-changers continues to improve.

Your Petitioners call on the Australian Labor Government to implement those policies and follow those principles of social justice, equity and redistribution which the majority of Australians voted for in 1983 and in 1984, and to adopt an immediate programme that will transfer the current economic burden to those better able to carry it.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Western Sydney State University
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:

That they strongly support the establishment of the Western Sydney State University as recommended in the Parry report and call upon the House to establish the Western Sydney State University in conjunction with the New South Wales Government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Cambodian Refugees
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, electors of the Division of Fowler shows the Thai Government recently announced that Khao-I-Dang refugee camp will be closed on 31st December 1986. More than 25,000 Cambodian refugees who survived the ``Killing Fields'' of the Khmer Rouge and entered Thailand after 1979 are still resident in Khao-I-Dang. We hold grave fears for the future and safety of these refugees who will be relocated to camps along the Thai-Cambodian border when Khao-I-Dang is closed.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government will uphold its enviable humanitarian record and act with all haste to facilitate the acceptance and resettlement of as many of these refugees as possible, including a proportion of those who have no relatives to sponsor them.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Prime Minister to keep his promise that inflation would remain below 5 per cent.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance is about two things which are both very directly connected. It is first and foremost about the credibility of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It is about a Prime Minister who has broken more promises than Greg Norman has shot birdies, a Prime Minister who has gone the length and breadth of this country dishonouring every promise that he made to the Australian people in 1983 and 1984. I defy and challenge whoever may reply to me in this debate to nominate one promise made by the Prime Minister which has actually been honoured.

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of this matter of public importance I will list promise after promise that this Prime Minister has broken and indicate the level of loss of credibility that he has now experienced. Before I do so, I remind the Parliament that the quarterly consumer price index figure for the September quarter of 1986 that was released today demonstrates that we now have an annual inflation rate of 8.9 per cent. That figure is no less than five times the average of our major trading partners-not one and a half times, not twice, not three times, but five times the average of our major trading partners. What do the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) say? They say: `Everything is on track; it is exactly what we predicted.' I would hate to imagine where we would be if the Prime Minister was saying that everything was not on track. Everybody in the House at Question Time today would have noticed that as the Prime Minister bobbed and squirmed and tried to evade the responsibility for this appalling high inflation rate, his great excuse-the great Hawke runner in the first half of Question Time-was that it was all the fault of devaluation. He said: `You cannot really blame us for it. It is all the fault of those wicked foreigners. If it had not been for the devaluation our situation would have been much better'.

Our inflation rate is not only five times that of our major trading partners, it is also five times the inflation rate of the United States of America. Is that not the country the Treasurer was lecturing only a few weeks ago? Did the Treasurer not say in Washington: `We have all our fiscal aggregates in order. We have got the deficit down. We have brought down inflation. We have brought down unemployment. It is you Yankees who ought to get your house in order.'? What a hide! What a cheek! No wonder he drives around Sydney in a car with tinted glass. With the sort of economic performance he has been running over the last three years I would drive around Sydney in a car with tinted glass. Actually, if I were him, I do not think I would drive around Sydney at all.

Let us not be uncharitable about this Government. Let us not be uncharitable about the Prime Minister and the Treasurer because, after all, according to them, this has all happened through circumstances beyond their control. They have a very selective view of history. When this Government came to power it had the benefit of the drought breaking, the benefit of the wages pause, which it bitterly opposed, and the benefit of the upturn in the international business cycle. Was that due to the rest of the world? Was that due to mother nature? Was that due to the last Government? Not on your sweet life. It was due to the sweet, innocent brilliance of the Treasurer and the Prime Minister and nothing else. I say to the Treasurer and the Prime Minister that they, and they alone, are responsible for the appalling uncompetitiveness of the Australian economy at the present time.

The other bit of news I have for them is that the swinging voters of Australia believe the Government is responsible for the appalling economic conditions this country has fallen into. There is not one single significant economic aggregate that is now running in the Government's favour. We have an inflation rate which, in relative terms to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, is worse than it has been since the OECD was formed 25 years ago. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer can rant and rave as much as they choose about what the rate of inflation was in March 1983, but what I will ram down their throats and what the Australian public will ram down their throats is that compared with the rest of the industrialised world our inflation rate is now worse than at any time since the formation of the OECD 25 years ago. No wonder the Treasurer got that wooden spoon. No wonder the Euromoney magazine recanted on the aberration of 18 months ago.

It is not only the inflation figure that is important. Let us take all the other relative aggregates. Guess who is the biggest taxing Treasurer this country has had? It is none other than good old Paul Keating. Guess who is the highest spending Treasurer this country has had? Honourable members have got it in one-Paul Keating. Guess who has presided over the highest interest rates we have had since the Great Depression? Honourable members have got it again-the good old exponent of the banana republic. Guess who has given us an even higher number of people on the dole than there were in March 1983? It is the present Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Really?

—Yes, really. The reality is that there are more people on the dole now than there were in March 1983. Guess who has presided over the three largest Budget deficits in the history of this country? The present Treasurer. Guess who has presided over a rate of increase in government spending more than twice the rate of increase under the former Government? Honourable members have got it again. It is rather like that story of 10 green bottles sitting on the wall, and one by one they all come smashing down. Today's figure means that this bloke has got not one green bottle left standing on the wall. They have all come down, one by one, and every single economic credential that in his wild flights of fancy he may have aspired to has been swept away. What a shocking disgrace that a country with the natural endowments that Australia has should be heading towards a total national indebtedness of $100 billion gross. What an appalling record it is that this man who struts around the business community, who flaunts his supposed ability in front of this Parliament, should be presiding over the worst current account deficit in the OECD in 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: What a disgrace it is that he should say to the people of Australia that he is going to introduce the greatest tax reform this country has ever seen. He has the most appalling chaos with the fringe benefits tax. His own back bench committee is about to roll him. He knows as well as we do that all those fellows in marginal seats, such as the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) and the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch)-if ever there was a dead one, it is Punch out in Barton-will be banging on his door and saying: `You have to do something about the fringe benefits tax, because if you don't we are dead'. I know that Treasury is breathing down his neck and saying: `Do not throw away the log books'. The Commissioner of Taxation will be saying: `For heaven's sake, you cannot open the floodgates and let any exceptions through because if you do you will destroy the beautiful symmetry of our fringe benefits tax'. I could almost write the minutes for you, mate. I know exactly what those people will be telling the Treasurer. He is in the most appalling mess on taxation. To crown it all, the one thing that is the king hit as far as the Treasurer and the Prime Minister are concerned, when we actually look at the figures, is that a family on average weekly earnings, after all these reforms, is going to be worse off in July next year than it was in March 1983, and there is nothing that the Prime Minister or the Treasurer can do about it.

If honourable members really want to know what this fellow has done for Australia I ask them to look at some of these charts. Look at this appalling indictment of the comparative inflation rates. Germany has a negative inflation rate of 0.4 per cent. The rate for Japan is 0.2 per cent. The United States of America-remember, that is the country that had it all wrong, the country that was lectured, the country that was destroying the economies of those well run countries such as Australia-has an inflation rate of not 16 per cent, not 12 per cent, not 10 per cent, but a miserly 1.6 per cent. The Treasurer has said that they are the people who have got it all wrong. According to the Treasurer, the United Kingdom cannot run an economy and its policies are all wrong, but it has an inflation rate of only 2.4 per cent.

It gets even better. If we look at this chart we see another gap opening wide, like a pair of jaws. That is the gap between the OECD inflation rate and the inflation rate of this country. But the most fascinating chart of all-this is the one this debate is all about, and I suggest to the House that this is the one that the next 15 months will be all about-is this one about the Prime Minister's credibility. This is a very interesting chart which pinpoints the very day on which the Prime Minister said: `We expect inflation will be less than five per cent in the year ahead and we are determined to keep it below five per cent'.

TALK.START.PARA: —When was that?

—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition asks when this was. It was in October 1984. I suppose the Prime Minister could not have been expected to tell the truth in October 1984 because he was in an election mode, I think it is called. I think he was in the middle of an election campaign, and we cannot really expect the Prime Minister to tell the truth during an election campaign!
—Order!
—Or at any other time.
—Or, indeed, at any other time.
—Order! The honourable member knows that--
—Was I being unfair, Mr Deputy Speaker?
—I think it might be an idea to withdraw those remarks.

—We cannot really expect the Prime Minister to be totally reverential towards accuracy during an election campaign. What did he say in October 1984? He said: `We're going to keep it below 4 per cent'. Where was it by March?
—The people said at the election--

—Oh, come on. The honour- able member should go back to the koalas in Lausanne. He was doing a very good job over there. Where was inflation by March 1985? It was soaring up to 6 per cent. Now it is at 9 per cent. So much for the promises of the Prime Minister. So much for the promise on petrol, the promise on capital gains tax, the promise on interest rates, the promise on pensioner benefits, the promise on the Bill of Rights, the promise on uranium, the promises on this and that. One after one, the Prime Minister has dishonoured every single promise that he has made to the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: He has the temerity to come into the Parliament and say to us today: `It's not our fault. Please don't blame me. I'm an honest man and I really want to be believed and loved by the Australian people. Please don't take it out on me. It's the world's fault. It's the business community's fault. It might, in time, even be Keating's fault. It cannot possibly be my fault because I, the present Prime Minister of Australia, can do no wrong'. He tried to tell us that the real reason inflation had gone up was devaluation and that it had nothing whatever to do with him.

When I put it to the Prime Minister that over the last three years unit labour costs have gone up by four times the level by which they have increased in the seven major member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development-in other words, our wages relative to those of our major trading partners have gone up by four times the rate they have risen in those countries-and that, had that not occurred, our competitive position would not be as bad and depreciation of the magnitude that has taken place to correct that competitive position would not have been necessary, was there any reply from the Prime Minister? He just waffled on about entirely irrelevant and unnecessary statistics from the Budget Papers. The fact is that the depreciation of the Australian dollar is a direct result of the fact that over the last three years our wage costs have gone up at four times the rate they have in comparable countries. That is the fact. That is the reality. If that had not occurred our dollar would not have depreciated by the amount that it has and we would not be suffering the inflationary surge we are at present.

It is therefore totally unacceptable for the Prime Minister to seek refuge behind the argument that it is all the fault of the Western world. It is the fault of two people and two people alone. The Australian people know it, the people concerned know it and this Parliament knows it. They both stand utterly condemned for their irresponsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have just heard is a noisy but nervous little speech given by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) not to the subject--
—Waffle.
—The Leader of the Opposition was heard in silence, now hear me in silence.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise on my left. The Leader of the Opposition was heard in silence.

—The honourable member did not talk to the policy issues. It was a speech given to the back bench of the coalition parties. That is what we just heard. We heard from the Leader of the Opposition words such as `Australia's appalling uncompetitiveness'. If there is one thing that the Leader of the Opposition ought to know about where the exchange rate is and the stability of wage outcomes it is that, on the Australian competitiveness index, we have not been as competitive as this in the last 20 years. But he says: `Australia's appalling uncompetitiveness'. In other words, he makes a totally erroneous point; a point made cheaply but a totally erroneous point. He talks about people on the dole when he doubled the unemployment rate in 18 months.

SPEECH.PARA: He makes the cheap and lousy point about my presiding over Budget deficits, the largest and the first of which was inherited from him, and he fails to make the point that the Government has brought down the Budget imbalance consistently over four Budgets, to the point where now, as the Economic Planning Advisory Council said in its estimation the other day, the structural Budget deficit is zero. He talks about Australia's indebtedness when he knows that the generator of our debt has been five or six accumulated current account deficits which have arisen from the lack of Australian competitiveness. He knows that the cause of that competitiveness is the overvaluation of the exchange rate over the years under his Administration, poor wage outcomes, bad inflation, a terms of trade collapse and a trend decline in the terms of trade. He talks about indebtedness and he knows the cause of it-an increase in the valuation effect off the depreciation in the Australian dollar denomination of debt. He knows that the accumulation of the current account imbalances is the cause of our uncompetitiveness.

He knows the position on the Budget deficit is not as he stated. He knows he makes simply a cheap point about the dole when unemployment was out of control in his period in office. His remark about Australia's appalling uncompetitiveness demonstrates either a lack of understanding on his part about how truly competitive Australia now is or simply a desire to make a cheap political point. The Leader of the Opposition came to office on a platform of decency in politics and a structure of political thinking and political policy. We have now found that all of that has been junked for the kind of opportunist rhetoric we have just heard. He had nothing constructive to say about competitiveness, employment, fiscal policy or indebtedness. At least let me say this of the former Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock): He may not have the framework the Leader of the Opposition believed he should have had, but at least what he did he did with grace and some style. What we have now is a graceless, styleless, idealless, nervous Leader of the Opposition.

While this Government struggles with the restoration of Australia's competitiveness, a trend decline in the terms of trade, double digit inflation, massive unemployment, pulling Australia from two major crises in its recent history-that is, the internally induced depression of 1982-83 and the terms of trade collapse of 1985-86-relieving Australia from the yoke of the current account deficit, giving it the prospects of long term, sustainable low inflationary growth, and while it deals with the massive, fundamental fiscal imbalance of nearly 5 per cent of gross domestic product bequeathed to us by the honourable member for Bennelong, there is not one solid, constructive, positive word for the Government's courage in floating the exchange rate, sticking with the adjustments, wearing the adjustments in wages over three years, pulling down the fiscal imbalance from 5 per cent of GDP to 1.4 per cent, to the point where now this country has one of the most rigorous fiscal and monetary regimes in the world.

Let me tell the House this-and I am quite prepared to point this out to any country, including the United States, Germany: This country has one of the most rigorous fiscal and monetary regimes in the world. We are not simply saying that we will let the dam wall of wages, the incomes policy, hold it all back. We are using the traditional instruments of policy effectively-more effectively than under the honourable member's Administration-but of course we have in place the other major policy of adjustment, an incomes policy, which has reduced real wage costs over the last few years.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about indexation? Do you support that?

—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition is stung by my answer at Question Time because he knows that he has put his foot in it yet again. On AM this morning he said that we ought to have another wage pause, when he rejects all notions of centralised wage fixing. The Leader of the Opposition denies the undeniable point that, when one has a major fall in the exchange rate, a major depreciation, to recover competitiveness, there is an unavoidable lift in inflation as imports price themselves out of the Australian market. As they do so, the price effect is measured by the consumer price index. Let us be clear about this: With a 2.3 per cent wage increase-the only one in calendar year 1986-it is clear that the surge in inflation has not come from wages; it has come from the depreciation.

SPEECH.PARA: In Question Time the Leader of the Opposition said that the Australian Statistician had measured the direct effect of the depreciation surge in the CPI at, I think, 0.38 per cent. But the Statistician has measured only the price effects of goods sold as imports in this economy. He has never measured and does not attempt to measure the indirect price effects of materials imported which are then produced into import replacement goods. He measures only the direct price of imported completed, finished goods as they arrive in this economy. He does not measure the indirect price effects of materials which go to import-competing products. That is a very convenient point for the Leader of the Opposition to overlook, but that is the cause of the temporary surge in inflation. That temporary surge will be diminished as the Government's wage policies pull that price surge out of wages and we see inflation track down.

What is this Government doing? It is dealing with the two big fundamental imbalances-the fiscal imbalance and the current account imbalance. It has licked the first; it is working on the second. It has laid down the policies to deal with the second. Australia fundamentally is in a much better position because its fiscal policies are down and Commonwealth demands on capital markets are down. In terms of the current account deficit, the dollar is now working its way to change the balance of imports and exports, to see the trade account respond to the increased indebtedness of the depreciation. We are then matching that inflationary surge with an incomes policy which we are putting together and have been putting together for the last 3 1/2 years with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and now with business.

In that shabby, nervous little speech that we just heard there was not one solid point about how there would be a more competitive economy under the coalition or about this Government's policies of rebalancing the economy to reweight it away from dependency on the primary export sector to the manufacturing sector, to rebuild our secondary structure and to relieve us of the yoke of the current account deficit to allow us to go back to a policy of growth without needing to restrain demand and imports. There was no discussion or questioning of this strategy, just attacks about the short term inflationary consequences of the shift in the dollar. Then came all the other silly points about the fringe benefits tax and everything else.

The Leader of the Opposition stands on his tax record. Everyone knows what it is. He talks about minutes from the Treasury. The Treasury knows that there was no courage lurking in the Leader of the Opposition to change the tax system. No one will find minutes from the Treasury urging him to make many changes because it knew that he would never make any. The Treasury is a department of principle. It is after good economic outcomes. I have fought for them; the Leader of the Opposition never did. He should not try to chide me about Treasury minutes. The Treasury has no pride in him. Let us be clear about that. Of course the Treasury fights for tax principles. Why would it not? Of course it fights for decent economic policies. Why would it not? I hope that the Australian Treasury will always stand up to any other section of the public and put its view courageously, as it does.

In terms of tax and the fringe benefits tax, the Commissioner of Taxation wrote to the former Treasurer in 1977, saying: `We must do something about fringe benefits taxation and our runaway tax system'. He wants to make those points. I respond to the Leader of the Opposition. He raises this issue of inflation. I have come in to listen to what he has to say, but essentially there is nothing but abuse about appalling uncompetitiveness-things which are banal-cheap points about people on the dole and about who lived under the highest interest rates. Those are silly, banal points.

This Government has in place a very sound structure for dealing with these problems. The quality, speed and magnitude of the changes are being recognised not just in Australia but around the world. The Leader of the Opposition mentioned my comments to American audiences. When they were told that equivalent changes in Budget outlays in the American budgetary system would be a change of $60 billion in outlays and $20 billion in receipts-which would reduce their deficit from about $200 billion to about $120 billion-they gasped at the rate of change here. When people around the world look at our monetary policy settings and the relative wage changes which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) read out at Question Time, they understand our position. That understanding is now being manifested in the exchange rate strengthening, interest rates subsiding today and a further decline in 90-day bill rates.

Sitting in front of me is an eminently beatable commodity in the Leader of the Opposition. As he said in New York when our exchange rate was under pressure, he may think that the times suit him. He thought that this Government would not measure up to the changes that it needed to make. It has made them and that will pay off for this Government and for Australia. Any nervous little speeches, giggling, cackling or speaking to his back bench will not disguise the quality and impact of those changes on this economy over the next couple of years. The Australian people will have a very clear choice at the next election between a government of quality with quality changes for the long term and the kinds of shibboleths they heard from the Leader of the Opposition today. I know what their choice will be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Treasurer's time has expired. The debate is concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 259th report of the Committee, relating to the Department of Community Services-Proposal to acquire computing facilities, and I ask leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Report 259 presents the findings of the Committee's examination of a proposal by the Department of Community Services to acquire a distributed computing capability. The proposal was referred to the Committee under the terms of its standing reference to investigate and report on proposed acquisitions of automatic data processing facilities by Commonwealth departments and authorities staffed under the Public Service Act 1922. The proposal by the Department of Community Services was estimated to cost approximately $20m for hardware and system software over three years and a further $6.1m per annum for other costs.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee identified several major areas of concern in the Department's initial submission which were not allayed by the Department's supplementary submission, sought by the Committee to address these matters. The Committee's primary concerns continue to relate to first, the definition of the system requirements: The individual applications proposed to be automated have not been examined for their cost effectiveness and have not been assigned priorities; and the estimate of computer capacity requirements appears excessive. Secondly, they relate to options for meeting system requirements: The Department has given serious consideration only to its preferred option of a distributed computing capability; insufficient consideration has been given to a range of options between the centralised and distributed options which might meet the Department's requirements at less cost; and no serious consideration has been given to less ambitious but potentially more cost effective options which exclude automation of low priority applications. Thirdly, they relate to option costs: Costs appear to have been understated for all options, particularly for the preferred option of a distributed computing capability; the understated costs have biased the proposal in favour of a distributed system; and should the Department proceed to acquire a distributed computing capability of the capacity proposed there is a likelihood of cost over-runs.

The Committee concluded that the Department's preferred option has not been satisfactorily justified on cost effectiveness grounds. The Committee concluded that there are several other less ambitious, less costly and potentially more cost effective options which the Department should seriously evaluate in greater detail before finalising its procurement proposals. The Committee's consideration of this proposal by the Department of Community Services has differed from the scrutiny given other proposals under the Committee's standing reference in that it did not include a public hearing.

The Committee has in its review of previous ADP acquisition proposals found that repeated attempts to elicit satisfactory answers and information from proponent departments have generally not justified the associated time and effort expended by the Committee. The Committee will in future be taking the view that if initial submissions are not satisfactory, and the subsequent communication of the Committee's concerns to the proponent department does not elicit a satisfactory response, the Committee will report its views to Parliament without further delay. The Committee has decided in this case to present its views in a short report to Parliament to enable the Department of Community Services to respond promptly to the concerns raised by the Committee in a further submission to Cabinet. The Committee considers that Cabinet funding approval should not be given to the Department to acquire computing facilities until the detailed studies recommended in this report have been completed, and the Department has demonstrated to Cabinet that it has selected the most cost-effective means of meeting its information requirements.

In May 1985 the Committee issued its initial guidelines for the content of submissions to the Committee under its standing reference, and invited comments from departments on these. It has to date received no comments. The Committee itself has identified some areas of deficiency and of potential improvement. It now intends, with the benefit of its experience of the four inquiries it has now completed under the reference, to issue revised guidelines which will assist departments to prepare submissions that will meet the Committee's needs and therefore expedite the process of the Committee's inquiry and report and ADP purchases. The Committee continues to welcome any comments that interested departments and agencies may wish to make on the guidelines. I recommend the report to honourable members.

DEBATE.TITLE: REDEVELOPMENT OF SCHOOL OF MILITARY ENGINEERING, CASULA, NEW SOUTH WALES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Redevelopment of the School of Military Engineering, Casula, NSW.

This proposed work was referred to the Public Works Committee on 5 June 1986. The proposal includes refurbishment and demolition of existing sub-standard facilities, some of which date back to World War II. The school provides training in military engineering and other specialist skills for the Royal Australian Engineers. The school trains foreign students and personnel from government departments, trains dogs and their handlers in the detection of explosives and develops engineer doctrines, techniques and training methods. It also provides assistance to the civilian community.

The proposed work comprises the provision of new training facilities, administration accommodation, vehicle maintenance and stores, and the provision of associated roads and engineering services. It also includes the refurbishment of facilities, the demolition of sub-standard installations, and the upgrading of the Moorebank area mains water system to provide a reliable and effective fire-fighting capability.

The estimated cost of the proposed work is $31.6m at August 1986 prices. It is intended that initial tenders will be invited in April 1987, the first construction contract awarded in June 1987, and for the work to be completed by June 1991. Consultants have been used to design the proposal and it is intended that consultants will be used for the project documentation. The design of the Moorebank area water mains system will be undertaken by my Department.

Construction of the work is to be contracted to private enterprise as has been the case for many years with DHC activities. This is consistent with the normal practice of my Department, contrary to anything that the Opposition spokesman on housing and construction may say or has said in the past. About 130 people will be employed on the work. I would like to thank the Public Works Committee for its effort, for the support it has given to this proposal and for the prompt way it has handled it. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the absence of my colleague the shadow Minister for Housing and Construction, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), I am pleased to inform the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) that the Opposition accepts this motion. We look forward to monitoring the progress of the things which are contained in it and which will flow from it.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEVELOPMENT OF NEW UTILITY HELICOPTER FACILITIES AT RAAF BASE, TOWNSVILLE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Development of new utility helicopter facilities at RAAF Base, Townsville.

This proposed work is for the construction of new operational, technical and administrative facilities at the Royal Australian Air Force Base in Townsville. This will enable the relocation of No. 9 Squadron from Amberley after it is re-equipped with the new Sikorsky Blackhawk helicopters. The primary role of No. 9 Squadron is to provide support to the Army, principally the operational deployment force based at Townsville. Because of the many non-productive transit flying hours involved in operating out of Amberley, the Squadron is to be relocated to Townsville.

The proposed work comprises site preparation and the provision of trunk engineering services, extension of the taxiway and new helicopter apron and the construction of a maintenance hangar, flight line annex and technical support facility. It also includes the construction of a headquarters building, ancillary building and carpark, the relocation of a fuel tanker parking area, and associated security measures. The relocation of No. 9 Squadron will require the provision of accommodation for RAAF personnel. This will initially involve a total of 15 married quarters. The estimated cost of providing these facilities at Townsville is $20.7m at October 1986 prices-$19.3m for on-base helicopter facilities and $1.4m for the 15 off-base houses. Provision for this outlay has been included in the Defence capital works program for 1986-87.

Possible future requirements to accommodate the squadron at Townsville include 56 new houses and land packages at a cost of $6.3m and the upgrading of 42 existing surplus Army dwellings at a cost of $1.5m. These items will be subject to separate funding arrangements by the Department of Defence in future financial years after actual needs and the identification of the surplus houses has been determined. In addition, four accommodation blocks for single personnel will be upgraded and refurbished at a cost of $700,000 which will be funded separately from Defence repairs and maintenance programs. Construction on the initial $20.7m facilities is urgent if they are to be available at the earliest date after delivery of the new helicopters in 1987.

In view of this urgency, approval has been given to concurrent documentation up to the tender stage pending the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Public Works. Subject to parliamentary approval of the proposed work, it is intended to invite tenders for the on-base helicopter facilities in March 1987, and to complete construction in August 1988. This will provide the RAAF with sufficient time to commission the new facilities before the squadron is relocated early in 1989. I table plans of the proposed work and commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, in the absence of my colleague the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), let me say that the Opposition welcomes the referral of these proposed works to the Joint Standing Committee on Public works. We look forward to its deliberations and report.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Privacy Bill and the associated Privacy (Consequential Amendments) Bill is to regulate the collection, handling and use by Commonwealth departments and agencies of information about individuals so as to provide them with a level of privacy protection that is consistent with efficient Government administration. The Privacy Bill will establish a comprehensive set of rules regulating such dealings with personal information and provide an effective means for monitoring compliance with the rules. The rules will, however, mesh with and avoid overlapping existing legislation which coincidentally protects privacy, such as the Freedom of Information Act.

At common law there is no enforceable right to privacy as such. There are, however, various existing legal rights that protect aspects of what are generally regarded as individual privacy. Thus the existing law on defamation, breach of confidence, copyright and passing off can be used to prevent unauthorised circulation of personal information or comment in various circumstances. In recent times there have been enormous developments in technology for processing information, providing immense opportunities for building up and using information on individuals. This has focused attention on the need to provide more comprehensive measures for protecting privacy against the threat posed by misuse of this technology. This has been recognised during the development of the Australia Card by the decision to establish the Data Protection Agency.

With the greater range of services being provided by the Government, the greater is the accumulation of personal information about individuals. More than anything else, the capacity of modern computers to search and process information offers the greatest potential for invasion of personal privacy by misuse. The greater the accumulations of personal information, the greater are the possibilities of inaccurate material being included amongst such information. Decisions based on wrong information are oppressive to the individual concerned and hinder efficient administration. Internationally, guidelines for the enactment of legislation protecting personal privacy in the processing of information have been developed by the Council of Europe and by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) of which Australia is a member. Most European countries, the United States of America and Canada have enacted privacy protection legislation. In December 1984, Australia formally signified its intention to introduce legislation along the lines of the OECD guidelines on the protection of privacy and transborder flows of personal data.

The Government has been giving detailed consideration for some time to comprehensive information privacy protection legislation. In December 1983 a very detailed report and recommendations were received from the Law Reform Commission following a reference to the Commission in 1976. The recommendations included draft legislation which drew on the OECD guidelines. The scheme of the Bill is to enunciate a series of rules, called information privacy principles, which are based on the principles recommended by the Law Reform Commission in its draft legislation. They will apply to Commonwealth departments and agencies to the same extent that the FOI Act applies to them. Privacy complaints against security and intelligence agencies, which are not subject to the FOI Act and thus are exempt from this Bill, will be able to be dealt with by the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security.

Under the principles, Commonwealth agencies must have a lawful purpose for collecting personal information, and the purpose must be related to the functions or activities of the collector. An agency collecting personal information from the information subject must see that the latter is generally aware of such things as the purpose for which the information is being collected and, if such is the case, the fact that collection is authorised or required by law. The principles require agencies, when both collecting and retaining information, to see that it is relevant to the purpose of collection, is up to date and is complete. Before using any information, they must also check its accuracy. Personal information is widely defined to include anything-fact, true or false, or opinion-that reasonably identifies the information subject. However, all the principles are concerned only with personal information in a record or collected for inclusion in a record or a publication, so unrecorded conversation, for example, is not covered.

The principles require agencies to store information records securely against loss or misuse. If asked, they are to provide information about the types of personal information they hold. Subject to FOI Act exemptions they are to provide access to them if sought by the information subject and to make corrections for accuracy, relevance and completeness. Subject to certain specific exceptions, notably to law enforcement and preservation of life, information that was sought from the information subject may not be used for a purpose or disclosed to a person other than with the agreement of the information subject.

Commonwealth agencies will be required to comply with these principles. A breach of the principles will be deemed by the Bill to be an interference with privacy. Under the Bill the Data Protection Agency-DPA-to be established by the Australia Card Bill will undertake the functions of investigating alleged interferences with privacy, attempting to resolve the allegations by conciliation and, failing that, reporting to the Minister where it finds that there has been such an interference. The DPA's powers in conducting investigations will be those prescribed in the Australia Card Bill. The DPA's investigation and reporting functions will be exercisable not only on complaint but also of its own motion. Remedies such as injunction and declaration will be able to be sought against interferences with privacy to the extent that they are available under existing law. However, the Government has decided that, at this initial stage, it should not be possible to recover damages for interferences with privacy by agencies. Nevertheless, when reporting a finding that an interference with privacy has occurred, the DPA will be able to make a recommendation for compensation to an individual affected by the interference.

To help agencies achieve compliance with the principles, the DPA will be able to give advisory opinions, issue guidelines and examine proposed enactments for privacy implications. Where an agency believes that a current or proposed practice that may breach the principles is nevertheless important to its operations, it will be able to seek from the DPA a determination allowing the practice to continue or go ahead without risk of its being found to be an interference with privacy. Such a determination may be granted only if the DPA is satisfied that the public interest in permitting the practice substantially outweighs the public interest in adherence to the principles.

I mentioned earlier that the law of confidence is an important existing means of protecting privacy in some circumstances. The Bill includes some limited extensions of the law of confidence recommended by the Law Reform Commission which will further enhance privacy protection. The companion Privacy (Consequential Amendments) Bill includes amendments of the FOI Act to extend the opportunities for access to personal affairs records by record subjects and establish the requirement for record subjects to be alerted to requests for access to those records by others. The proposals contained in the Privacy Bill and the Privacy (Consequential Amendments) Bill are expected to have a direct cost to the Government of $800,000 in a full year of operation.

International instruments to which I have referred, overseas legislation and the Law Reform Commission's report recognise that there are important interests that compete with the right to privacy, including effective government administration, law enforcement and free flow of information. The Government considers that the Privacy Bill, applying as it does to Commonwealth agencies, strikes a fair balance between the right of the individual to privacy and the equally important concern of the individual, as a taxpayer, that the Commonwealth administration is not overburdened. What will be achieved by the Privacy Bill is a comprehensive code of information privacy protection standards. It will be the first such legislation anywhere in Australia. It will also provide a practical means for persons who have been adversely affected by a failure to comply with those standards to seek redress. I commend the Bill to the House. I present to the House an explanatory memorandum to this Bill and to the subsequent Privacy (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986.
Debate (on motion by Mr Shack) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Mr Deputy Speaker, this Bill is a companion measure to the Privacy Bill which I have just introduced. The main amendment made by this Bill is to the Freedom of Information Act to introduce `reverse FOI' for personal affairs documents. That is, where documents requested under FOI include a record of personal affairs of a person other than the requester, the record-subject must, if possible, be consulted and given an opportunity to seek exemption from disclosure to the requester of that record. Another amendment to the Act will slightly restrict the circumstances in which a ground of exemption from access can be used to prevent access to a record of personal affairs by the record subject. Otherwise this Bill makes essentially machinery amendments to ensure that privacy complaints wrongly directed to other agencies are transferred to the Data Protection Agency for investigation under the Privacy Bill without inconvenience to the complainant. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Shack) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Industrial Matters)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Mr Deputy Speaker, on 25 September 1986 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) announced in this place a range of decisions taken by the Government to give effect to our commitment to improve the efficiency of the public sector. This Bill implements those decisions that require amendment of legislation-in particular, amendment of the Public Service Act and repeal of the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act.

From the beginning of this Government's term in office we recognised that there were substantial barriers to productivity and efficiency in many industries because of inefficient work and management practices. Those barriers had built up and become ingrained over many years and would not be changed overnight. We recognised that change was vital if we were to maximise our economic potential. Consequently, agreements to address such practices formed an integral part of proposals to restructure the steel industry, the heavy engineering industry, the motor vehicle industry, the shipbuilding industry, and most recently the ship repair industry. The need to address inefficient work and management practices was agreed by both business and union representatives at the work practices meeting convened by the Federal Government. This meeting was a major initiative and the resultant agreement was a vital step forward in tripartite co-operation to address inefficient practices and improve productivity.

The Government is therefore giving a lead to changing work practices in the private sector. It is, however, equally determined that its own house should be in order. This Bill is part of that process. Taken together with this Government's Public Service reform legislation passed in 1984, this amounts to the most substantial amendment of Public Service employment legislation since the introduction of the present Public Service Act in 1922. The most significant areas of change in the current legislation are: Revised redeployment and retirement provisions in circumstances of excess officers, inefficiency invalidity and loss of essential qualifications; and changes to the promotion and the promotion appeals system. In addition, many other amendments are made consistent with the Government's desire to simplify and streamline a range of personnel processes.

There is a common thread to these changes-increased efficiency and better management. The Government expects its managers to manage. It is establishing the framework within which that can take place. Turning first to the tenure of public servants, this Bill repeals the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act 1979. As the Prime Minister said in his statement, this Act has not provided a satis- factory basis for the redeployment and retirement of staff. In its place, this Bill inserts new provisions in the Public Service Act which provide for circumstances of excess staff, inefficiency, invalidity or loss of essential qualifications.
Surplus Staff

The Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act has not provided an efficient or satisfactory mechanism for dealing with surplus staff. The processes of the Act are extremely complex; it does not provide for an effective voluntary retrenchment scheme; it provides too many stages of appeal; and its potential for providing a Commonwealth employment-wide redeployment system has not been realised.
