Further, its processes are extremely time consuming and it can take up to two years to finalise a surplus staff situation under the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act Award. The Government has decided to simplify and speed up the processes of dealing with surplus staff. Detailed procedures have been kept out of the Public Service Act. Negotiations will take place with the unions to obtain a new redeployment and retirement award to apply to all public servants to provide common consultation, notice and benefit provisions.

When a potential redundancy arises the secretary to a department will notify the relevant unions and the Board. After consultation with the unions, where redeployment prospects are poor, and where the Board approves, staff will be eligible for lump sum termination benefits if they agree to voluntary retrenchment. Voluntary retrenchment, where necessary, will be able to be offered one month after the unions have been provided with the relevant facts. A voluntary retrenchment payment of two weeks for each year of service with a minimum of four weeks and a maximum of 48 weeks pay, plus four weeks notice of payment in lieu, is proposed. Staff will be given one month to elect to take retrenchment.

Using this approach, where redundancies are unavoidable, the aim will be to have voluntary retirements achieved within two months. Secretaries and the Public Service Board will continue to accept an obligation to take reasonable action to find alternative suitable employment in the Service before exercising the power to retrench involuntarily or reduce an officer's classification. In these circumstances, the current income maintenance periods of six or 12 months will be retained, beginning from the date of the offer of voluntary retrenchment; that is, at least two months earlier than the current processes. As an essential protection against arbitrary or capricious action by management there will be in the Public Service Act a right of appeal against involuntary retrenchment or reduction in classification to a tripartite Redeployment and Retirement Appeal Committee established by the Merit Protection and Review Agency.
Inefficient Staff

The repeal of the Redeployment and Retirement Act and the substitution of new streamlined provisions in the Public Service Act will have a substantial effect on management's ability to deal with inefficient staff. The Government acknowledges that most public servants are conscientious, hard-working and efficient. However, there are exceptions, as there must be in any big organisation. As the Prime Minister said in his ministerial statement, the Government expects the power given to departmental secretaries in respect of non-performing staff to be used in appropriate circumstances. Poor performers will be given a formal warning in writing and a three-month period in which to reach the necessary standard. If they do not improve, the Secretary, on the advice of an assessment committee, will be able to reduce them to a lower level or to retire them. The officer will have one month's notice of redeployment to a lower level or retirement and a right to appeal to a Redeployment and Retirement Appeal Committee established by the Merit Protection and Review Agency. The new measures are markedly different from those under the previous arrangements which provided for a multiplicity of appeals and a requirement for the Public Service Board to attempt to redeploy inefficient staff. The new provisions will be a significant spur to efficient performance.
Promotions and Appeals

I turn now to the promotion and promotions appeals system. The Government is firmly committed to promotion solely on the basis of merit. The Public Service is justifiably proud of the absence of cronyism from its ranks. There is no place for patronage, favouritism or discrimination. This Bill strengthens and extends the existing prohibitions on patronage, favouritism and discrimination. Section 33 of the Act will state categorically that powers are to be exercised without patronage, favouritism or discrimination. The disciplinary provisions will be amended to make express reference to the fact that patronage, favouritism or discrimination amount to misconduct and render officers liable to disciplinary action.

The Bill amends the definition of efficiency for promotion decisions. It will be broadened to permit secretaries to departments to consider the potential for future career development of applicants and their capability to perform a variety of jobs at the same level as well as their suitability for the particular vacancy. This will lead to more realistic selection decisions and more flexible staffing. Whilst the present promotion and appeal system is generally providing good results, it is far too expensive and time consuming. When an appeal is involved it is estimated that, on average, it takes 36 weeks to fill a vacancy.

Measures must be taken to reduce the costs and time involved when making promotions. This Bill and associated regulations will exclude appeals against promotions to positions above Clerical Administrative Class 8 and equivalent grades in other occupations. These positions are managerial, senior technical and professional in nature. This is already recognised by the cut-off of eligibility for overtime payments above this level. In such cases it is not appropriate for an external body such as the Promotion Appeal Committee to be substituting its view for that of departmental management as to who is best suited to do the job. However, as a protection against improper selection practices, the Merit Protection and Review Agency will be able to recommend to the departmental secretary that a promotion be cancelled if an unsuccessful applicant can establish, to its satisfaction, that the promotion decision was affected by patronage, favouritism or discrimination or that there was a serious defect in the selection process, and that it is unreasonable for the promotion to stand. Other significant changes to the promotion appeal system include the reduction of the appeal period and the limitation of the right to appeal to original applicants.

The Government sees the increased use of joint selection committees as making a significant contribution to reducing the costs of selection processes, particularly where bulk promotions are concerned. The legislation will be amended to introduce a special category of management-initiated joint selection committees. After, consultation with the unions, the Board will notify in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette the circumstances in which these committees may be used. The committees will comprise a convenor nominated by the Merit Protection and Review Agency, a nominee of the department and, if nominated within a prescribed period, a nominee of the relevant union. If no union nomination is forthcoming the committee will nevertheless be able to proceed. However, due to the consultation with the unions it is expected that there will be full co-operation during the trial period of 12 months. Where the secretary accepts the unanimous advice of a joint selection committee, the promotion will not be subject to appeal.

The Government would expect these procedures to be used in bulk selection situations in agreed areas such as the Australian Taxation Office, the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations and the Department of Social Security where significant numbers of vacancies at the same level are to be filled simultaneously. It is expected that, together with revised guidelines on selections, these changes to the promotion and appeal systems will significantly reduce the time taken to fill positions and the number and cost of appeals. This must lead to a more responsive and efficient Service.

I now wish to mention some of the other more important features of the Bill. The Bill includes a number of changes to the disciplinary provisions. This aims at reducing unnecessary procedural steps, providing more relevant penalties and removing costly appeals against minor disciplinary actions. There are also a number of amendments designed to permit the devolution of casework from the Public Service Board to departments. Over the years the Board has progressively delegated many of its functions; this is a continuation of that process. It is fundamental to the aim of providing managers with the power to manage. A range of other delegations will be implemented by administrative action by the Public Service Board. As mentioned in the Prime Minister's statement, many of the Government's decisions will be implemented by subordinate legislation or other administrative action.

Regulations are currently being drafted to simplify selection procedures for temporary higher duties by allowing departments to select the most suitable officer available, having regard to operational requirements, and abolishing appeals against such selections, unless the period of acting extends beyond three months. These regulations are not dependent upon legislation and it is expected that they will be made as soon as possible. Arrangements are already in hand to begin the review by the Public Service Board of flextime.

Honourable members will also recall the Prime Minister's announcement of the establishment of an efficiency scrutiny unit to be headed by Mr David Block, AO, and the announcement of a number of other measures to enhance financial efficiency. The efficiency scrutiny unit is expected to be up and running early in the new year and early action is being taken to implement the decisions announced on financial management.
Financial Impact

It is not possible precisely to quantify the financial savings that will flow from passage and implementation of this Bill. Major savings will be derived from more efficient personnel practices generally. In particular, there will be savings from a more streamlined promotion and appeal system, the removal of appeals above Class 8 and the increased use of joint selection committees. More efficient processes for handling surplus staff situations and the significant changes relating to the retirement of inefficient staff will also be a source of significant long term savings for the Government.

This Government has done more than any of its predecessors to reform the Public Service, to maximise its efficiency and effectiveness and to improve the quality of services provided to the Government and the community. This Bill makes further significant changes towards that same end. I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Shack) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill and the two associated Bills-the Pig Industry (Transitional Provisions) Bill 1986 and the Pig Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986-is to restructure the statutory arrangements fo the Australian pig and pigmeat industry. This Bill establishes an Australian Pork Corporation to replace the existing Pork Promotion Committee, and establishes an Australian Pork Corporation Selection Committee, to nominate suitably qualified persons for appointment to the Corporation, and an Australian Pig Industry Policy Council to provide a forum where matters of concern to the industry as a whole can be discussed and appropriate policy options developed.

During the past 10 years the Australian pigmeat industry has made many significant advances. These are best illustrated by the increase in pigs slaughtered from 3.4 million in 1974-75 to an estimated 4.5 million in 1985-86. The gross value of production in the same period has risen from $197m to $450m. Domestic per capita consumption of pig meat has risen from 12.9 kilograms to over 16 kilograms. These are growth rates of which any industry would be proud. It is appropriate that such a dynamic industry should review its organisational structure to ensure that it is relevant to today's needs and the requirements of tomorrow.

The Australian pig industry has been concerned for some time that the legislation creating the Pork Promotion Committee has not been sufficiently broad to enable that body to become involved in marketing initiatives on behalf of the industry as a whole. This has included such developments as computer aided livestock marketing-CALM-and the development of a national livestock language-Ausmeat. In both these initiatives the interests of the beef and sheep meat industries have been represented by the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation-AMLC. If the pig industry is to be fully involved in either of these schemes it will be necessary to place the responsibility in the hands of a statutorily-funded body.

In discussions with the industry on the most suitable structure for industry organisations a number of options were put forward, one of which was to bring the marketing of pigs and pig meat within the scope of the AMLC. Serious consideration was given to this option but in the end the pig industry decided it wanted to remain independent of the AMLC. After lengthy discussion with the industry the package contained within this legislation was developed and accepted by the Australian Pork Producers' Federation as the most suitable that could be achieved. The new Australian Pork Corporation will have a wider range of functions and powers than the present Pork Promotion Committee. This will enable it to become involved in marketing issues affecting the industry where it feels such involvement is necessary and desirable. The Corporation is not intended to be a trading body or to involve itself in any form of price setting mechanism that would restrict competition in the market-place.

The Corporation will have the power, on behalf of the pig industry, to participate in and contribute financially to marketing arrangements such as CALM or Ausmeat should, if in the commercial judgment of the Corporation, such schemes appear to be in the interests of the industry.

The Corporation will consist of seven members. There will be an independent chairperson, a Commonwealth Government member and five members selected for their expertise in such matters as pig production, pig meat processing, product from promotion, marketing or appropriate commercial skills. The five members will be selected by an Australian Pork Corporation Selection Committee. This Committee will have four members: An independent chairperson, two members nominated by the Australian Pork Producers Federation and one member nominated by the National Meat Processors Association-the NMPA.

Policy development within the industry is to be strengthened by the formation of an Australian Pig Industry Policy Council. The purpose of the Council will be to inquire into and report to the Minister and the industry about matters affecting the wellbeing of the industry and to develop recommendations and plans for measures to further the interests of the industry. The Council will be made up of an independent chairperson, the President and Senior Vice-President of the Australian Pork Producers Federation, the President of the National Meat Processors Association, the Chairperson of the National Smallgoods Council, the President of the Stockfeed Manufacturers Association of Australia, the Chairperson of the Australian Pork Corporation-the APC-and the Chairperson of the Pig Research Council.

The new arrangements are to be financed from levies collected on pigs slaughtered in Australia for human consumption. There will be no implications for Commonwealth finances arriving from the legislative changes. The legislation governing the operations of the new bodies is in line with the guidelines laid down in the Government's policy statement `Reform of Primary Industry Statutory Marketing Authorities' which I tabled on 20 January 1986.

The accountability of the Corporation has been strengthened by requiring the Corporation to report at least once a year to the executives of the APPF and the NMPA. At such meetings the whole range of APC activities can be discussed. This accountability to industry is in addition to the usual requirement for an annual report to Parliament. The APC is to be responsible for making recommendations to the Minister for Primary Industry on the rate of the pig slaughter levy for the APC. In making such recommendations the Corporation will be required to consult with the APPF and the NMPA and will be required to inform the Minister of the views of those bodies when requesting an increase.

The APC will be required to prepare and submit for approval by the Minister for Primary Industry a three-to-five-year corporate plan setting out its broad objectives for the period and its proposed strategies for achieving those objectives. In addition the APC will be required to prepare an annual operating plan setting out its strategies, programs and proposed resource usage for the year. Again this annual plan will need to be approved by the Minister for Primary Industry.

The sections of this Bill associated with the selection of the members of the APC come into force on the day it receives the royal assent and the rest of the Bill will be proclaimed when the selection process has been completed and the new Corporation is ready to proceed.

In concluding I would like to pay tribute to those members who have served on the Pork Promotion Committee since its inception in 1975. The progress and achievement of the industry to which I referred earlier are, I am sure, in no small measure due to the work of the Committee and the promotional activities it has organised. I commend the Bill to honourable members and present an explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Shack) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill, which is associated with the Pig Industry Bill 1986, is to provide a smooth transfer of functions from the Pork Promotion Committee to the new statutory structure for the pig industry detailed in the Pig Industry Bill 1986.

The arrangements will have no impact on Commonwealth revenue as the Bill provides that costs associated with selection of members for the new Corporation will be met by the Pork Promotion Committee which is financed solely by a levy on pigs slaughtered. I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Shack) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill, which is associated with the Pig Industry Bill 1986, is to provide for the financing of the Australian Pork Corporation. The portion of the pig slaughter levy that, until now, has been paid to the Pork Promotion Committee will, in the future, be paid to the new Corporation.

The Bill also raises from $1 to $1.50 per pig the maximum rate of levy that can be collected for the new Corporation, although it is not intended to increase levies to that level at this time. The Bill has no effect on the operative rate of levy nor does it impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue. I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hurford, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

In his statement on Public Service reforms on 25 September 1986 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) announced the Government's intention to introduce measures to contain the rate of invalidity retirements and associated costs under the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. As part of that initiative this Bill contains provisions which will require invalidity pensioners under the scheme to report any employment. Invalidity pensions will be adjusted where annual earnings exceed a prescribed limit. In addition, the Bill contains a large number of essentially technical provisions intended to update and clarify the operation of the Superannuation Acts 1922 and 1976 and improve the administration of the scheme.

The Commonwealth superannuation scheme is the principal occupational superannuation scheme for Commonwealth sector employees. Of the 74,000 Commonwealth scheme pensioners, 28,000-almost 38 per cent-receive invalidity pensions. Invalidity pensions offer higher benefits than those otherwise obtainable on early age retirement. A survey of Commonwealth scheme invalidity pensioners conducted earlier this year by the Australian Government Retirement Benefits Office and the Australian Bureau of Statistics has indicated that 12.4 per cent of invalidity pensioners under 65 years of age were employed some time during 1985. The average earnings of those employed was $4,540 and the average pension paid to them was $15,200.

In 1.3 per cent of cases, earnings from employment plus pension exceeded the salary the pensioners would have received had they continued in their previous Commonwealth employment. Invalidity pensions payable under the Commonwealth scheme are based on the premise that the recipient is unfit to perform duties. The Government therefore considers it imperative that the invalidity provisions of the scheme should not provide a taxpayer financed supplement to those who engage in employment.

The Bill will amend the provisions of the Superannuation Act 1976 in relation to invalidity pensions payable under that Act and the Superannuation Act 1922 to persons who have not attained 65 years of age. It will require them to provide information to the Commissioner for Superannuation regarding any employment in which they are, or intend to be, engaged during the year. Invalidity pensions payable to such persons will be reduced on a dollar for dollar basis where the aggregate amount of the pension and income from personal exertion exceeds a prescribed limit. In setting that limit the Government will have regard to the position of persons in receipt of low pensions.

Provision is also made for invalidity pensions payable to persons who have not attained age 65 to be cancelled where that pension has been suspended for 12 months because the person failed to provide information on employment or failed to comply with a request to attend a medical examination which would establish whether or not he or she had been restored to health. The Bill provides that a person who became entitled to an invalidity pension on or after attaining his or her minimum retiring age-generally age 55-will have the option to forgo that pension and receive instead the age or early retirement pension which would have been payable if, at the date the person retired on invalidity grounds, he or she had retired on age grounds.

Taken together the new provisions concerning invalidity pension are expected to result in net savings of between $4.2m per annum and $7m per annum, depending on the level of the prescribed limit above which pension reductions will apply. Minimal offsetting costs and savings will result from other measures contained in the Bill, which I will now outline.

Consistent with changes in employment prac- tices since the current Commonwealth scheme was introduced in 1976, the provisions concerning the preservation of superannuation rights are to be changed to enable persons to whom deferred benefits apply under the scheme to have access to those benefits on or after attaining the minimum retiring age-generally 55-that would have applied to them had they not ceased to be contributors. Under the existing provisions, such benefits become payable on or after a person attains age 60. Deferred benefits paid before age 60 will be payable at a reduced rate. The Bill provides for certain regulations under the Superannuation Act 1976 to be made with retrospective effect to enable those regulations to operate as originally intended. These provisions would be purely beneficial in nature and would extend intended rights to persons in certain situations that are presently not provided for in the legislation. In response to a recommendation made by the Auditor-General the Bill adds to the existing auditing provisions contained in the Superannuation Act 1976 so that the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust will be subject to standard auditing provisions applicable to the generality of statutory authorities.

Other provisions contained in the Bill may broadly be described as `housekeeping' changes which have been identified in the 10 years since the current scheme was introduced. These are intended to ensure that the provisions operate in the manner originally intended, to clarify certain provisions and to improve the administration of the scheme. Detailed explanations of each new provision are contained in the explanatory memorandum. Passage of this Bill will complete a major overhaul of legislation relating to the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. It will place the scheme on a more efficient footing enabling it to operate in an equitable and economic manner which has due regard for the legitimate concerns of contributors and taxpayers alike. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tim Fischer) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr John Brown, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
Purpose of the Bill

The purpose of this Bill is to protect the Olympic insignia-that is, the five interlocking rings and the other designs of the Australian Olympic Federation from use by persons not connected with the Olympic movement. The Bill also provides that these insignia shall not be registered under the Designs Act 1906. The Bill invests the Australian Olympic Federation with a monopoly in the insignia and provides that the insignia are not to be used in trade or commerce unless a licence for such use has been granted by the Federation.
Background

The Australian Olympic Federation is established under the charter of the International Olympic Committee-the IOC-in Australia. It is the responsibility of the Federation to promote the Olympic principles in Australia and to co-ordinate the massive effort required to ensure that Australia is effectively represented every four years at both the summer and winter Olympic Games by the best possible team of sports men and women in the country.

It is a task that the Australian Olympic Federation has undertaken for 90 years involving the attendance of Australian teams at every one of the 23 Olympiads. This great distinction is shared by only two other countries, Greece and Great Britain. I would like to point out that this has been achieved despite the horrendous pressure from the previous Government on the Federation and the athletes selected to represent Australia to boycott the 1980 Moscow Olympic Games. Had the previous Government been successful in its endeavours this great distinction would have been lost. Who, in this place, now remembers the nations that did not attend the Moscow Games? Who remembers the nations that boycotted the Los Angeles Games in retaliation, four years later?

The Federation's responsibility has, of course, increased greatly over the period of the modern Olympiads. The size of teams that the Federation has had to prepare has increased greatly. For example, in 1948 in London, Australia was represented by 88 athletes and officials whereas in 1984 in Los Angeles Australia was represented by 335 athletes and officials-a four-fold increase. The performance of Australians at the Olympics has been quite outstanding, given the country's size and resources-right from the first modern Olympiad in 1896 when Edwin Flack won two gold medals, through to the champions in 1984, Glynis Nunn, John Seiben, Dean Lukin and the team pursuit cyclists-Michael Grenda, Kevin Nicholls, Michael Turtur and Dean Woods.

The environment within which the Australian Olympic Federation has to set about its responsibilities has also changed dramatically over the years. The world of sport has become tougher and more competitive. The margin between success and failure is constantly shrinking with the pressures to improve and to win being greater than ever. It is the Federation's task to respond to these pressures in a way which strikes and sustains a balance between the desire to succeed and the no less important values and principles for which sport is rightly renowned. Indeed, it might be said that this is the challenge to Australian sport in 1986 and the years beyond. The Federal Government has been playing its part. We have taken up the challenge to offer more effective support to the sports community as it strives to realise its own high ambitions. Government funding to sport over the past three years has increased substantially.

This Government recognises the important contribution that the Australian Olympic Federation makes to Australian sport. The Federation has on its Board leading persons from all walks of life who are deeply committed to the furthering of all sport in Australia as well as the Olympic sports. The President, Kevan Gosper, is the managing director of the Shell Group of Companies. Phil Coles, a great Australian sportsman, is the Secretary-General. Mr Gosper and Mr Coles are also the Australian representatives on the International Olympic Committee and Mr Gosper only last week was elected to the IOC Executive. These two have taken over from Syd Grange and Judy Patching, who retired at the end of last year, and both of whom, on behalf of the Australian Government and all sports lovers, I would like to thank for their tireless and total commitment over the years in promoting Australia and the Olympic movement. I am sure that Kevan Gosper and Phil Coles will emulate their efforts and ensure the attainment of the Olympic ideals in Australia. Judy Patching is of course continuing his great effort for sport as the Secretary-General of the Oceania Olympic Committee. The Olympic movement is respected world wide and makes an important contribution to the spread of good will and better understanding amongst all nations. It thereby contributes greatly to world harmony and it is fitting that this contribution is recognised, especially in this year of world peace. Anybody who has been to an Olympic Games, and particularly those who have had the pleasure of seeing a closing ceremony, can hardly help but be impressed with the extraordinary show of affection and understanding between athletes of differing political persuasions, colours and creeds as they all join together in this marvellous communion of love for sport. It is my own belief that in many ways the Olympic Games are the greatest vehicle for peace, understanding and harmony in the world.

The Government supports the Federation's endeavours wholeheartedly. It makes a substantial financial contribution to the Federation and considers it to be a blue chip investment in Australia's sporting future. For the 1984 Games the Government provided $1.4m towards the preparation of the Olympic team. This compares with $40,000 provided for the 1960 Rome Games. The total cost of preparing the Australian team for the 1984 Games was $5m and the Australian Olympic Federation was responsible for raising the balance of these funds. It did so through a range of marketing programs which involved the use of its various insignia. I note in passing that there was some criticism of the Government for providing in 1984 $1.4m of public funds to the Olympic Games team. I can remember suggesting at the time to a critic that the contribution was 10c per head of population for four years, which is 2 1/2c per head of population per year-a pretty small charge to be levied on the public considering the enormous pride we felt from the involvement and certainly the success of our athletes at the 1984 Games.

With the escalating cost of participating in Olympic Games the Australian Olympic Federation must ensure a continuing flow of funds. To do this it has embarked on a major marketing program based on the licensing and franchising of the Olympic insignia. This campaign has proved very successful, with exclusive rights being granted to some 66 products of major international and national companies. This campaign will provide an ongoing and major source of funds and will help to ensure that Australia is represented in a fitting and proper way.

It may be seen as a measure of the success of the Australian Olympic Federation's marketing program that it has encountered problems with unscrupulous persons whose use of the Olympic insignia suggests, deceptively, to the public that they, or their products, are associated with and help fund the Olympic movement. Given the Government's support for the Australian Olympic Federation, and the Federation's responsible efforts to ensure its own financial independence, such unauthorised and deceptive use must be prevented. The Government has decided that, as with the `Advance Australia' logo and the bicentennial logo, legislation is necessary to aid in securing the rights of the Federation to its insignia and to prevent them from being used in a deceptive manner. It will also ensure that, if they are used deceptively the federation has a speedy and simple mechanism available to curtail such conduct. This is the purpose of this Bill. The ability to ensure exclusivity of use is also a matter of critical importance for the Federation when negotiating the best terms for its licensing agreements.

I add that this protection is not without precedent in Australia. Prior to the 1956 Games held in Melbourne the government of the day brought in legislation prescribing the Olympic rings, the Olympic motto and the words `Olympic Champion' as prohibited trade marks. That is, they could not be registered under the Trade Marks Act 1955. That, however, does not prevent persons using them as unregistered marks and in these commercial times, when sponsorship plays such an important role, greater protection is required.

This certainly would have been the case with Brisbane had its bid for the 1992 Olympic Games been successful. Regrettably, it was not. Nevertheless, the Brisbane City Council and in particular the Lord Mayor, Alderman Sallyanne Atkinson, together with the Olympic Project Office under the control of John Coates, must be commended for their tremendous endeavours to win the Games for Australia. They showed real confidence in the ability of Brisbane and Australia to take on such a mammoth task. They were also well aware of the really significant benefits through tourism and increased employment which major sporting events such as the Olympics bring to both the national and local economies.

I note in passing that being a part of that Brisbane bid was one of the more enjoyable experiences of my life. I was a very proud Australian to stand before the Olympic Committee in Lausanne and be a small part of that effort, across the political borders of the State Government in Queensland, the Commonwealth Government in Canberra and the Brisbane City Council, all of differing political colours, together with an enormous amount of support from a whole range of private and public companies and seven of our former Olympic champions-Michael Wenden, Michelle Ford, Bill Hoffmann from the 1956 Games, John Konrads, Herb Elliott, Kevan Gosper and Phillip Coles-to present, on behalf of Brisbane and Australia, a very convincing case. I say without prejudice that the Brisbane bid was certainly the best. The only thing that defeated us was the politics of the International Olympic Committee. It decided that the Games should go back to Europe, and unfortunately that was the case. It certainly was a very proud moment for me. Anybody who has an opportunity to see the video that was put together by Brisbane for that bid, featuring a choir of Australian kids, would I am sure be very proud and would understand what a good case we put for Australia on the international market. It is a pity that there are critics of that bid. I have noticed in recent days some criticism in the Press that had the Games been secured for Brisbane they would have been a financial disaster. I can assure the critics that that would not have been the case. The economic study that was done for the Brisbane Games was very convincing and very positive. There is no possibility that the Games could not have succeeded, despite criticism to the contrary. The time slot for television coverage in the United States of America would have been absolutely perfect. Finals run in the morning in Brisbane would have been shown on television in the United States at peak viewing time, and the United States is where the big television money is. Australia was better placed than any country to guarantee the security, the safety and the peace of every visiting athlete and every visitor to the Games. It is a pity that the great Australian sport of knocking always takes over when Australia attempts to do something great.
Major Features of the Bill

The Bill provides that the Australian Olympic Federation has a monopoly in design in Australia with respect to the Olympic rings, thus ensuring its rights to use the rings in relation to any article. The Bill also provides that the Australian Olympic Federation has ownership of the copyright in the Olympic rings. These provisions will not, of course, impede the fair use of the rings for the purposes of disseminating information on the Olympic movement or its activities by the media.

The Bill makes provision for the Australian Olympic Federation to grant licences to use the insignia in return for a payment or other consideration. The Australian Olympic Federation is a voluntary organisation whose purpose is to promote Olympic sport in Australia. The Bill provides speedy and effective mechanisms to ensure the Australian Olympic Federation is not in a situation where it must devote scarce resources, through common law actions, to protect its rights. The Australian Olympic Federation, or the holder of a licence in relation to the insignia whose interests are affected, may bring action against an unauthorised user of the insignia. The remedies available to the Federation include injunctions, damages and accounts of profits.

It is recognised that some persons use the Olympic rings in conjunction with their goods and have done so for a considerable period. These persons have never held themselves out as being connected with the Olympic movement and do not increase their activity in Olympic years when the Australian Olympic Federation's fund raising campaign is at its peak. The rights of these persons to use the insignia are recognised and the Bill expressly preserves existing property rights in the insignia.

The Australian Olympic Federation does not restrict its campaign to the Olympic rings. The Federation has developed a range of logos for which it grants licences. Honourable members would be familiar with Willy the Koala. I have it on good authority that Willy, unlike some of his cousins, is very well behaved in public! In addition to Willy, these logos include the Olympic rings and boomerangs and the Olympic rings and kangaroo.

The Bill has provision for these logos to be registered as Olympic designs. Registration provides similar protection to that provided for the use of the Olympic rings. It also provides similar remedies for their unauthorised use. As these designs may change over time, registration for each logo will be for a period of 12 years, after which registration may be renewed. The maximum number of designs that may be registered at any one time will be restricted to 10. This will ensure that when the Australian Olympic Federation no longer has a use for a logo it will pass into the public domain. It also minimises the administrative costs associated with the process of registration.

In terms of financial impact I would like to assure honourable members that the ongoing financial cost to the Government of administering this legislation will be minimal. My own Department will have no on going administrative costs. The Office of Patents, Trade Marks and Designs will incur costs associated with the registration of Olympic designs. However, given that the Australian Olympic Federation is the only eligible applicant, and that a maximum of 10 designs only will be registered at any one time, the administrative costs will be minimal and, in any case, will be offset by the payment of an appropriate fee for each registration. This fee is currently set at $65. This is the same as the amount charged for design registrations under the Designs Act 1906.

The Government firmly believes that the measures provided for in this Bill will greatly assist the Australian Olympic Federation in ensuring that it is able to field the best possible teams in Seoul and Calgary in 1988 and in subsequent Olympics. It is likely that the increased security of the Olympic designs will improve the Federation's capacity to raise funds from its marketing program and consequently reduce its call on Commonwealth financial assistance. I commend this Bill to the House and table the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tim Fischer) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: NURSING HOMES AND HOSTELS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in the day I began speaking on the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 and had reached the point where I wanted to focus attention on the position of the patients in nursing homes. In Australia today there is a large number of nursing homes to cater for that group in the population who need nursing home care. In the main they are people who are in excess of 70 years of age. In many nursing homes the population exceed 80 years of age. So they are very old people, people who are frail, people who are very much in the evening of their lives. Some may ask whether they should be supported by their families. We need to recognise that their families, in many instances, are pensioners themselves because they are of the age of 60 or 65 and facing all the difficulties that confront people as they move from income that comes from participation in the work force to the limited income available to many people in our retired community.

SPEECH.PARA: The participating nursing homes are privately operated, operated for profit, but they are very much controlled by the Commonwealth administration. Because of the high cost of providing nursing care, the Commonwealth over the years has provided support to patients in nursing homes. At present it costs, in round figures, $400 a week to maintain a patient in a nursing home. The practice of the Commonwealth has been to adjust the nursing home benefit to take account of rising nursing home costs. As the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) pointed out in his second reading speech, over the last 10 or so years the rate of increase in nursing home costs has far outstripped the ordinary consumer price index increase. Wages in nursing homes-and sometimes the standards of nursing home care-have been set higher by State governments, and therefore the costs have increased at a very rapid rate. Had there not been Commonwealth income-type support for the patients in nursing homes, many people would not have been able to afford to enter those nursing homes.

The practice has been for the Commonwealth each November to set nursing home benefits applicable to each State at a level that would ensure that, within each State, 70 per cent of the beds in participating nursing homes would be available to pensioners who had no other income. The formula applied was to set a standard fee that the patient would have to pay. It was set at 87.5 per cent of the pension plus the rent allowance, the belief being-it was a proper belief-that anyone, even a nursing home patient, should be left with some discretionary income to purchase the necessary personal requisites one needs, even if one is a patient in a nursing home.

Over the years, pension adjustments have been made in November and sometimes they have been made in May and November, but now we are changing the dates for that. As a result of those adjustments the patients have had to pay an increased amount so that they continue to pay 87.5 per cent of their pension. More significantly, the problem has arisen that during the year the costs of operating nursing homes have varied. Homes have made application to the Government fee fixing bodies and have been allowed to increase their fees, so that, after a 12 month period, instead of there being 70 per cent of the nursing home beds available at a figure that pensioners could afford the percentage so available would be substantially reduced.

The Opposition is suggesting that the whole question should be examined to ensure that fee increases, pension increases and benefit increases are synchronised in a way that provides to the patients of nursing homes the ability to predict the sort of liability that will confront them. That would be easy if that were true in all parts of Australia, but unfortunately that is not so. The Government has frozen the amount of the nursing home benefits paid to certain States, notably the States of South Australia and Victoria. True though it may be that the fees payable in Victoria and South Australia are higher because the State governments have set higher standards of nursing care, and sometimes higher standards of accommodation, the Government has utterly failed the patients in nursing homes because it has failed to negotiate with the State governments to ensure that the State governments either relax their requirements and their conditions or, alternatively, put in the money to enable the patients in nursing homes to afford to pay the fees.

In South Australia nursing home fees have gone up by 10 per cent but the bill received by patients in nursing homes has gone up by 40 per cent because in the past the Commonwealth was paying three-quarters of the increased costs and the patient was paying one-quarter. Now the patient in South Australia is being required to pay 100 per cent of every increase in costs. So there has been a dramatic drop in the percentage of beds available for pensioners at a fee they can afford. Instead of 70 per cent of beds being available as they were some 18 months or two years ago the number in South Australia has dropped to 36 per cent and will continue to fall.

No one knows when this situation will be improved because the Minister has not said whether New South Wales or Queensland benefits are to be used as the yardstick. Will South Australian nursing home patients have to pay another $36 a week before they get any relief from the Commonwealth Government or will it be $60 a week before they get any relief? The great majority of these patients do not have the resources to do so, so they and their families are worried about how they will meet the costs of nursing home care. The great majority of patients have no alternative but to be in nursing homes. They have been properly assessed as being nursing home patients. My final point is that I am concerned that under the report that the Government is examining it will apply a similar type of fee structure to deficit funded nursing homes. Am I to say to patients in the deficit funded nursing homes within my electorate that they too will be faced with the same financial problems that confront those in privately operated nursing homes? If they cannot afford to pay the extra fees where are they to go?

The Minister should do what his report recommended. He should talk with the South Australian Government and make sure that there is proper co-operation between Commonwealth, and its funding of nursing home patients, and the State and its requirement for the standards that it sets for nurse-patient ratios and other features that make the cost of operating nursing homes in South Australia higher than those elsewhere. Nursing home patients in South Australia are in a desperate condition. Their plight needs to be carefully examined. They should be funded to a level that ensures that 70 per cent of the beds are available at an amount that they can afford.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The community services aspects of this year's Budget have been well received. The Australian Council of Social Service in its Budget briefing notes said that the Government:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . has maintained its commitment to significantly improve services for the aged and for people with disabilities.
Of particular importance is the commitment to increased funding for hostels and home and community care to prevent unnecessary placing of elderly people in nursing homes.

The Budget allocates $23.9m as part of a three-year strategy to implement matters arising from the Nursing Homes and Hostels Review. Of this amount $13.5m is to be used for capital funds to strengthen the hostel sector. Hostel care subsidies will rise by 19.3 per cent. The aim is to fund a strategy to restructure and improve residential and community care services for aged people through a shift to hostel based services. The honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) would not be aware-but would be glad-that the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) announced today that the benefits freeze in Victoria and South Australia for nursing home benefits is to be lifted. In Victoria, the new benefits will be increased to $53.60 a day, an increase of $5.10 a day or $35.70 a week. In South Australia and the Northern Territory, where the freeze has been in place, the benefit will be $45.05 a day, an increase of $3, from 13 November.

The matters to be discussed in the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill arise out of a series of inquiries into nursing home administration. The first of these inquiries was back in 1981-an efficiency audit by the Auditor-General. This was followed by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure report-the McLeay report-and the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes report-the Giles report. Prominent in these reports was the criticism that government intervention was largely unplanned, ad hoc and unco-ordinated. As a result, the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) instigated a review. In April the report of the Nursing Homes and Hostels Review was tabled in the Senate. It indicated that a disproportionate number of beds were allocated by regions and States; there was too great an emphasis on nursing homes; and there was inadequate support for hostels. The Review recommended that there should be a correction of the imbalance and that there should be new controls to organise the growth of the nursing home and hostel sector. This is in line with the Government's overall strategy in aged care to move away from institutionalised care and to encourage home and community care, to enable the elderly of the community to have a more independent style of living.

After extensive consultations with State governments, the nursing home industry, consumers, welfare groups and professionals working in the field, the Government has decided upon a strategy. It is of interest to note that in the report of the migration committee of the National Population Council entitled `Greying Australia: Future Impacts of Population Ageing', a report which aims to encourage discussion and promote an awareness of the issues associated with ageing in the society, the following comment in made:

There is no advocate with the political clout to compete with the nursing home industry. Unless the political will can be mobilised to improve services, there will be more misuse of expensive institutional care in dealing with non-critical patients, inadequate care of older people at home, and continuing heavy burdens on daughters and other carers.

This legislation in part deals with and tries to redress some of those imbalances. Also, we should recognise the other aspects of the Government's strategy in providing adequate aged care. I was interested in the recent announcement of subsidies for geriatric assessment units. One which was founded was the Bundoora geriatric assessment team in Bundoora. It works at the Bundoora Extended Care Centre and covers municipalities in the north-east region of Melbourne. It is to get funding of up to $223,000. It is an important part of the program because there is a need to assess properly the type of accommodation that our elderly need. As the Minister said in his second reading speech, perhaps up to 25 per cent of placements in nursing homes are inappropriate. The people who are placed there perhaps do not need that type of care. Another aspect is put very succinctly by the review report. It states:

Elderly and sick people are not in a position to make realistic choices between nursing homes on the basis of the best standard of care commensurate with their capacity and willingness to pay. Experience suggests that if beds are available they are likely to be filled, thus generating pressures on the Commonwealth to extend the availability of benefits. The focus should be on the provision of alternatives to nursing home care rather than on stimulating competition within the one sector through increasing the supply of beds.

The review proposes that there should be a national ratio of 100 hostel places and nursing home beds per 100 persons aged 70 years or over. The review arrived at that ratio because it approximates the present situation. The report indicates that the Australia-wide ratio is 103.8 hostel and nursing home places per 1,000 persons over 70 years of age. The figures are interesting. They indicate disproportionate coverage in different States. In Western Australia there is a high of 117.7 places per 1,000 persons and in Victoria a low of 84.1 places. The Government's strategy is to try to redress that sort of imbalance. There are not only imbalances between States. There are also regional imbalances within States. Another aspect highlighted by the review is the way the different kinds of nursing homes are spread according to the socio-economic status of the areas where services are provided. The review states:
Government, deficit-financed and participating non-profit homes predominate in low socio-economic areas.

The mention of deficit-financed homes brings me to acknowledge something I noticed while researching for this debate when I looked at the Nursing Homes Assistance Bill 1974. This point relates to the honourable member who preceded me, the honourable member for Sturt, who I note also participated in debate on that Bill. The honourable member for Petrie (Mr Hodges), who follows me, might also have been a participant in that debate. As this legislation has a great deal of bipartisan support, I should acknowledge their continuing interest in nursing homes and, in particular, the care of elderly Australians. I return to the report. It also indicates:
there are considerably more participating-for-profit homes in high status areas.

This is an unfortunate aspect. We tend to move away from equity unless we intervene and provide services in areas in which entrepreneurs decide not to participate. The Government's response to the review was arrived at after considerable consultation. It includes a five-point thrust, which was outlined by the Minister in his second reading speech. The honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) outlined it again, earlier in the debate. I refer to the third point, which is the extension of residential care services beyond hostels to other forms of accommodation, such as group housing arrangements. A particular type of group housing arrangement of which I have recently become aware is the Abbeyfield concept. I was very pleased to launch recently, on behalf of the Broadmeadows branch of the Abbeyfield society, a study of the aged residential accommodation available in the Broadmeadows municipality. I congratulate the society and also the Rotary Club of Broadmeadows which sponsored the study.

That study of the needs in a suburb in my electorate indicated that there was clearly a lack of most types of aged accommodation. There is in the municipality only one hostel, which has an extremely high demand and a waiting list which is closed. All the nursing homes in the area are full and have long waiting lists. The study indicated that the Abbeyfield concept, which commenced in the United Kingdom and which allows for independent group living within a house with a housekeeper, is one alternative that perhaps we could look at. It provides the range of services, the alternatives and choices that our elderly should be given. Recently, the Minister for Community Services opened an Abbeyfield house in Malvern which receives funding under the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act. Perhaps that home can serve as a model for other Abbeyfield houses.

This legislation proposes that we move away from the ad hoc way in which areas for nursing homes have been selected. It highlights the necessity for a needs-based planning approach. It provides for a change in the existing balance between providing intensive care through nursing homes and providing appropriate community services and hostel options. I was a little disappointed when the honourable member for Richmond indicated that the Government might be rushing into this area and that there might be some cause for concern for people in nursing homes at present. As the Minister indicated in his second reading speech, these changes will be implemented gradually. There is an acknowledgment by the Government that there is a need to be sensitive to those people because of their fears that they will suddenly be turfed out of their nursing homes or have their form of accommodation changed.

The legislation implements the Government's intention to ensure greater flexibility in arranging programs for special groups. The special group I would like to highlight is migrants. Honourable members would perhaps know that there is a high ethnic population in the electorate of Scullin. There is a need for accommodation services which acknowledge the special needs of this group. This legislation will introduce a flexibility which will allow disadvantaged groups to get 100 per cent capital funding for new proposals. Inflexibility in this area was a drawback in times past.

The Victorian Ethnic Affairs Commission, in a discussion paper it put out entitled `Ethnic Aged Policies', indicates general principles which perhaps need to be applied when putting ethnic services into place. I would like to go through them and highlight one principle, in particular, because I think it is of importance in the provision of nursing homes or hostels for ethnic communities. The general principles were: Equity, access, cultural relevance, locality, participation-that is, participation of ethnic communities in the planning and delivery of services for them-integration, complementary services, choice and dignity. I would like to highlight the notion of complementary services. The discussion paper says of these services:
A combination of adequately supported and integrated ethno-specific services and universally accessible general service is desirable.

When I was discussing this problem with a geriatric physician at the Bundoora extended care centre, he indicated that the problem we will have in putting into place ethno-specific nursing homes or hostels is that the overall population of individual ethnic groups will perhaps not be large enough for us to be able to give them nursing homes of their own. One of things they are trying to come to grips with at his geriatric hospitals is the recruitment of suitably qualified people who are multilingual. That is only one aspect of it because not only is the language a problem but also there are different cultural problems which are reflected in the types of meals these people require and other aspects. There is a need for these things to be considered because of the problem of not having populations of sufficient size within these communities to justify ethno-specific services. I am sure that, with the special attention that is being given to the provision of aged services for the migrant elderly, those aspects will be given particular attention.

In conclusion, I think that this Bill, as part of an overall strategy that tries to encourage a more community based thrust to aged care, is an indication of what might be termed the quiet revolution that has occurred in aged care over the last three years under this Labor Government. I think it is important to note that strategy, because the honourable member for Sturt talked about the changing needs of the elderly and how this Government had chopped and changed its policies. I suggest that it is a matter of perception. We need to put into place, through a co-ordinated plan, the type of services that best represents and helps to give the elderly of Australia an independent way of living.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 I wish to highlight some real concerns affecting the industry as a whole and, more importantly, affecting patients not only now but also in the not too distant future. In considering this legislation, which deals with the provision of nursing home and hostel beds, one must take account of the whole range of services that are being provided for the elderly and disabled in this country. In its total spectrum it goes from pensioner units, which are usually provided by State governments, to unit and townhouse type developments where private enterprise has been rather vigorous in the past three or four years, through to the home and community care program-the HACC program, as it is known-which is designed to keep the elderly in their homes.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) made some reference to the move away from institutionalised care to keeping people in their own home environment. I support that concept completely. One then moves to nursing homes and hostels, whether they are operated by religious or charitable organisations or, in the case of nursing homes, by private enterprise. One has to take in the total area of the care of the aged and the disabled in this debate.

My main concern in this debate is to point out what I believe is a head in the sand approach by the Government to the problems of the elderly in respect of the provision of nursing homes. In effect, the Government is saying that, with an increased emphasis on the home and community care program-that is, the provision of services within the home, whether they are home nursing services, meals on wheels or whatever-there is going to be a lesser need for hostel and nursing home beds and that, as a result of this legislation and the Government's current move towards the provision of a greater number of hostel beds, the need for nursing home beds will diminish. I just flag this as a problem in the not too distant future. Maybe three, four or five years hence we will find that a bottleneck develops. I think this has to be considered very carefully by the Government.

I recognise that we have a very high proportion of nursing home beds per thousand of population for people aged 65 or 70 years and over, but there is this quaint view that with the HACC program and more hostel beds we will need fewer nursing home beds. I am not convinced that that is the case. Let us look at the cost of the provision of a nursing home bed. A very large proportion of elderly people, whether they are in their home environment, a single-unit dwelling, a townhouse or unit-type accommodation or, indeed, in a hostel bed, are going to require a nursing home bed or perhaps even a hospital bed. In round figures, it costs about $50 a day to keep a patient in a nursing home bed. If that patient is moved into a hospital bed, the cost rockets to between $180 and perhaps even $250, depending on the part of Australia in which the patient lives and the type of hospital accommodation. There is a vast difference in the cost of keeping a patient in a nursing home bed and in a hospital bed. It may well be that if there is an inadequate number of nursing home beds many of those people will finish up in the more costly hospital bed accommodation.

I want to refer to a couple of examples of nursing homes and hostels within my own electorate. I do have among my constituents a fairly large number of elderly people and, like most honourable members, I have in my electorate some nursing homes and hostels. The Uniting Church in Australia, operates one establishment with a total unit accommodation-hostel and nursing home beds-of almost 600 people. Another establishment has 65 nursing home beds and 64 hostel beds. In the nursing home with 65 beds, in the city of Redcliffe, 63 of those beds are for extensive care patients. I think that is a fair illustration to the Government that when a nursing home has 65 beds and 63 of them are extensive care, we have to be extremely careful that we do not finish up with that bottleneck that I talked about, with an inadequate number of nursing home beds for an aging population.

About half of the patients in the hostel which has 64 beds are personal care subsidy residents. Again the emphasis, I know, has moved towards caring for the frail aged in hostel accommodation. I do not necessarily disagree with that, but we have to be careful, given the number of frail aged being looked after in hostel accommodation, that we do not find ourselves with more of those people wanting to get or needing nursing home accommodation but with beds not being available.

I turn to a couple of the private nursing homes within my electorate. One at Scarborough has 30 patients and 27 of those patients, or about 90 per cent of the total, are extensive care patients. The other three are ordinary-care patients. In the Redcliffe nursing home, another privately owned home within my electorate, 40 out of the 63 patients-about 60 per cent-are extensive care patients. I would dearly like to take the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) to my electorate. Indeed, he could take the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) there. The only problem is, of course, that between now and the Queensland election, I do not think any Ministers of this Government will be welcome in Queensland. Certainly, the Prime Minister is not. Perhaps the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) could hold them by the hand as they went around my electorate. He appears to be accepted in Queensland. I would dearly like the Minister for Social Security, who is in the House and who has a deal of compassion for these people, to visit my electorate. Unfortunately, he is not allowed to fulfil a lot of his desires because of the economic mess in which the Government has the nation at the moment. I say that with all the compassion I can muster because I believe that he does have a feel for these people, who are less fortunate than we are.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly with the CPI today.

—As the honourable member for Farrer reminds me, with the consumer price index increase now running at an annual rate of about 9 per cent with the 2.6 per cent rise announced today, the difficulty for pensioners in nursing homes and hostels will be in finding sufficient excess money, in addition to what they are paying out for their accommodation, to buy the niceties of life most of us accept as a part of our lives without too much thought.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to Garden Settlement, a complex of the Uniting Church in Australia. It has almost 600 residents. There are 193 nursing home beds, with 100 of them-more than 50 per cent-for extensive care. Of the total of 336 hostel beds, about 15 per cent receive the personal care subsidy. I pay tribute also to the operations of private enterprise people and to the Hibernian-Australasian Catholic Benefits Society, which has been developing for a number of years a complex for residents with a bell to provide after hours service for those who get themselves into trouble. It is an excellent operation called Ballycara, which is in my electorate. There is also a private enterprise operation known as Peninsula Terraces, which has privately owned units basically for people between 50 and 80 years of age. It also provides an on site caretaker type of person who looks after the needs of those who get into trouble.

I return to the difficulty and the danger I see for the Government in what it is doing in relation to expenditure in this area on new beds. I know the reason that the Government wants to curtail the amount of expenditure in this area. It is not so much the capital cost. I think in this financial year it is planning to spend about $56m on new hostel and nursing home beds. In 1985-86 a lesser number of beds was built than in 1984-85. It is not the capital cost that is the worry. The Minister for Social Security, who is at the table, knows only too well that the problem is the recurrent cost of the beds once they are in place. Something like $1.1 billion is to be spent in this financial year for recurrent costs by way of subsidies to the wide range of people who are operating nursing home and hostel accommodation. I accept that that is a major concern for the Government. I turn to the Estimates committee hearings of the Senate which have just been completed. Senator Walters asked:
How many new nursing homes are in the pipeline? Are there any? What is the figure?
Mr Campbell replied:
We have just over 4,000 outstanding approvals in principle.

That is the number of beds approved in principle; but when one examines Budget Paper No. 1 1986-87 one notes an increase of about 400 beds, from 56,500 to 56,900, in 1985-86. In the case of the deficit financing arrangements, there is an increase of about 500 to a total of 19,500; that is, about 900 beds in one year. I have a feeling that with 4,000 outstanding approvals in principle and fewer than 1,000 beds being constructed-that is, right across the nation-in any one financial year we will fall rapidly behind the tens of thousands of people, in the not too distant future, who will want nursing home beds and will not be able to get them. Why would we approve 4,000 beds in principle when in fact we are building fewer than 1,000 annually?

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government has no compassion.

—As the honourable member for Denison said, this Government has no compassion. I think individual Ministers in some instances do. The Government could have had more compassion had it not got the country into the economic mess that it has. The Minister ought to take note of what will happen to pensioner patients in nursing homes because the correspondence and complaints are flying thick and fast on this issue. They will continue to do so, particularly to Government back benchers. Government back benchers with marginal seats had better watch out. I spoke to a proprietor of one of the deficit funded nursing homes today and asked about drugs. He said: `I am terribly concerned about 1 November because many of these patients take considerable quantities of analgesics-paracetamol, aspirin-and preparations such as cough suppressants and expectorants'. It will cost them up to $5 a week extra if they are to continue to get what I call first line treatment drugs. It is possible they may have prescribed for them drugs that will be less satisfactory but which will be prescribed because they are free. They will have more side effects. This particular nursing home proprietor raised this issue with me. There is no logic in the Government keeping on the list a number of preparations which we term extemporaneously prepared preparations, in terms of the logic the Government has applied to the deletion of 45 ready-made preparations. It may as well delete those as well. The Government should be warned about nursing home patients in particular because those patients or their relatives or friends will have to find a considerable amount of money for drugs that the patients consume to keep them in what one might term a more normal state. These drugs are often called comfort drugs but they are essential to those people.
—Pain killers.

—As the honourable member for Denison said, in many instances they are pain killers. Other drugs are taken to relieve the symptoms of coughs and colds. This Government is deleting them from the list from 1 November and it ought to be ashamed of that action. Nursing home patients in particular will have great difficulty in finding the extra money and it will fall to their relatives or friends to provide those drugs or the patients will not have the treatment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before going on with my comments on the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill I would like to make some remarks arising out of the comments of the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Hodges). If what he said is correct, I can understand the grave concern in the community. I followed up the issue and I spoke to a senior person tied up with the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. I was informed that there are nine members on that Committee. Six of those members are appointed by or are delegates or representatives of the Australian Medical Association; one is a pharmacologist; one represents the Pharmacy Guild; and one is a Government appointee. The nine voted unanimously for the change in the pharmaceutical benefits list.
—They are all there at the pleasure of the Government.

—That is not what I am told. Moreover, I have been told that the changes that come into force on 1 November have been put forward because of a need to ensure that abuse and misuse of certain drugs does not-
—Rubbish!

—Let me continue. The honourable member had his go. I want to give him some credit for raising the issue because it is a matter of concern in the community. I think the facts ought to be known. Another factor is cost.
—Now you are talking about-

—We are talking about general costs. It has been pointed out to me that when a pensioner goes to a doctor to get what could be aspirin-although I imagine he would get most of those things while seeing the doctor for another reason, but many times he goes to see the doctor for some drug-that costs the taxpayer $12.50. When he gets the prescription filled at a chemist it costs the taxpayer another $2.50. So drugs that can be purchased over the counter at Woolworths or other places for $2 can cost not this Government, not the Hawke Government, not the Labor Party, but the people of Australia $15. Surely that must exercise the minds of all honourable members concerned about efficiency, waste and the delivery of Government health services.

SPEECH.PARA: If what the honourable member for Petrie has said is correct I will follow this up as well, but I do not believe that is what it is about. When I asked, I was told that there were two aspirin type drugs left on the list and they were the ones that the aged needed for arthritic complaints and so on. That has been verified. I think we need to follow this up further. Maybe we ought to speak to the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) at a later time. But let us be sure that this has been done because of recommendations from a body that is non-political. A body made up of doctors--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a money saving measure. You know that.

—No, it is not. I do not believe that is true. It is a group of six doctors from the Australian Medical Association. I am also told that recommendations have been forthcoming to this Government-and to previous governments-for review and changes. In many cases drugs that have been taken off the list have been replaced by more expensive drugs. That was admitted recently at a pensioners meeting in Rockhampton. The head of the Mount Morgan Pensioners League said that the drug he would normally use was no longer available but he could get another one that was more expensive. I suggest to the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) that money saving is not necessarily the issue. It could well be a question of efficiency. But let us come back to the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: In April this year the Minister for Community Services, Senator Don Grimes, tabled in the Senate the results of a major review into nursing homes and hostels that was carried out by his Department. I am sure that this created a lot of interest from all members and that most members read it. That report put forward a number of very important objectives which I believe are of paramount importance. I believe this Government has given special weight to these measures and objectives in the Bill that is before the House.

I refer to four basic goals that were set out in this review: The first was that aged and disabled people should, as far as possible, be supported in their own homes, in their own communities. I suggest that few honourable members would disagree with that proposition. The second goal was that aged and disabled people should be supported by residential services only where other support systems are not appropriate to meet their needs. In other words, the aged should not just be put in a nursing home, as has been the case so many times in the past. The third goal was that services should be provided in an atmosphere and using processes which promote, as far as possible, rehabilitation and restoration of function and that the manner in which services are provided should develop and enhance personal freedom and independent functioning of all residents. The fourth goal was that services should be based on a recognition that, for many people, discharge to a residential service providing a less intensive form of care or to a community based support service would be a possible and desirable outcome. These four goals have been adopted by the Government. I hope they will be supported by all members of the Parliament who have taken an interest in the nursing home issue in their electorates.

This legislation will allow for a more flexible and a more integrated planning approach to the provision of residential services and a better resourced hostel sector. There has certainly been a need for change. I think that need has been recognised, certainly amongst those who are involved in the care of the aged. But the point that I ask the Minister to take on board-and also Senator Don Grimes-is that that need must be explained over and over again to the people. There is still an attitude that when a relative, be it one's mother or father, is too old to care for herself or himself, the only alternative is to put that person in a nursing home. That is an attitude that has prevailed. I believe that this Government has a different approach. I believe that many members of the Opposition who have spoken in this debate and with whom I have discussed the matter understand that this is not the desirable approach and that we need to change it.
