Whilst we are doing that by way of this Bill-and the Budget is heading down that track-there are still people who have this attitude, and it must be changed.

We all appreciate that during the last decade there has been enormous growth in the nursing home industry. Private enterprise has grasped what it sees as a very profitable arena. It has entered that arena, most regrettably for many relatives. I know of cases in which people have paid, and are still paying, about $50 per week just to keep an aged relative in a privately run nursing home. We need to stress to relatives of aged people that there is an alternative. We need to educate them as to the range of care options which are available, or which should be available. I take the point about the backlog mentioned by the honourable member for Petrie, and I will also mention that matter.

Australia, like all Western countries-and, I suggest, also many Eastern bloc countries-faces an aging population problem. We have an enormous growth projection. Recently I attended a Blue Nursing Service meeting in my electorate. Some figures provided to me show that, at the moment, there is one aged person to about every five working people, but by the year 2020 or 2025 that ratio will drop to one aged person to only two working people. The question arises: How do we continue to pay for aged care? It is no wonder that this Government has embarked upon a national superannuation scheme so that we all contribute towards our retirement, because the pension burden will be massive. The capital cost of providing residential care will be unbelievable unless we address the problem. This is why I believe this Government has rightly adopted a new approach, a new strategy, on aged accommodation. Honourable members who listened to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) introduce this measure the other day will realise that this Government has embarked on a three-year plan. During this period we intend to accelerate the growth of those new services-the alternative care options. Also, we will limit the growth in the number of nursing home beds.

This Government has recognised the need to enable people to stay in their own homes much longer. They should have options rather than that of moving into nursing homes. I applaud the care that has been given, and is being given, in nursing homes by so many concerned and sensitive people, but it occurs to me that many of the people who are in those homes should not be there. Somewhere down the track the assessment system has broken down. Earlier I made a point about an option. If a discharge took place, in most instances that discharge would be to the benefit of the resident.

This measure will allow for a reallocation of government funding. Again, some information has been provided to me which shows that the people of Australia are spending 90 per cent of aged care funding on 10 per cent of the aged-that is, the 10 per cent who live in nursing homes. We spend only about 10 per cent on the other 90 per cent in the community. There must be a reallocation, a restructuring of funding. That will take place. The Bill before the House will ensure a redirection of our financial resources and, I would hope, save some money, because there is certainly a huge burden on the taxpayer. I am not sure whether much of it is spent wisely.

I take the point that the honourable member for Petrie has raised, because it is a matter of introducing things gradually. There is a plan and a strategy, but we must make sure that the people who are already in the homes are not affected. I note that the Minister stated in particular that what is being proposed in this Bill will not hurt those who are already in these homes. But we do not want to cause a backlog. Already there are applicants who cannot get into nursing homes, and as we cut down and limit the growth in the number of nursing home beds they will not be able to go anywhere else-unless, of course, there is funding, in real money terms for hostels.

This Government is increasing hostel funding. It is increasing the hostel care subsidy. If one looks at the figures that are available, one will note that there is a significant increase in hostel places. In 1986-87 there will be 2,750 new hostel and nursing home places. In 1987-88 there will be 4,730 new hostel and nursing home places. In the following year there will be 5,400 new places. That means that, in the three-year period under this strategy, there will be 12,880 new hostel and nursing home places. But the important statistic is that, of the 12,880 places, 11,585 will be hostel places. So there will be a reallocation, a redirection. This will lead to a growth of some 30 per cent in hostel places. In my State of Queensland this year there will be 60 new nursing home places, but 370 hostel places will be created. In 1987-88 60 new nursing home places will still be created, but there will be 510 hostel places. In the final year of the strategy there will still be 60 new nursing home places, but there will be 740 hostel places. So of a total 1,800 places, there will be 1,620 hostel places.

I believe that we are putting this policy into place in a very realistic and proper manner. It will never be enough-we know that. Members constantly get constituents contacting them and saying: `My mother is old. She cannot stay in her home any more'-this applies especially to Queensland houses that are high and, as often said by southerners, on stilts-`she can no longer negotiate the steps which she has already fallen down and she must get out of that home'. However, that does not mean that she must go into a nursing home. I am most pleased with what the Government is doing in this area. We are tackling a very serious problem and we have not tackled it too soon because the problem, as I said earlier, will accelerate upon us. If something is not done urgently and quickly, we will have a crisis situation developing.

I also ask the Minister to take on board the need for people to be able to stay in their communities. Those of us who represent country and provincial city areas find too often that people have to move from their small townships to go into the cities. People throughout my electorate, who have lived there for 60 and 70 years in some instances, have to wipe out all their friendships, break down all the arrangements that they have had, and live somewhere in Rockhampton, Mackay or Brisbane. We must ensure that hostel places are available in country areas as well and that we do not force the aged, because of the location of the facility, to go to the city.

I also mention the need for the State Government to do something about the waiting lists. This is not just a belt at the State Government; it is something that is very real. In the public housing sector, which now supplies a considerablenumber of places for the aged, there is an enormous waiting list for the units that are provided. The Queensland Government needs to address that problem, with the support and co-operation of the Federal Government.

There is also a need for State governments and the Federal Government to constantly monitor the standard and conditions of some of the nursing home and hostel accommodation available. It was not so long ago that one place in Brisbane was exposed. An old fellow was living downstairs on a dirt floor. He was still paying the same amount of money as people living elsewhere in that accommodation, but he was living there because there were so many beds on the verandah and in the rooms and there was simply nowhere else he could be. The worst part about it is that it was better than staying at his home. He could not stay there and he had to be somewhere.

There is also a need to constantly monitor the rorts that go on when it comes to aged residential investments. Not so long ago on the Gold Coast many people lost a lot of money when they invested in aged care programs, in Eventide Homes in which they were looking to live themselves, but lost everything. We also have to ensure that people are aware of the moneys that are available to allow them to move into the hostel area. I welcome the Government's seed money program. This financial year $10m is still available for councils and others to get a grant to build some hostel accommodation. It has happened in the Mackay area and it will now happen in the Mount Morgan area.

In closing I want to make one point. We have to ensure that those who are involved in doing things for the aged are fair dinkum. Many community groups are constantly called upon to help churches and various groups involved in the care of the aged, and it angers me when information is presented to me that an organisation has been set up that is not doing what it says it is doing. I refer to a group called Community Link in Brisbane which has been set up by a politician. I regret this because a number of politicians in Queensland have been involved in setting up all sorts of groups to help the aged raise money. This group was set up in Greenslopes. The member, Leisha Harvey, is only a new member and that is probably the problem. The brochure that was sent out stressed the importance of why it was set up and how it would help everybody and said that it would be a non-political, social organisation to raise money for the aged and to help the Red Cross Society.

Recently information was provided to me about three newspaper advertisements that were placed in newspapers in that electorate area prior to Christmas wishing everybody a happy Christmas. That is wonderful. I think members of Parliament should do this. However, those advertisements contained the names of State Ministers. The question arises: Who paid for them? It is suspected that the advertisements were paid for out of Community Link money. Other moneys were raised last Melbourne Cup day, which is almost a year ago; and the figures given to me show that approximately 150 people went along to a function and paid $12 each. Honourable members can see that $1,800 was raised. It was said that this money was raised to help needy people in the community through Red Cross, but the Queensland Parliament was told that a profit of only $492 was made and that this money went to Red Cross. I am told that that money did not all go to Red Cross.

If we are to ensure that community groups are getting the proper help, if we are to ensure that the aged are cared for and that there is willingness on behalf of ordinary people to back groups, whether it be Community Link or anything else, we have to make sure that they are accountable and that no nonsense goes on. I would like to see the accounts and papers of Community Link made public. I believe they ought to be made public. We want to know how much money is being raised, who is paying for political advertisements and where the money has been going. If the organisation was set up to help aged people, that is what the money should be used for. These kinds of activities throw a stigma on many other groups throughout the community which are raising money to help ordinary people, particularly the aged.

Finally, I return to the Bill. I welcome what the Government is doing. I believe that all honourable members will appreciate the need to move down this track. In doing what we are doing under this three-year strategy plan we will achieve a major change in accommodation and care for aged people in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my contribution will be interrupted, I would like first of all to take issue with something the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) said with regard to flexibility. He said that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) had flexibility under the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1986. We note from the Minister's second reading speech that he has a flexibility to vary allocations between the States, regions and special needs group whilst remaining within the national ceiling determined by government. I do not believe enough flexibility is in the legislation to take into consideration the problems we have in our isolated communities.

SPEECH.PARA: In some communities in the division of Hinkler the beds available are allocated under a regional scheme. Elderly people who require hostel-type accommodation or care in a nursing home have to be taken many hundreds of kilometres away from their community. It is extremely traumatic to elderly people to be taken away, and to be isolated from their family and friends in an environment away from where they have lived most of their lives. I believe that the flexibility could have been greater and that the Minister could have been given the means by which he could have gone outside the guidelines in extreme circumstances. It is a worry for isolated communities. The worry is not so great in metropolitan areas because nursing homes are established there and people can be moved, can still be in close proximity to their families and friends and can still have visitors. Community nursing homes, from the Gunther Retirement Village in Gayndah, and even the retirement village at Theodore, to the nursing homes that are established in Bundaberg, should be able to provide beds for the aged within communities close to where they have lived for most of their lives. Let us make it quite clear, and understand, that this legislation relates inter alia to the reduction in the growth of expenditure for nursing homes.

In his second reading speech the Minister indicated that inappropriate admissions of up to 25 per cent of current nursing care residents have been encouraged by the present system which emphasises the provision of the more intensive institutionalised care services provided by nursing homes while not producing the range of care options which elderly people are seeking. Within the division of Hinkler there are a number of facilities which provide assistance and care for the aged with hostel and nursing home accommodation. There are also a few retirement villages. The many voluntary community organisations which involve themselves with these facilities comprise dedicated people who, along with the administrators and staff, take a considerable amount of pride in the service they provide to the aged community-and well they might. It was indeed a pleasure that the Governor-General, Sir Ninian Stephen, and Lady Stephen chose to call on one of these facilities recently. The Pioneer Memorial Home in Bundaberg, which the Governor-General visited, is in the Hinkler electorate. All at the home were delighted to meet Their Excellencies. I believe that Sir Ninian Stephen would have recognised the great work of the nursing homes that we have established in the Hinkler electorate.

I have a strong feeling for our senior citizens and am highly supportive of an earlier Government initiative-the home and community care program. However, it must be recognised that nursing homes are still providing a service to meet a particular need which, from my observations, is still increasing and will continue to so do.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the suspension of the sitting for dinner, whilst my speech was interrupted, I had some discussions with the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) and the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks), who both agree with me that in many instances residents in hostels are in such poor physical and/or mental condition that they require nursing home-type care. In fact, they receive it, but in a hostel environment. I have recently visited one such institution in my electorate where it was demonstrated to me that the greatest need was for more nursing home accommodation because of the number of highly dependent residents in the hostel section requiring extensive care. The matron and members of the hostel committee in Gayndah want a resolution to their problem. I can appreciate that there are instances in which people are accommodated in nursing home care when their condition is only a little worse than that of a hostel resident. In some cases, because of inappropriate admissions, their condition is really more suited to hostel accommodation. Certainly this does not apply at the institution I referred to prior to the suspension of the sitting. My personal experience convinces me that the percentage of nursing home patients in those institutions in the Hinkler electorate who have been inappropriately admitted would be very small. I say this because the general comment always seems to be that they could do with more nursing home beds. However, it would be foolish to ignore totally the statistical evidence cited by the Minister to which I referred earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: The intent of the legislation is, in part, to introduce new growth control arrangements over the approvals in principle and approval mechanisms for new nursing homes. It is also designed to provide a better hostel sector which can and will care for increasingly dependent aged people. This intention is seen quite clearly when we look at the Government's planning strategy for the next three years. This strategy effectively plans for 12,880 additional places up until 1988-89, of which 1,295 or about 10 per cent, will be for nursing homes. The balance will be for hostel places.

Key elements of this residential care program are to provide alternative residential care services to nursing homes in the form of hostels. It is intended to strengthen the role of hostels in the care of the more frail aged, and the Minister's second reading speech indicated that existing hostels were under resourced. A commitment has been made by the Government to maintain the real level of subsidies and to increase assistance for care of those more frail aged people. I suppose the statistical evidence on which this legislative initiative is based reflects the broad view. Consequently, it can fail to be relative to particular situations in particular locations. I mentioned some of those earlier in my speech. The flexibility given the Minister to vary allocations between States and regions while remaining within the national ceiling set by the Government will, I hope, be a suitable mechanism by which this broad view can be related to individual situations throughout Australia. I mentioned earlier the problems of people in the isolated locations where people who require intensive or extensive care have to be located many hundreds of kilometres from the environment in which they have lived all their life. Their families and friends find it very difficult to visit them. Patients in this situation undergo a very traumatic experience.

The scenario developing is one of a relocation of inappropriately admitted nursing home-type patients to upgraded hostel accommodation. This action will, if we are to accept the Government's proposal, provide sufficient extensive nursing care bed growth to cater for needs at a ratio of 40:1,000 aged 70 and over well into the next century. The ultimate conclusion will be that all nursing home beds are for extensive nursing care only. The balance of patients requiring support from residential services up to a moderate dependent level will be accommodated in hostels with provision of a full, improved ranged of personal care services.

I can only agree with the strategy of the home and community care program. I believe that should provide a continuity of care for the aged. I think the strategy is good. I am concerned, however, about what will happen in the transition period between the existing situation and that which is intended. When I think of that particular institution in my electorate which has more nursing home-type patients occupying beds than it has nursing care beds I am concerned about how this legislation will be implemented to remedy the imbalance. To adjust the existing out of kilter situation, those patients whose residential care status is inappropriate relative to their health condition classification will have to be relocated. I hope that any relocation will be done by allowing the passage of time to adjust the situation rather than by any physical movement of patients to other institutions some distance from their present residences.

This adjustment will be complemented by the adoption of appropriate admission procedures and accurate assessment practices so that the mistakes of the past will not be repeated. When we talk about the flexibility of this strategy it is probably most appropriate to encourage a similar flexibility on the part of the residential institutions to be able to cater for the varying numbers of either category of admissions to these respective institutions; in other words, try to avoid locking into a set number of beds for one particular type of accommodation only, where the institution caters for both nursing care and hostel patients. By doing this, I believe the aims of this legislation will be better met. Such a move may well present a challenge to architects in designing future residential institutions and extensions to existing buildings. I do not believe this should be beyond their reach.

Whilst the coalition is not opposing this Bill and we believe it has some strategies that are certainly acceptable, we believe the flexibility that has been given may have some restraints. In regard to the national strategy, I would ask that the Minister and the Government take heed of the situation in those isolated communities where people who are requiring extensive and intensive care in nursing homes at present have to be relocated many hundreds of kilometres from the environment in which they have lived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak on this Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill. I am sure everyone recognises the fact that it is essential that we strive to provide a better residential care program for elderly Australians. We must develop more effective assessment and rehabilitation procedures. We must make sure that we provide services which are better matched to the real needs of our elderly citizens. It is imperative that we develop better community care programs that provide support for those who wish to retain their independence and remain in their own homes. Where an elderly man or woman chooses to remain in his or her own home in preference to a nursing home and when that man or woman is given care and aid by a loved one, whether it be a more physically fit partner, a son or daughter, grandchild or sister or brother, we must make sure that the carer-the person who cares for and administers to the needs of a loved one-is given a realistic allowance or a pension in return for the care that he or she provides. I have always recognised that most people between 20 and 60 years of age have a fair chance of taking care of their own needs and looking after themselves. My concern is mainly directed towards the young and the elderly because I believe they are the ones who need great assistance. We have our youth Priority One. We should have the aged equal priority one.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation before the House is splendid legislation. It is a very important step towards the development of standards of care and quality of life measures to improve the care provided for elderly citizens. It is a step towards a strengthening of home and community care services to ensure a better balance in the provision of care, better services to meet more adequately the real needs of the people towards whom they are directed. This Government is concerned about reports that elderly people are being neglected or badly treated in nursing homes. It will upgrade the inspection program to ensure that sub-standard care is completely eliminated. Our elderly citizens deserve better than sub-standard care; they deserve the best care. Since 1963 there has been a significant growth in the number of nursing home beds. Today there are about 1,200 nursing homes in Australia containing 75,000 beds, and this Government subsidises them all. This represents about 67 beds per 1,000 people aged 70 years or more. This bed rate is high by international standards. Before next month's increase the cost to the Government this financial year will be over $1 billion, or $14,000 per bed. The increased subsidy which will be paid from 13 November, the first pension pay day in November, will increase the Federal Government subsidy per bed to $43.40 per day, which totals nearly $16,000 per bed per year. In New South Wales the increased subsidy to be paid on 13 November is $6.60 per day.

I have said that the bed rate in Australia is high by international standards, and this bed rate, this huge drain on government expenditure, will increase. The funding of nursing homes will increase because we have an aging population. Because of medical progress people are living longer, and because of the post-war baby boom we have an increasing elderly population. This Government is quite right to slow down the increase in nursing home beds and to increase the number of hostel beds. A nursing home, as its name suggests, provides professional nursing care on a 24-hour basis for patients who cannot cope without such care. A hostel, on the other hand, provides help for those people who need personal assistance at particular times, such as meal times and shower time. Hostels generally provide a private bedroom which a resident may personally furnish. This Government wants to build more hostels because there are many more people who need this type of care rather than nursing home care. Yet strangely, there are fewer hostels than nursing homes.

This legislation is not an exercise designed to save money by limiting the growth of nursing homes. The aim is to switch to hostel accommodation, and that aim is intended to benefit elderly people. It has the approval of experts in that field and it also satisfies the wishes of all the elderly. It is quite correct, as other honourable members have said, that we need more hostels in country centres so that people can get accommodation in their local areas. There is nothing more traumatic than for elderly people to be taken away from the area in which they have lived for many years and to have to go to some distant spot and know that their loved ones will suffer the inconvenience of having to travel distances to visit them. It is not good enough that elderly people should be moved far away from those who love them and want to visit them.

I wish to make a few comments about concerns which have arisen as a result of increases in nursing home fees. The Government's recent decision to allow nursing homes to increase fees has imposed real hardship on many nursing home patients or their loved ones. There are many cases within my electorate of Hunter where a pensioner is required to pay up to an extra $40 per week to meet the fees charged his pensioner wife who is a patient in a nursing home. Honourable members all know how easy it is for a pensioner to have to shell out $40 a week to have his aged wife cared for! I thank those people in the Hunter electorate who have rung me with details of hardships. People on unemployment benefit pay $40 per week in nursing home fees for a loved grandmother.

A previous speaker from the Opposition criticised the Government for the fact that this gap between the Government subsidy and the increase in nursing home fees should have occurred. However, as I have said, early next month the Government intends to increase the subsidy for nursing home beds, but it is a pity that the increased subsidy and the increase in nursing home fees were not synchronised. I am disappointed at this interval which is causing hardship to nursing home patients, but it must be recognised that similar intervals of hardship occurred when the Opposition was in Government. However, that is no reason for the lack of synchronisation to be allowed to continue.

I would like to refer briefly to one section of the legislation. Under the Aged Persons Homes Act 1954, the Commonwealth makes grants to eligible organisations towards meeting the capital cost of homes for aged or disabled people. The amount of a grant may not exceed 80 per cent of the capital cost of the home. Some eligible organisations which represent financially disadvantaged groups in the community experience difficulty in raising matching funds. The Government, in this Bill, is introducing flexibility in matching arrangements to allow for up to 100 per cent of Commonwealth funds for special groups, including ethnic communities, Aborigines and other disadvantaged groups. This measure is estimated to cost $500,000 in 1986-87 and $2.8m in 1987-88.

To digress for just one moment, I would like to speak about the satisfaction that I have had from the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes). There is a home in Maitland called Benhome Home for the Aged which is operated by the Maitland Benevolent Society. It is a home for aged and has hostel accommodation. The building is quite old and recently the Board of Fire Commissioners inspected it and said: `This home will have to close because it does not meet fire regulations'. Honourable members can imagine the panic that caused the committee of Benhome. Wonderful women such as Mrs Turner and Miss Frith and other hard-working members of the committee who have run fetes and done everything possible to raise money to help their fellow human beings were just desperate. They came to my office. I made representations to the Minister and within a matter of weeks these people who thought their patients would be consigned to the streets and thrown out with no homes whatsoever received a grant of $420,000 as a start towards meeting the fire regulations.

In Cessnock there is a masonic retirement village. In recent months it has installed a magnificent example of hostel accommodation for the people of the Cessnock city area. Substantial funding for that hostel was provided by this Government. Further substantial funding was provided by this Government for Greenhills Nursing Home in Maitland. The things I have mentioned are proof of the genuine care and concern of this Government for aged people. This is a good Bill. I am pleased that the Opposition will not oppose its passage. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to speak on the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1986. I notice that by sheer coincidence, the very attractive group of children in the gallery come from one of the schools in the beautiful Blue Mountains, John Wycliffe Christian School.
—Is that in your electorate?

—Yes. I am sure many of them have grandparents and even great-grandparents, some of whom may be in some of the lovely hostels and nursing homes that abound in Macquarie. Many nursing home patients and administrators in my electorate are aware that this legislation is being debated today. From what I have been informed, some of them find it very hard to accept that one of the purposes of this Bill is to improve the planning and co-ordination of nursing home and hostel care. They find it hard to accept because, over the last couple of weeks, they or their families have become anxious about and distressed by the Government's seeming inability properly to plan and co-ordinate three important things: An increase in nursing home fees, consideration and approval of an appropriate subsidy increase and an increase in pension benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: The same Government, which seems oblivious to the unfair burden it has placed on pensioners by deferring pension increases, has, through either incompetence or disinterest, allowed elderly patients in nursing homes to face the temporary but very frightening situation in which they or their families are unable to continue to meet their fees. That situation has been compounded by the Government's inability to reassure them as to whether it will adequately adjust benefits and, unfortunately, I think by its arrogant dismissal of their concerns. I believe that today an announcement has been made about the subsidies that will be paid.

I will justify that last statement by quoting from a letter from the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) released by the Nursing Homes Association of New South Wales. The Minister blithely stated:

There is a percentage of people whose fees are not made up by the combination of the pension and the nursing home benefit which is payable. That always happens. In these circumstances, for a few weeks, that will happen again.

It is incomprehensible to me how a Minister for Community Services could speak so matter of factly about a situation which has caused, and is still causing, real distress and hardship for pensioners in homes. But then it is, it seems, consistent with the actions of the Cabinet, which blindly spreads the sacrifices required to bring us out of recession evenly across groups which are not equally equipped to cope with them. Indeed, the more cynical community might be led to believe that the Cabinet has discovered some perverse utilitarian formula which has shown that political pain for the Government can be minimised by directing the sacrifices disproportionately and in short bursts towards those already suffering hardship.

This Bill is intended to introduce new, but still overly centralised, nursing home care arrangements. It is intended to strengthen the role of hostel care. It provides new funding for the aged and care for special groups of disadvantaged Australians. It seeks to revise planning arrangements and improve consultation with the States, and it seeks minor amendments of the legislation. The Opposition finds no significant problems with the Bill in this regard. I want, however, to state a personal assessment, which is that I consider an opportunity has been lost by the Government in bringing this legislation before the House-an opportunity I believe it had to tackle the underlying barrier preventing adequate and appropriate care for the aged in Australia.

The first view that I have has to do with the business environment within which nursing home and hostel operators are expected to operate. What businessmen or women will venture into this service sector, given the combination of excessive regulation, ever increasing on-costs, the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax? The other day I was talking to one retired nursing home operator who was outraged at the Minister's uninformed comments concerning the profits made by nursing home operators. He pointed out to me that he had made nothing from his operation until he sold it, and now, under this Government's capital gains tax, even that small return would be threatened. If the Government thinks that the charities and the churches will fill the void, it and the aged are in for an unpleasant surprise several years from now.

The second view I wish to express has to do with encouraging Australians to take steps during their working life to ensure self-reliance and dignity in retirement. Suffice it to say that taxation on superannuation benefits, capital gains and the assets test are very effective disincentives to make such provision.

The last point I wish to make has to do with the failure of the Government to provide taxation and allowance support for families to retain responsibility for the care of elderly members. What young or middle-aged family providers, with excessively high mortgages, child-raising costs and taxation, are in any position to bear the strain and costs of caring for an aged member of their extended family? This really goes to the crux of the matter. It is the wish of most aged citizens to be able to stay with or near their families. I believe that most families, given the chance, would not dump grandparents or brothers and sisters into institutions. It is in the interests of the nation as a whole, both morally and in terms of welfare resources, that we do not unnecessarily institutionalise the aged.

This piecemeal short term readjustment of government regulation, manipulation and restriction is not a long term option in the search for quality and cost effective care of our aged. What we should have seen when this legislation was brought before us was an overall strategy to deal with the three key factors in this matter-private enterprise, self-reliance and the family. But, of course, that would require that the whole philosophy and record of this Government's taxation policy be reversed. A long term strategy based on these three factors is needed. I assure those people in my electorate of Macquarie as well as honourable members present in the House today who are concerned about nursing homes and other forms of care for the aged that this is what I will pursue with my colleagues in the coalition when we assume office after the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me a very great deal of pleasure to speak this evening on the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1986. The purpose of this Bill is to make certain that the amount of money and resources that is devoted to aged care is spent correctly. It is to make certain that it does not go into the pockets of a few greedy individuals. For too long some entrepreneurs have been abusing the Government's assistance given to those in greatest need in our community. Many nursing home proprietors do not abuse the benefits that are given to them by the Government. However, the few who do have given this section of business a very bad name. The report of the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes, the Giles report, and the report of the Standing Committee on Expenditure on Accommodation and Home Care for the Aged, the McLeay report, identified very significant problems associated with the provision of Commonwealth aged care services. The growth in private nursing homes and their cost has increased rapidly during the last 10 years. It is an area in which entrepreneurs and doctors can invest and make very large profits very quickly.

SPEECH.PARA: The nursing home and hostel review, the report of which was tabled in the Senate in April, had four basic philosophical goals. They are that aged and disabled people should as far as possible be supported in their own homes and in their communities. Aged and disabled people should be supported by residential services only where other support systems are not appropriate to meet their needs. Services should be provided in an atmosphere of, and using processes which promote as far as possible, rehabilitation and restoration of function. The manner in which services are provided should develop and enhance personal freedom and the independent functioning of all residents. Services should be based on a recognition that, for many people, discharge to a residential service providing a less intensive form of care or to a community-based support service will be a possible and very desirable outcome. These recommendations form the basis of the amendments which this Bill addresses.

The electorate of Dunkley covers part of the Mornington Peninsula. I would like to bring to the notice of our Government the special problems that have arisen in this area in relation to nursing homes and hostel care. In the 1950s and 1960s many residents of the Melbourne metropolitan area built holiday homes on the peninsula. They have spent many wonderful holidays there. They have now reached retiring age, have sold their suburban houses and are enjoying a well earned retirement on the peninsula. Very large retirement villages have been established on the peninsula which have attracted people from all over Victoria to live there. This has created the very large problem in relation to aged care that we have today on the peninsula.

I take the opportunity in this debate to mention the Baxter Village, which has over 700 residents. It is in my electorate, just out of Frankston. I am sure that honourable members will be aware that it had very serious financial problems some 12 months ago. I am happy to say that a new company has been formed by the Baptist Union of Victoria and the Commonwealth Bank of Australia which have had to pay out debts of over $20m. Even with the investigations that have taken place, I still have not had explained to me how $20m was lost in three years. Bob Payne, who was the head of the village and one of the leaders of the Festival of Light, has now left the village. From discussions with a large number of residents it appears that a new feeling of optimism and a coming together of the community have emerged. The distress and anguish caused by greed and avarice have begun to dissipate. I thank all those who were involved in the battle to make certain that the residents were not disadvantaged in any way. Particular thanks must go to the Corporate Affairs Commission and the State Government of Victoria, for without their timely intervention a much greater and more serious problem would have occurred.

Returning to the Bill, the peninsula had the highest rate of resident growth in Victoria between 1976 and 1983. The aged population of the Mornington Peninsula is increasing at an annual rate of 4 per cent. According to the latest figures I have, there are on the peninsula an estimated 8,624 people over the age of 70. There are only 338 nursing home beds, which is a ratio of 39.2 beds per 1,000 people over 70 years of age. The average rate of nursing home beds per 1,000 people over 70 years of age throughout Victoria is 60 to 70. The Mornington Peninsula is believed to have the lowest ratio of nursing home beds of any large community in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What ratio is it? Do you know what the figure is?

—The figure is 39.2. The huge growth in the number of aged persons is putting tremendous strains on local hospitals and the various geriatric centres throughout the peninsula. These strains have been caused by many people being attracted to the peninsula by large retirement villages. This is causing a great deal of distress amongst the elderly and their families. It is not right that our citizens should go into hospitals when hostel accommodation may be quite adequate. I have made representations to the responsible Minister asking that urgent attention be given to the special problems presented on the peninsula. I will continue to press the case. We must look after our elderly better. The amendments that are incorporated in this Bill, I am sure, will go a long way towards redressing the problem that has existed for many years. This has not just happened overnight; it has been building up over the last 10 to 15 years. I wish to end this speech with a poem that I used in a newsletter I distributed about 10 years ago. I feel it is a very important testimony which gives the view of the frail aged in our society. The poem was found among the possessions of an old lady who died in the geriatric ward of Ashludie Hospital, near Dundee. There is no information as to her name, when she died or who she was. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: What do you see, nurses, what do you see?
Are you thinking when you look at me-
A crabbit old woman, not very wise,
Uncertain of health, with far-away eyes,
Who dribbles her food and makes no reply
When you say in a loud voice,
`I do wish you'd try'.
Who seems not to notice the things that you do,
And forever is losing a stocking or shoe,
Who unresisting or not, lets you do as you will,
With bathing and feeding, the long day to fill.
Is that what you're thinking, is that what you see?
Then open your eyes, nurse, you're not looking at me.
I'll tell you who I am as I sit here so still,
As I rise at your bidding, as I eat at your will.
I'm a small child of ten with a father and mother,
Brothers and sisters, who love one another;
A young girl of sixteen with wings on her feet,
Dreaming that soon now a lover she'll meet;
A bride soon at twenty-my heart gives a leap
Remembering the vows that I promised to keep;
At twenty-five now I have young of my own
Who need me to build a secure happy home;
A woman of thirty, my young now grow fast,
Bound to each other with ties that should last.
At forty, my young sons have grown and are gone,
But my man's beside me to see I don't mourn;
At fifty once more babies play round my knee,
Again we know children, my loved one and me.
Dark days are upon me, my husband is dead,
I look to the future, I shudder with dread.
For all my young are rearing young of their own,
And I think of the years and the love I have known.
I'm an old woman now and nature is cruel-
'Tis her jest to make old age look like a fool.
The body is crumbled, grace and vigour depart.
There now is a stone where there once was a heart.
But inside this old carcass a young girl still dwells,
And now and again my battered heart swells.
I remember the years, I remember the pain,
And I'm loving and living life over again.
I think of the years all too few-gone too fast,
And accept the stark fact that nothing can last.
So open your eyes, nurses, open and see.
Not a crabbit old woman, look close-see ME.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a very nice poem and, of course, tonight is not the time to get political and aggressive. There have not been many interjections on most of the speeches tonight because they have all been down to earth and the speakers have all realised that we have a mammoth problem and that between us we should try to overcome it. I have some very strong views on the aged and I always have had. I believe it has been said tonight that all of a sudden this problem has caught up with us. There is a realisation that we have an aging population and that we need to do more. I have studied fairly carefully the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill and, of course, the Opposition is not opposing it. The measures seem fine. It is a redirection towards hostel accommodation. But I do ask a few questions.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not always agree with documents such as this Bill, because sometimes I study the people who have prepared it and they do not fit in with my line of thinking. I am a practical person; I go around my electorate and I look, talk and observe. Hostel accommodation is fine, but who will look after the people in these hostels? We have an aging population. We have lazy women out on the Parliament House lawn who talk about peace. They should try to look after some of the elderly people I know, who cannot cut their lawns and cannot do this and cannot do that. But we have a lazy, rotten lot in Australia who have not settled down to the fact that there are a lot of people out there who need us. A lot of people are talking about this and laying down foundations as to what should be done but, regrettably, they do not do it. We are talking about the elderly being integrated into hostel beds. That is fine, but I repeat: Who is going to look after them? Who is going to be with them after their 40 hours of care? Has anyone sat down and found out what domiciliary sisters do? They do a good job but they do only the bare necessities. They do only what is set down in the guidelines.

An honourable member said tonight that married couples cannot look after the elderly. Some of them cannot because the wife may be working or the husband may not be in a fit condition to have his parents around him, et cetera. I understand all that, but who is going to look after the increasing number of elderly people if the elderly are to be redirected into nursing and hostel accommodation?

TALK.START.PARA: —Into institutions.

—I do not like the word `institutions'. It has been used tonight. Once nursing homes were thought of as places where people go to die-that is it, that is the end. We heard a lovely poem tonight illustrating the fact that elderly people need to be integrated with the young. Sometimes there is condemnation of single mothers. Would it not be good if some of the single mothers, with their little babies, could, to a degree, be integrated into nursing homes and look after these elderly people? Would it not be good if we could harness some of the unemployed in Australia, who want to do something, to help some of the elderly people who need help and attention?

SPEECH.PARA: It is easy to put down statistics and say: `Bang, we will put them all in hostel accommodation'. But I ask again: Who is going to look after these people? Where are we going to get the people to care for them? Where are the young ones going to come from to look after them and do all the things that are absolutely necessary when one is old? We have a changing situation. Some people are old at 55. Dementia can set in at a very early age.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're not.
—I am not; I am vivid and wide awake. But I am different, I see things as they are.
—But you're not 55.
—I am not 55 either. Some people get to the stage where they need help and attention at a very early age, so we have a massive problem. Some people are made redundant at a very early age.
—Who is going to look after them?

—Exactly; who is going to look after them? I have read a report on this matter. I have not studied it all that carefully because I do not study reports that much. Instead, I go around and look for myself. Then I am able to judge things for myself. Why is there an increasing number of people contacting me in Hobart and saying: `Bruce, we cannot get our mum or dad into a nursing home. It is impos- sible. They are full'? Yet a study of the com- munity of Hobart-done by probably very good people-talks about statistics and the number of people who are in nursing homes and in hostel accommodation. The honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) looks at me quizzically. That report just does not make sense to me. Therefore, I start to ask questions about where we are going. Senator Grimes apparently had the best of experts to bring down this report. I only hope to God that they are right because we have an increasing number of elderly people in Australia and if they are not redirected the correct way, we will have a massive problem on our hands.
—We already have one.

—We already have one. It has come up so rapidly, before our very eyes. I get mad when, having gone to the opening of a magnificent building, a sports arena or something like that, and seen on the wall the name of a politician, who smiles and puts out his chest, I go around the corner and I see some sick elderly person who may be dying but who cannot get into a nursing home. Our priorities are not right. We need to redirect those priorities. We as politicians should start to realise that it is not the sporting, cultural or opera openings that are important; that we should start opening places for the elderly. We should start to realise that care for the aged is a massive problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Denison and I were criticised in a Mercury editorial. People forget about the decent work we do. We are condemned just because we are a bit light- hearted at times. People do not realise the constant number of people we see every day, as we have for 11 years. The fact that we put on a lighthearted approach at times does not mean that we are not deadly serious, do not care or do not look after our electorates to the best of our abilities. This is a problem that comes before honourable members and we should all be aware of it. If we do not look after elderly people, we should be condemned for not doing our job. It is useless walking around and saying that we are great fellows because we believe in this or in that; if we forget about the people who need our help, our attention, we shall be in dire straits in the long term.

TALK.START.PARA: —How is the task force going?
—I am chairman of the task force-and I am doing it my way, so is the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) and Senator-what is her name?
—Senator Knowles.

—Knowles-I always forget the women. They are all going a good job-because we are going out doing it our way, finding out the problems for ourselves, not condemning, not looking to the experts, not looking to the ones who have their heads in the sky and who think that statistics are everything. We are having a good look. Some of the places we have seen are using new ideas. For example, at Christmas they are bringing in young children and young singers and there is an integration between young and old.
—Making it happy.

—As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition says, making it happy. That is the important thing. That is good, because innovations occur every day and there seems to be an awareness of what is needed. On the one hand, there are the selfish people, and on the other hand, the people who are prepared to go in and have a look and to make certain that they are doing the best they possibly can for the elderly. The lonely elderly people who are out there tonight, who may not have very much money and who may be looking after their own little homes, doing the best they possibly can, should rest assured that there are people in this House who care for them, who are trying to find out their problems, to bring down recommendations and to make their lives better in the long term.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Accommodation for the frail, the chronically ill, the aging and the disabled needs to adapt. The honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) will agree that under successive governments it has become very difficult to adapt to the demands, particularly for nursing home accommodation. Our system requires more care, more planning, more co-ordination and better direction.

SPEECH.PARA: What has gone wrong? First, there was an emphasis-I know that the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) does not like the word-on institutionalisation. Nursing homes were once the growth area of the aged persons' accommodation. In 1961 a Barry Humphries character named Sandy Stone said that when families grow up `They either wipe their boots on you, or they marry the first one that comes along and pack you off to a twilight home'. People who went into nursing homes all too often were transformed from residents into patients. The frail were accommodated with the chronically ill, the mentally active tended to receive little stimulus, and the costs of operation of nursing homes were high. It is to the credit of many nursing home proprietors and charities that much more has been done in recent years in resident care.

There has also been a growing recognition in the community that Australians have for long pushed the aging aside. This recognition was accompanied by a trend to the less expensive, less disciplined hostel-type accommodation that employs administrative and often a very small nursing staff. They provide a mix of care, community activity and private living suitable for many frail people. In Eden-Monaro hostels operate at George Forbes House, Queanbeyan, Narooma, Bombala, Dalmeny and Milton. They are able to link in with nursing home accommodation at Queanbeyan, Cooma, Pambula, Bega, Dalmeny and Milton. Federal and State governments have at last come to grips with the need for aged and disabled people to have alternatives to nursing home accommodation, to be supported even in their own homes and in their own communities as far as possible. This action to help people live in their own homes is only now taking place through the Federal Government's home and community care program to the extent that it needs to be.

State and Federal governments have at last joined to ensure the provision of not only personal and health care but also other assistance. It was only three years ago when an elderly elector told me that he had a choice of staying at home or moving to a nursing home. He was unable to do odd jobs around the house. The honourable member for Franklin has mentioned them-lawn mowing, garden clearing and certain aspects of housework. All the elderly elector needed was help for two or three hours a day five or six days a week. The dilemma seemed to be a tragic one: To leave the community and the house that he knew and cherished; or to stay there unable to cope-all for the lack of two or three hours assistance a day. Here was one case in which governments would surely save taxpayers' funds by keeping an aging person at home.

Today, under the home and community care program, people such as that person should be able to receive some help in the home. This Bill takes us a step further. It follows extensive consultations with State governments, nursing homes, hostels, consumers, welfare groups, staff and public servants. The Bill amends the nursing homes and hostels legislation to give effect to some very important matters raised in those consultations. For a start, residential services will be better planned. Better planning will be associated with more monitoring and evaluation. Tonight the Sir William Hudson Nursing Home in Cooma is holding its annual meeting. This follows a series of actions and changes at the nursing home which led to calls to me for more government involvement. No action could be taken under legislation to perform the type of monitoring that was requested.

Under the proposed amendments, monitoring and evaluation will be possible. Changes can be made where necessary. Integration of nursing homes, with their intensive care, and hostels, with community services, is required. Hostels will also be assisted to care for increasingly dependent people. Hostels, with their less intensive care, are not only less costly for taxpayers; they also allow residents to adapt to varying degrees of care. They are less likely to restrict residents to a high degree of care when it is not really needed. The amendments we are considering tonight will mean that the growth of nursing home accommodation can be controlled. This defends patients as well as taxpayers. It also allows for approval for beds to special needs groups, including the deaf and the blind aged. The change from nursing home emphasis to hostel options will be gradual and it will not affect present residents of nursing homes or hostels.

I must say that I was very disturbed to hear recently of some unjustified rumours about pensioners being squeezed out of nursing homes or their relatives being charged for accommodation. For that reason I am very pleased to advise of increased rates for pensioners in nursing homes amounting to a benefit of $43.40 a day-a rise of $6.60 a day or $46.20 a week. In New South Wales that will more than compensate for the recent fee rise of $5.10 a day in that State, the result of a long overdue wage increase for nurses in nursing homes. The additional benefit for residents whose frailty or other disabilities require extensive care will remain at $42 a week. In 1537 Pietro Aretino said: `Age has a good mind and sorry shanks'. That is not always the case, but this Bill does recognise the sorry shanks when they exist and ensures that good minds are not allowed to waste. I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill is the culmination of many years of analysis by the Government and, indeed, all parties in the Parliament of the problems of caring for the aged. We hope that the legislation will actually contain sufficient provisions to ensure the proper and adequate care of aged people in the community who require help. I emphasise that this legislation must continue to give to local people who have their nursing homes and communities adequate control of them without too much bureaucratic or government interference. We must recognise that the three avenues which provide care for the aged when they are ill are nursing homes, hostels and hospitals. I welcome the fact that the legislation enables people to have better care within their own private homes. This is terribly important and I trust that the States, together with the Commonwealth, will financially encourage this aspect of assistance. I know that many speakers in this debate have been able to quote instances in their own electorates and all of us know dozens, even hundreds of people who we believe are in need of particular care.

SPEECH.PARA: I emphasise the fact that there are some aspects of the legislation that concern me from the practical point of view of looking after aged people within the community. I appreciate the fact that the emphasis will be on the hostels and not the nursing homes. In my electorate of Lyne we have quite a number of nursing homes and hostels for the aged. I know of no patient who is in a nursing home in my electorate who I personally believe could be cared for in his or her own home. These people are very ill-many of them are vegetables-and many have no relations to look after them. That is particularly important. There are others who have families but those families are not in a position to look after them. In these cases there is no avenue for these people, other than a nursing home or another type of institution, such as a hospital.

I trust that in this legislation the Government will allow for a tremendous amount of flexibility in relation to hostel accommodation. This will certainly be needed. We will not be able to continue with the present criterion whereby an aged person is supposed to be immobile before he or she is allowed into a hostel. The Government will need to provide flexibility and ensure that adequate hostel care is available to people who, on present day grades, should be in a nursing home. I hope that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) will be able to provide that flexibility because it has never been spelt out clearly where that fine line will be drawn. I know it is difficult to draw such a line but we must know when a sick person is eligible to enter a hostel. We must know what state of immobility will be required.

I also emphasise that wherever possible accommodation for aged persons should be undertaken by responsible groups within the community. I am not talking about the private nursing homes; I am taking about places such as the Nelson Bay Retirement Village, the Bushland Place at Taree, the Frank Widden Masonic Home at Wingham and other centres in my electorate where a community of people has raised one-third of the funds to build the home and has received a two-thirds grant from the Government. These homes then come under the deficit funding scheme. I strongly believe in the deficit funding scheme for community homes. We must never forget that the basic success of these homes is that they are run by experienced local people who know the needs of the local community. We must never ever forget that fact. There will be instances within the legislation whereby the disadvantaged groups-Aboriginals and others in the community-will receive 100 per cent of the total capital cost for the accommodation and then receive some extra care after that. I point out to the Government that there are many disadvantaged groups within the community today. The average age pensioner within the community is a disadvantaged person, as far as I am concerned. Many, not all, age pensioners within my electorate, and I am sure elsewhere throughout Australia, are disadvantaged. We do not want to see somebody turned out of bed in order to allow another person to use the bed. That person should be allowed to remain there.

I hope that the legislation will be reasonable. Whenever I see this type of legislation before the House I wonder what the outcome of it, in practical terms, will be. I am concerned because I know that the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) intends to introduce legislation concerning sheltered workshops. The same thing applies to sheltered workshops within the community. Wherever these workshops operate, they are highly successful. There is one at Manning Valley, Taree, in my electorate called Valley Industries, in which over 90 people work. I hope that if there is a change in the legislation control will not be taken over by the bureaucracy, out of the hands of the local people. The bureaucracy has an opportunity to get into this field. The legislation that is before us tonight refers to therapy that is to be applied to these groups. This is the avenue used by the bureaucracy to control nursing homes, hostels and sheltered workshops. It is able to tap into this area. We must be careful of this. I emphasise this point again: The local people who control these places understand the problems of the aged or the disadvantaged within the community. These people are best able to serve the institutions and the public.

One hears some very interesting references with regard to aged persons accommodation. There is a Dr Redshaw in my electorate who has done a tremendous amount for the community. One day he suggested to me: `You should not put the three together-the unit, the nursing home and the hostel accommodation-on the one block of land'. One does not want people to go by way of steps and stairs from one into the other because, in the end, they are only awaiting death. I know it is not always practical to do this because of the services, ranging from the laundry to the kitchen, that must be provided. But these are practical facts that, when we get old, we will think about. We will be waiting to die. So we must be practical in our thinking and in the legislation that we introduce in the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Long term planning.

—That is right. I emphasise that private nursing home and hostel accommodation provides a tremendous amount of accommodation for the needy. I do not know whether the Minister has announced the increase in the fees today-apparently he has-but I hope that it is adequate to meet the demands. It must be accepted that if a group, a company or a person builds a nursing home-we all have these within our electorates-they stand to make a reason- able return on their investment. We should remember the tremendous advantage that those beds provide-be they nursing home or hostel beds-to the people in the community. In my area there are dozens and dozens of people on waiting lists for beds in nursing homes or hostels. These people, whether or not they can afford it, are forced to go into these places. Dozens of people have contacted me in recent days, particularly concerning the Bonventi nursing home at Forster-Tuncurry. Initially, the people are put in such places because they are in need of accommodation. But when the fees go up-and they have to go up because of the nurses award in New South Wales and other extra costs involved-they are unable to meet the increased fees. They are unable to meet them because in many instances pensioners are contributing to pensioners. There is no other way out. We see many age pensioner couples within the community whose mother or father is in a nursing home. They are the only ones who are able, from their pension, to meet these extra costs.

SPEECH.PARA: I do want to pay tribute to those people who have the entrepreneurship, the initiative, to build private nursing homes to cater for those people in our country who need these services. We all have to realise that we have the tiger by the tail. We have a great responsibility in this area; at the moment we spend over $1 billion a year. I am sure the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) will agree with me because he has quite a lot of nursing homes in his area. An owner of a number of those nursing homes also owns some in my electorate. The fact is that we as Australians have a tremendous responsibility to care for the aged. I am pleased to support the legislation but I trust that the Minister will heed those few warnings that I have issued this evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My good friend the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) and I both served in the New South Wales Parliament and we have known each other for a long time. As State members and now as Federal members, one of the biggest problems we have is advising and helping people who have elderly parents who need either hostel accommodation or nursing home accommodation. Perhaps I could reassure the honourable member that the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) has today announced an increase in nursing home benefits in New South Wales of $6.60 a day. This will more than cover the recent fee rise of $5.10 a day in that State, which was brought about by a long overdue increase in award wages for nurses, matrons and other hospital staff.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not agree with one point the honourable member made. He referred to a suggestion by a doctor constituent that perhaps nursing homes should be put in a separate area to hostels, that facilities for the aged should be spread around. I have trouble with an elderly couple when from time to time one is in a nursing home and the other is in a hostel some considerable distance away and they cannot visit each other. It is distressing for people if they are living together in a retired person's hostel and one is taken a long distance away to a nursing home. So there is another side to the coin, and I am sure my good friend the honourable member for Lyne would appreciate that. The problems are very acute. I did serve for three years on the Executive Council of the Council on Ageing in New South Wales; so I have had a number of problems brought to my attention. I do thank Dr Paul D'Arbon at Western Suburbs Hospital in Croydon, Sydney, a man who has helped and advised me and who has helped many constituents whom I have referred to him. He has helped place elderly parents in nursing homes and advised people about respite care, the carer's pension and all the accoutrements that are now available to assist aging people in our nation, the population of which is aging rapidly.

The area of Sydney that I represent in this national Parliament was really the nursing home heartland of Sydney, containing suburbs such as Burwood, Strathfield, Croydon and Ashfield. They were the places that people used to think of when talking about nursing homes. There is a great range of nursing homes there; there are the church and charitable nursing homes and nursing homes run privately, but they all have to comply with State registration requirements. They are strictly supervised and they are all of the highest order.

Some years ago a proprietor, who is now dead, was gaining a great deal of notoriety in the local Press about not paying staff, or not paying long service leave or holiday pay, and putting pensioners who did not pay their bills out into the street. Nevertheless, when I rang the New South Wales Health Commission I was assured that the two nursing homes involved, in Five Dock at the time, were properly run and were even better than many others that looked very well run on the surface. The patients were well cared for and nurtured; they were properly treated.

In New South Wales, and I am sure in the other States, the growth of nursing homes has been higgledy-piggledy and they have sprung up here and there. The late Jim Maher of Strathfield, Executive Secretary of the St Vincent de Paul Society, went to visit an old lady in Strathfield many years ago. A Matron Cullen was running a nursing home in Albert Road. When he got there he found that Matron Cullen was in bed sick and no one was looking after the frail patients in the nursing home. Jim Maher asked a number of local ladies to feed these people and then the St Vincent de Paul Society took over that responsibility. To cut a long story short, this home is now the largest nursing home in my electorate; it grew up by chance. It is now a Schedule 5 hospital, so the Health Commission has the right to place patients from public hospitals in Our Lady of Loreto, Strathfield. It is an outstanding nursing home. There is a wide variety of nursing homes and hostels in Lowe. We have the Little Sisters of the Poor in Drummoyne, we have the Presbyterian home at Drummoyne, which is a hostel complex and aged persons units. We have new ventures such as St Mary's Villa, Concord, a nursing home and a hostel which was opened last year by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

We also have ethnic nursing homes. We have one for the Chinese community, and the Russian community also has one. I am sure that all honourable members would have had the same experiences I have had when visiting these places. We all go to such places at election time, of course, and perhaps it is a good thing. Most of the homes are polling places in State, Federal and local elections. If nothing else, people go to these homes at election time and see what is happening. They meet the patients and the proprietors, and that can only do good.

One of the great things about being a member of parliament is that one meets some wonderful people. One man I met told me that he was working for the community because his old dad, who was a digger, had gone senile, had been put in a repatriation ward of the Gladesville Psychiatric Hospital in Sydney and had been cured. He was brought back to reality and returned to live with his family, where he lived for some years before dying peacefully. This man was so appreciative of what this hospital had done that he did voluntary work in psychiatric hospitals in Sydney.

The legislation tries to create an atmosphere in which people are not seen to be depositing aged relatives in nursing homes forever. Nursing homes are essentially part of the hospital system. The whole notion of the legislation is to control their growth so that someone cannot start a nursing home just by raising money. A very worthwhile report entitled `Nursing Homes and Hostels Review', commissioned by the Minister for Community Services and available to honourable members and the general public, has pointed out not that Australia has more nursing home beds than any other country but certainly that we have more than most others and have a disproportionate ratio of nursing home beds to hostel beds.

In 1985 in Australia there were 46.8 nursing home beds for every 1,000 people over 65 years of age. In Great Britain there were only 12; New Zealand had 21 and Canada 23. Only in the United States and Denmark were the figures higher than in Australia. Australia had 21.9 hostel accommodation beds per 1,000 of the population over 65 years. Other countries had a higher percentage of hostel beds; the United Kingdom had 25, New Zealand 32 and Canada 40. In other countries with which we compare ourselves there is more of a mix of hostel beds and nursing home beds than there is in Australia. If this can be achieved in our nation, as the honourable member for Lyne said, it will save an enormous amount of money. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), in his second reading speech, pointed out that some of the principles and philosophical goals of the legislation are that the aged and disabled should, as far as possible, be supported in their own homes and in their own communities. Naturally, there are people who must go into nursing homes because they have no one to care for them adequately, but tonight we must pay tribute to some of the people who care for others in their homes-volunteers who work in the community, the volunteers who do meals on wheels, the people who serve on committees to keep the home care services going, and the people who perhaps just help their neighbours to do what they can to assist them in their homes.

Another provision that the Minister outlined and highlighted was that aged and disabled people should be supported by residential services only where other support systems are not appropriate to meet their needs. He also made the point that services should be provided in an atmosphere, and using processes, which promote, as far as possible, rehabilitation and restoration of function. I could not agree more. We must never reach the point where people are put into nursing homes and that is it-there being no return to outside life. The Minister stressed in this second reading speech that there must be a more flexible integrated planning approach to the provision of residential services and a better resourced hostel section.

We are dealing in the private sector with a very valuable item and that is nursing home beds. In Victoria nursing home beds turn over for about $15,000 each. When a nursing home is sold, so too are its goods, chattels and goodwill. Australia, with its aging population, is going through a very difficult financial time. There is a very rapid growth in the expensive costs of nursing homes. This legislation has been brought forward, in a sense, to remove the political pressures for the establishment of nursing homes. A committee will overview and supervise the establishment of new nursing homes which will be needed to keep abreast of the aging processes in society. I am delighted to find that that committee will not be composed of career public servants but will include community representatives, representatives of the proprietors and also, I trust, representatives of the users. The present committee which advises on the establishment of new nursing homes in our community does not contain representatives of the voluntary or charitable nursing homes and I have brought that fact to the attention of the Minister.

Finally, I point out that groups applying for a certificate to establish new nursing homes will be subject to rigorous standards. However, the basic aim of the legislation is to modernise the machinery under which nursing homes are established and at the same time encourage the establishment of hostel beds. I certainly commend the legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many honourable members have indicated that they wanted to speak on the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1986. So that everyone who wants to speak can participate in this debate we have agreed voluntarily to restrict our remarks. Therefore, the number of topics that one can cover in this debate is very limited. This is, of course, a very substantial piece of legislation which involves very large expenditure. The issues which it addresses are very fundamental. It is a pity, therefore, that the debate could not have been a little longer.

SPEECH.PARA: I have decided not to recanvass many of the issues that have been raised tonight by both my colleagues and members on the other side of the House. My remarks basically will be ones of general principle. I will take the opportunity to reiterate some of the concerns that I have expressed in this place in the past. I say at the outset that I have no objection to the basic thrust of government policy insofar as there is good will towards the aged. I believe there is good will towards the aged and that, in my opinion, is essential. I have said before in this place-and I was reiterating the words of someone wiser than I-that the health of a society is truly measured by its attitude towards the young and the elderly. It is true that people's expectations in respect of age govern their behaviour throughout their adult lives. This is certainly so from the age of about 30 onwards. Government measures can affect people's patterns of behaviour, consumption, savings, earnings, expectations and so on.

One thing that concerns me a little about debate on the aged, and specifically debate on this legislation, is that I am not sure that enough attention has been paid to the priorities that elderly people in Australia have for themselves. The aged tend to have different priorities of need than do other age groups.
