Matters that may seem very simple to people in their 40s, 50s or even 60s can assume very much large significance and have a higher priority in the life of the aged. For example, I have expressed in the past some concern that we do not put pressure on elderly people to stay in their homes longer than they really want to. Twenty or thirty years ago it was considered not desirable for elderly people to go into nursing homes. Nursing homes, were few; they were not well supported financially by government, and therefore they were very expensive. Alternatively, the standards were not very high, in order to make them affordable. We have made enormous progress in the area in Australia in the last two or three decades. In general terms these days nursing homes are affordable and of a very high standard and provide a very desirable service for the aged.

I reiterate that my concern is that, our having moved away from not believing nursing homes were a desirable feature in our society to a stage where they are overutilised because of a lack of alternatives in some cases, I would hate to see a situation arise whereby we put psychological or financial obstacles in the way of people who really need nursing home care. As people get older their familiar surroundings become very much more important to them. I have had matrons of nursing homes tell me stories of elderly people whom they have moved, believing they were doing them a favour, from one bed to another-to beds which were in single rooms or which had a better aspect-and who shortly afterwards have died, not because there has been any reason for their health to decline but because a simple change of location, a loss of territory, even if that territory was only a nursing home bed, and a transplant into alien territory was more than they could cope with psychologically.

All of us who have elderly relations become more aware as they grow older of how important their own territory and familiar surroundings are to them. That is why I have said in the past that I am very attracted to the type of aged persons development referred to by the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) and the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher), which are a combination of freestanding residential accommodation, hostels and nursing homes. There was a time when I found that sort of combination a little depressing, a little distressing. It seemed to me some years ago when I was first in this field that once somebody made the move into aged persons' accommodation he was on a slowly moving escalator which took him inexorably into the nursing home and beyond. I have realised in time that that is not so and that people who go into hostel accommodation do not view it in that way at all, although it may end up being the truth for them. A variety of other things can happen as well. I have realised, on the other hand, that somebody who has been resident in a hostel and has needed nursing home care-for example, a person who has had a stroke or a serious fall which has resulted in a broken hip-because of his connection with those in the hostel and the nursing home is very much happier with the situation in which he finds himself, very much more content and very much more capable of looking after the disability because he is not transferred suddenly to alien territory.

I have learned that one of the most distressing things for the aged is to go from their own homes into nursing homes because of some health trauma. When something suddenly happens and they are uprooted from the homes in which they have lived for a very long time to what is, to them, totally alien territory, combined with a health trauma, it is a terrifying thing for them indeed. Some aged people are of sufficient independence and strength of mind that they can cope with that very well, but most cannot. I believe that type of developed accommodation is the best, except for those who really want to, and can, live successfully on their own.

The importance of familiarity of surroundings, company and friends and relief from the pressure of everyday chores are very important priorities for elderly people. For younger, more mobile and more vigorous people, and people more flexible in attitude, it is not so important. The chores of keeping home, which a younger person does without thinking, can become insufferable burdens to an elderly person. The chore of having to prepare meals, of having to do the marketing and of having to look after personal hygiene, can become overwhelming. Good evidence of that is the number of people who are admitted to nursing homes needing nursing home care who, after a couple of months on a good diet and proper supervision of their own health, hygiene and medication, no longer need the nursing home care. They may need hostel-type accommodation, where there is supervision and support, but they do not need nursing home care. I am aware that this Bill attempts to address that. I support the principles stated by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), who introduced the Bill, which were referred to earlier by the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher). I admit some small disquiet, however, with a couple of details on the first principle, which states:
Aged and disabled people should as far as possible be supported in their own homes, in their own communities.
I would have preferred the word `desirable' to be used there and that the aged were the ones who decided what was desirable. The second point relates to this passage:
Aged and disabled people should be supported by residential services only where other support systems are not appropriate to meet their needs.

I raise the question: Who decides their needs? If it is the aged and the disabled who have a free choice in making that decision, I have no difficulty with it. I strongly support the principle which states:

Services should be provided in an atmosphere and using processes which promote as far as possible rehabilitation and restoration of function. The manner in which services are provided should develop and enhance personal freedom and independent functioning of all residents.

I am nearly out of time and I shall therefore bring my comments to a conclusion. I very quickly raise a couple of points to which I do not ask the Minister to reply this evening, unless he wishes to. I raise them because I would like them to be in the minds of those people making decisions on this matter in the next year or two. The accusation has been made that many of the combined residential services that I have referred to have traditionally been middle-class establishments. I agree that that is probably so, because in order to stay in the free living accommodation people really need to have at least previously owned their own home to have enough capital. I believe there is not enough flexibility for nursing homes to add hostel accommodation. Too often either only a hostel is built or only a nursing home. It is only the much more recent establishments that have managed to combine the two, and I would like to see more of that.

The other point I flag, which was referred to very briefly by the honourable member for Lowe, is that I am sorry there is no mention of the growing problem of non-English speaking migrant aged. Many of the non-English speaking migrants who came to Australia post-war are becoming elderly and needing residential care. The very particular problems that are involved with that are becoming well known and addressed and will require special solutions. I hope that in the planning taking account of regional needs there will also be a good recognition of the fact that this need will be magnified in the next couple of years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 deals with the problems of aged people. It was announced today that the consumer price index-that is, the measure of inflation in Australia-has grown to 9 per cent per annum, or about four to five times that of other countries. Nobody suffers more from inflation, and rampant inflation, as we now have, than the elderly. I wonder how much we see of the effects that inflation has on the elderly. I well remember my parents discussing the fact that if they could save enough to guarantee their receiving ten pounds a week in their retirement, they would live very comfortably. That is within my memory. One wonders where $20 a week might go today to support an elderly person. The inflationary effects over past years have eroded the savings of retired people, who cannot get back into the work force and get indexed wages to assist them. This Government should be concerned if it believes it is going to help the elderly with a program such as this one. The reality is that inflation is killing the aged. Other countries have got to grips with inflation but this Government has not. It has failed to do so because it is the biggest spending and biggest taxing government in the history of Australia. The devaluation of our currency is not the cause of inflation; inflation and big government spending are the cause of the devaluation. Governments must realise this.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, this legislation is a positive initiative by the Government. It will assist by shifting some people back to hostel accommodation, and I certainly approve of that. However, I have to put in another word for the aged because it seems that the policies of this Government generally do not assist the aged in comparison with the young and the fit. This Government has constantly increased unemployment relief, which I think creates two problems for the young: Firstly, is discourages them from seeking work; and secondly, it is a misallocation of scarce government resources. If I had my druthers, I would always make sure the aged were well cared for ahead of the young. It is my experience that the young can protect themselves much better than people who are elderly and who are no longer able to compete in the work force.

Let us look at some of the things this Government has done to the aged. It has introduced the assets test. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) will give us his 12 millionaires speech about that. We concede that the Government caught 12 millionaires. We also know it disadvantaged 56,000 other pensioners who did not really have very much on which to support themselves other than their need to stay in the home that they had occupied for many years. What is this Bill all about? It is about keeping people in the best possible place, be it a hostel or whatever. The Government's home and community care program allows for them to be helped in their homes, but I have cases in my electorate where the Government's assets test drove people out of their family homes and forced them into other houses so that they could qualify for the pension. The lump sum superannuation tax and reductions of Commonwealth pensions are an attack-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for O'Connor may be making a valid point, but he is rather irrelevant to the Bill.

—I disagree that it is irrelevant to the Bill. A number of people today in hostels and nursing homes subject to this legislation have been put there by this Government's actions. The assets test has had the effect of driving people out of their homes. I make the point that that is very relevant to what is going on and my concern for elderly people-

—Order! The Chair cannot accept the honourable member's proposition. It is a Bill within fairly simple parameters. Whilst the honourable member may have views as to the overall situation, the Bill before the House curtails him in his remarks on a broader basis.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I will accept your ruling. This Bill increases certain payments, and we see in the second reading speech that the purpose is to put more accent on the funding of hostels as compared to nursing homes. As I said, this is where the merit of the Bill lies. People should not be put into any sort of hospital environment until they absolutely need it. At one stage I spent four months in hospital after a vehicle accident, and I agree that a hospital is a very debilitating place. It is a place where nobody wants to be unless it is absolutely necessary. We know that the cost of care in those areas is very expensive and therefore should be avoided in terms of government expenditure. Nevertheless, we have to look at how the Government is proposing to go ahead with these measures.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to raise specifically the case of a hostel in my electorate. It is all right for the Government to say that it wants hostels to be built in places of greatest need. If there are resources in certain communities to build these facilities and the local community is prepared to contribute, there is a very good reason to construct them there. This sometimes means that if a facility is not built in a `deserving area', people may move from that area to an area where the community is prepared to build these facilities.

I particularly want to draw the Minister's attention to the position in the town of Kojonup in my electorate where the community did just that-it spent $650,000, for which it received $178,000 only from the Commonwealth and $80,000 from State authorities towards that sum. It received only $178,000 of Commonwealth money because the Commonwealth told the community that it only needed 14 units. The community knew that it needed more than 14 units: First, for economies of scale, because when one goes into this more intensive area of care there is the need to employ certain people and there have to be economies of scale and utilisation of staff; and, secondly, for the advantages in terms of capital. One can add additional units without great addition to other facilities including kitchens and things of that nature. The community knew what was best. It would have liked the subsidy which still would have required a substantial amount of community contribution, as one can see from those costs. In reality, 18 of the 22 units available for elderly people are occupied; the other two being required for the staff. Over the last four years the facility has generally been full. But statistically the Minister's figures tell him that that is not necessary because the elderly do not appear to be there. When the facility was created the elderly appeared. It is not a community of great need in terms of financial capacity. It is generally a reasonably wealthy community. It is prepared to help. I believe that the Government should, on the evidence that has been presented on the occupancy rate of that hospital, come to the party and provide the funding that it would have otherwise provided for the other 10 units. At that stage it was only $120,000-$12,000 a unit. In the second reading speech the Minister says:
The Bill will also provide a mechanism for annual automatic increases--
which is good-
In addition the Government recognises that increased numbers of hostel beds will necessitate a significant strengthening of the resources available for capital funding.

These people are, of course, in the trap of having recognised the need at the time and now being ignored. Although the community has 18 elderly people in the 24 units at present, and has frequently had more than that, on 21 October it received a letter saying: `Definitely and for the last time, no, we will not assist you'. That tends to show that many of the words in the Minister's second reading speech are merely words rather than action. Apparently the money is not available. If these people were to get that assistance it would allow them to reduce the loans that were raised by the local authority for which they are paying very high interest rates as a result of this Government's inability to get interest rates down when they are so low in every other part of the world. The town of Kojonup should get better consideration than it has received. I would think that the Minister might, when he leaves this place, look at the circumstances related to that development. It was built with good faith and because the community had the sense to know that a home could not survive on 14 units and that one cannot give an economic service which is surely what government is all about.

It is interesting to see-and I guess this is relevant-that the Minister in the other place has now announced increased nursing benefits. The Minister might advise me why Western Australia, my State, gets $37 a day when his State gets $53.60 a day-there must be some evidence. He could probably tell me that it is more expensive to provide a bed in Victoria and one might ask why. We have heard of a lady in Victoria-a trade unionist-who is causing a lot of trouble in nursing homes. As one of my shire clerks, who has the responsibility for looking after nursing homes and hostels in his area, said today, the unions are now running the show and some of the benefits that are being demanded are quite ridiculous. We have to look at that.

My time is running out. I am sorry that I was not able to comment tonight on some of the other problems affecting the elderly because they are significant. It is no good the Government coming into the Parliament, arguing the goodies and saying that it is doing a great job with nursing homes when other people are being grossly disadvantaged by other Government policies. I am concerned for the elderly and I am certainly concerned that they be looked after ahead of other people in the community when it comes to the expenditure of government money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak in this debate and support the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1986. I begin by complimenting the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) and his colleague in the Senate, the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes), who put together a comprehensive program both in terms of institutional arrangements and for dealing with groups in the community. In my view our total approach to social security and community services compares very favourably with that of our predecessors. One thing that marks off this Government's approach to community care is its commitment to the needs of groups. I want to devote just a moment in this debate to the concerns of special needs groups.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill will introduce a mechanism to enable the approval of beds for special needs groups. For example, in my electorate of Stirling there is particular concern about ethnic groups. I refer to groups such as the Macedonian community in the electorate of Stirling which, under the new arrangements and ethno-specific guidelines, is a group particularly concerned to see the development of hostel accommodation for its members. That is one of the areas that we as a government are very keen to see developed. Clearly, this legislation pays attention to that. We on this side of the House believe that is very important. A view being put about in the community at the moment is that this Government is not favourably disposed to ethnic communities. Again, in my electorate of Stirling the Maurice Zeffert Memorial Home, which looks after Jewish aged people in the community, has received approval for funding. That is important in terms of support that we regard as significant.

In addition, I noted that speakers opposite have said that this Government's policies towards the aged leave something to be desired. They tended to go back to issues such as the assets test and talked about the attitudes that we developed at that time. It is important in the context of this debate to reassure the community that what this Government is about doing is directing more of its resources to the areas of greatest need. Once one begins to recognise that, one begins to see very clearly that, for example, the assets test was about taking scarce resources and providing them more specifically to areas of need. If one looks at this legislation, one sees very clearly that this Government is concerned about the effective and rational distribution of scarce resources to areas of need.

Another initiative of this Government that is important is the emphasis being given to non-institutional care. We on this side of the House believe there are effective ways of dealing with non-institutional care. This Government has given that program priority. My purpose in intervening in this debate is really to say to those who are listening to this debate that we on this side of the House are confident that we have an arrangement of policies that go a long way towards meeting the needs of the community. I also say to the community in general that we recognise that, in times of economic difficulty such as we face in this community, it is not always easy to make the best decisions and to deliver resources to those in need. But I also say that we as a government are confident that policies such as those enshrined in this legislation have been well thought through and are designed to do those things that we as a government have committed ourselves to do.

I close by saying that the intention of this Government is to continue to provide substantial policies for those groups in need. This legislation is part of that framework. As I said at the outset, the Minister for Social Security has indicated that his concern is to do that. This legislation provides substance towards that end. I am pleased to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this debate on the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill with a great deal of pleasure and interest because, as many honourable members would know, I take a particular interest in the care of aged Australians. The care of elderly Australians is a most important issue. Many matters come before this place on which we must spend a great deal of time and to which we must devote a great deal of attention. The care of elderly Australians is not a sectional matter. It is not like, say, the steel industry, the motor vehicle industry or the farming industry. It affects virtually every Australian. All of us have elderly parents or grandparents. Above all, every young Australian, including every young person listening to this debate, will end up being aged. So the problem of caring for elderly Australians is of vital and great importance.

SPEECH.PARA: I must be fair. I welcome the announcement by the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) that nursing home subsidies will be increased. However, I wonder why, when the fees were increased from 1 October, there will be a six-week hiatus before the subsidy increases. The Minister announced today that the subsidy would rise only from 13 November. There is a six-week gap. I cannot help but ask: Why so long, and why so heartless an action? We are talking about elderly Australians, very many of whom have very little income. A great many of them will have to carry the burden of the fee increase themselves. I cannot understand why the Government has imposed this six-week, cash imposition on pensioners. In my electorate office I have had many calls from people who have been stirred up and made most fearful because of this action. I do not think it is fair that elderly Australians should have this imposed on them. It is not necessary and I do not believe it is right. I would be very grateful if the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) could ask his colleague in the other place to give some form of favourable consideration to genuine cases of hardship caused by this action.

I am also a trifle concerned that, in announcing the increased subsidy, the Minister for Community Services launched into an attack on the Nursing Homes and Private Hospitals Association of Australia. In his Press release he said that the Association had conducted `a most unsavoury campaign in which the interests of nursing home residents were cruelly exploited'. He said also: `The Government has not been influenced by this scurrilous campaign'. I do not think it is right or proper that the Minister, in defence of the six-week shortfall between the fee increase and the subsidy increase, should attack the Nursing Homes Association. After all, it is trying to do the right thing by everybody.

We are talking not only about nursing homes but also about hostels. This brings me to the home and community care area. Most of us in this place agree that the longer we can keep people happily in their own homes and environment, the better. However, one of the difficulties in this is that there seems to be a danger of going overboard. One cannot have the most marvellous scheme in the world-if that is what it is; it is probably not the most marvellous scheme but it is not bad-unless one has the funding for it. One can have all the theories, all the ideas, but unless one has the funds to back them up they will not be much good.

TALK.START.PARA: —And flexibility.

—Flexibility is very important. I am concerned because, if we are going to keep people in their own homes, we cannot just say: `There you are, you are slotted in'. I speak from some experience. My parents are still alive. My mother is 82; my father is 81, and I know the sorts of things that affect and worry elderly Australians, such as how to get the lawns cut. Okay, my parents can afford to pay, but a great many pensioners cannot; all they have is the pension. How do they get the windows washed? Do they climb on a stool, a ladder or something and fall off and break a hip? All these matters are perhaps not important to the Minister for Social Security, who is sitting at the table. He has his health and his strength and he is able to get out every Sunday and mow his lawns with vigour. But we cannot really put the people I am talking about in a situation in which they will be so totally dependent on physical capacities they do not have. We have to go a bit beyond that.

SPEECH.PARA: I am also very doubtful about the proposition that nursing homes should become basically extensive care nursing homes. I think presently 30 beds out of every 100 are hostel beds and 70 are nursing home beds. If we are to make the transition to 70 hostel beds and only 30 nursing home beds, I think we will end up in very big trouble, because we will end up with nursing homes that are chock-a-block full of people who will certainly need extensive care. I think the problem of burn-out of matrons and nursing staff will become a significant one. Once that situation comes about, it will be increasingly difficult to find nurses for nursing homes and, of course, this is an area where they are needed. I think, too, that another very human point that has to be considered is the impact on the people living in the nursing homes. If there is a fairly broad spectrum of people in the homes-some who are bed-ridden, some who get extensive care and some who are well and truly ambulatory-at least there is some stimulation; we do not have everybody stuck in a bed and there is some cross-flow. In terms of the very human needs of these elderly Australians, we have to consider that particular point. It is not just a question of medical condition in respect of nursing homes. There are social conditions as well and there are, most certainly, environmental conditions.

I just cannot help but come back to this point about the six-week gap which has caused so much incredible worry for so many elderly Australians. I would like, in the time available to me, to make a plea, too, for special consideration of the integrated approach to caring for our elderly Australians-the situation where we have at least a hostel and a nursing home together. Very often it would be preferable-there are some outstanding instances of this in my electorate of Cowper-for there to be retirement units, a hostel and a nursing home together. This would mean that, if there were a need to go into a nursing home, it need not be a total change of environment and people would be able to make the transition. For heaven's sake, we have to look at the proposition of people being able to come back out of nursing homes. Again, it is very helpful if they can do it in the same environment.

I would like also to particularly ask the Minister-if he cannot answer this question now I would be grateful if he could pursue it-about funding for new retirement villages or new units at existing ones. I am told that the amendments mean that there will be no further funding for new retirement villages or increases in the number of units at existing ones-that funding will cease under this Bill. I hope that this is not the case, but I would like to know because there is a lot of doubt out in the community. The second point is that we should also have some reassurance on the funding position of existing retirement villages, because people need to know whether that will continue too. I think it is very appropriate when talking about nursing home beds and the cost-and, of course, the Government naturally is concerned about the recurrent cost of nursing home beds, not just the capital cost-that it should be remembered that to keep somebody in an ordinary hospital costs four to five times the cost of caring for an elderly person in a nursing home. I pay tribute to the nursing homes and hostels which operate throughout my electorate of Cowper. A number of them are community based and a number are privately owned. To my personal knowledge, all of them are doing an excellent job. I refer to nursing homes and hostels in Wauchope, Port Macquarie, Kempsey, Macksville, Bellingen and Coffs Harbour. We should be working to assist them to continue doing an excellent job.

In conclusion I would just like to say that every elderly Australian deserves a fair go. It is probably fair to say that this Government can be castigated for its attitude to the aged. I will not go into details on the assets test as the Minister for Social Services (Mr Howe) knows how I feel about that. However, I refer to the delay of the flow-on of the consumer price index increase in the pension for six weeks. Elderly Australians who are on the pension should not be short changed because after all they have very little change left.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight because the matter of nursing homes in the electorate of Gilmore has been one of the biggest issues over the last few weeks. It has been brought to my attention because of the large number of telephone calls, letters and visits from concerned constituents of mine. They have all gone on about the tremendous increase in the price of nursing home accommodation for patients. Because of that I have taken a particular interest in nursing homes and have put myself on the speakers list tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: The original speech that I proposed to give tonight was going to be severely critical of the Government for not raising the subsidy for nursing home accommodation by an amount equal to the recent increases that patients in nursing homes have had to undergo. The announcement by the Minister for Social Services (Mr Howe) in the last few minutes that the Government has decided that there will be an increase in the subsidy is very welcome. I know that in the electorate of Gilmore many people will sleep a little easier tonight because they will now be able to continue to afford either to be a patient in a nursing home or to have a spouse, relative or friend as a patient in a nursing home.

In the Press release that was delivered this evening by the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) I noted, as did the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), that the increase in the subsidy for nursing home accommodation will take place as of 13 November. As the honourable member for Cowper has pointed out, this represents a six weeks' delay in the catch-up between the cost increase and the cost compensation. Six weeks seems to be a very notable period in relation to this Government because as of 1 November all pensioners in Australia will be subject to a six-week delay in the implementation of their pension increases. In the case of a single pensioner I understand that will cost $49 and in the case of a married couple around $84. This delay, coupled with the fact that the inflation rates are increasing--

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member is rather getting away from the Bill. I ask him to come back to it.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I was just relating how recent inflation rates-
—Order! The honourable member was called to order on that very issue.

—As I was saying, the people in the electorate of Gilmore have been very concerned. Now that the Government has decided to announce an increase in the subsidy they will certainly rest a little easier, but the point I make tonight is that the six weeks delay in the implementation of the increase will mean that many nursing home residents in my electorate will suffer a financial loss. From reading some of the correspondence I have received over the last few weeks, I estimate that many of the residents in nursing homes will lose, as a result of the delay in the increase, about $250. The sum of $250 may not seem a lot of money to honourable members, but I can assure them that it is a lot of money to people on very limited incomes. For example, one of my constituents, a lady living in a nursing home in the Shoalhaven district, for the last few weeks has been drawing on her funeral fund to meet the shortfall between her pension and the cost of staying in the nursing home. I also know another gentleman who has a total life savings of $337.77 and who has been drawing on those meagre savings to meet the shortfall. Because of the delay that the Government is imposing on people in nursing homes, it will not make up the shortfall and the people concerned will be much the worse off financially.

SPEECH.PARA: In speaking of nursing homes, it is important to mention that I have a particular problem in a nursing home in Crookwell, the Harley Nursing Home. Unfortunately, a few years ago the proprietors of the nursing home received a shortfall in payments from the Department of Community Services. Recently that shortfall has been detected and the Government has promised to make good that sum. But to find the funding for that shortfall a special loading has been imposed on the residents of the home to try to make up the difference. I find this extraordinary. It means that if somebody in the Department of Community Services makes a mistake in payments to a nursing home proprietor, if that mistake is found, the people who eventually end up paying for it are not the Government but the residents of the nursing home. I have brought this matter to the attention of the Minister for Community Services, and I know that he is investigating the matter seeking to ascertain how this illogical situation could have developed. But as a result of the development, patients have been paying $29.15 a day over and above the Government subsidy at the Harley Nursing Home. A sum of $29.15 is certainly more than a pensioner can afford. I hope that as a result of the representations I have made to the Minister for Community Services and the mention of it in this debate tonight the Government will be able to sort out this illogical situation at the Harley Nursing Home.

Australia is going towards an aging population. Because of that, I believe that the issue of nursing homes will become more important in our society. As parliamentarians we shall be dealing with this issue more and more frequently. In discussing the growing aging population, I mention the district of Culburra in the Shoalhaven region. The sum of $800,000 has just been graciously and gratefully received from the Government for the funding of hostel accommodation at Culburra. The Government has decided to provide this funding because it recognises that there is a very large aging population in Culburra. It is a rapid growth district, with 17 per cent growth per annum. Culburra's environment attracts elderly people, and though the Government recognises a need for hostel accommodation, to date it has refused to recognise the need for nursing home accommodation. I suggest that if there is a need for hostel accommodation today, as surely as night follows day-as another member would say-there will be a need for nursing home accommodation in future in Culburra. I have made representations to the Minister on this point and I hope that he will heed my words. If he wishes to do justice to the citizens of Culburra and to the people of the Shoalhaven district, it is a must that a nursing home be constructed at Culburra in that geographically isolated district.

The people of Culburra have organised themselves extremely well. It has a community health committee headed by Fred Evans, and over the years it has been responsible for ensuring the health of all the people in Culburra. It has raised hundreds of thousands of dollars and that money, added to the $800,000-odd which the Government will provide, will help to fund and build a worthwhile retirement complex. The Culburra Community Health Committee will be a worthy recipient of any funds towards building a nursing home facility in that district. The whole issue of caring for the aged-whether it be through pension payments or the provision of hostel accommodation, home and community care facilities or nursing homes-will be of ever-growing importance to this Parliament and the people of Australia. This Government and future governments must ensure that they give high priority to this issue, because if they do not they will be dealing with our elderly people in a most unsatisfactory fashion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable members from both sides of the House who have contributed, with the exception of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), to an extremely amicable debate in which there has been broad agreement about the principles involved in the legislation. A number of speakers from both sides of the House have referred favourably to the legislation. A number of honourable members referred to the delay in the nursing home benefit increases. Let me simply say that the increases announced today were on schedule, that they have been announced each year by governments of whatever political persuasion at around this time to coincide with the November payment of indexation increases. The announcement of the lifting of the freeze on nursing home benefits in Victoria, South Australia and the Northern Territory reflects the negotiations that have taken place with those States with respect to staffing levels.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Petrie (Mr Hodges) referred to some concerns about population increases in the future resulting in a lack of sufficient beds in nursing homes. There is no basis to that argument. While restricting the growth of nursing home beds-with emphasis on `growth'-the Government is expanding the number of hostel beds, and of course it is developing the home and community care program and the provision of services within the community. A combination of all these measures will mean that we will have adequate accommodation for those who choose it. I emphasise the aspect of choice because this was referred to by an Opposition member. The terms of my second reading speech may not reflect it, but it is Government policy to maximise choice for the aged. That is why we have sought to provide a greater range of accommodation and services.

Several Opposition members referred to the need to give the public a voice in the planning of aged care services and to ensure that needs of remote country areas are recognised and met. The Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) has announced his intention to establish aged care advisory committees to advise him on the planning priorities for the distribution of new residential places between regions and to advise him with respect to special needs groups in each State or Territory, including advice on the needs in rural areas. In addition to representatives of Commonwealth, State and local governments, these advisory committees will comprise representatives of both service providers and service consumers, thus ensuring a public voice in the planning process.

The honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) raised the question of consultation between the Commonwealth and the States with respect to the variation in fee levels between States, which, of course, in turn-as the honourable member for O'Connor said-reflects different staffing standards that have been established in different States. Those standards have arisen not to create a conspiracy against the people of Western Australia but as a reflection of the different traditions that have operated in different States. That has been a matter of concern to the Commonwealth, which has put some pressure on those States with higher staffing levels. We believe that substantial agreement has been achieved as a result of the discussions that have taken place on future standards, and that has resulted in the freeze being lifted in those States.

I conclude by thanking honourable members on both sides of the House who have contributed to this debate. The Government is very concerned to achieve a comprehensive policy for the aged and aged services. We have seen support for this policy from many members of the House tonight and that reflects well on the Minister for Community Services, the processes of consultation, and the research and reports that have preceded this Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Having regard to the late hour I will keep my remarks on these amendments very brief. The amendments which have been circulated in my name are seconded by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 4, page 2, line 25, proposed new paragraph 9 (1) (b), after ``Secretary'' insert ``certifies, in writing, that the Secretary''.
(2) Clause 4, page 2, at the end of the clause add the following proposed sub-sections:

`` `(4) Each certificate under paragraph 9 (1) (b) and each determination under sub-section (3) shall be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the certificate or the determination, as the case may be, is signed by the Secretary.

`(5) If either House of the Parliament, within 20 sitting days of that House after a certificate or a determination has been laid before that House, passes a resolution disallowing the certificate or the determination, the certificate or the determination, as the case may be, shall be void and of no effect.

`(6) If neither House of the Parliament passes a resolution in accordance with sub-section (5) disallowing a certificate or a determination, the certificate or the determination, as the case may be, commences to have effect on the day immediately following the last day upon which such a resolution in respect of the certificate or the determination could have been passed by either House.'.''.

These amendments relate to clause 4 of the Bill, which amends clause 9 of the principal Act. They relate to a decision of the Government to implement a recommendation of the Nursing Homes and Hostels Review Report, which enables the Minister to provide up to 100 per cent of capital funding for certain categories of nursing homes and hostels for certain groups in the community, in particular ethnic groups, Aborigines and other disadvantaged people. The intention of the amendments is to provide for the certificates to be given under this clause to be tabled before the Parliament, to lie on the table and be subject to disallowance. We believe that in the granting of capital funding in this area it is appropriate for there to be public and parliamentary scrutiny of the Minister's decisions, the amount of funds to be granted, and the groups to which those funds are to be given.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept the Opposition's amendments. I understand that the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) has confined his remarks very briefly. I guess that there may be further opportunities to discuss the principle behind the amendments in another place. We believe that the carriage of the amendments would result in substantial delays-perhaps up to six months-as a result of the proposed procedures. The intention of the Government is to liberalise the legislation in order to help disadvantaged groups in the current year, with particular focus on the needs of remote Aboriginal communities. Nevertheless, in other years there will no doubt be focus on migrant groups and other very disadvantaged groups in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the fourteenth report from the Publications Committee sitting in conference with the Publications Committee of the Senate. Copies of the report have been circulated to honourable members in the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Report-by leave-adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report, incorporating two dissenting reports, together with the minutes of proceedings from the Committee of Privileges relating to the disruption caused to the work of the electorate office of the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) by telephone calls made in response to false advertisements in the Sydney Morning Herald of 20 September 1986, referred to the Committee by the House on 23 September 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report deals with the disruption caused to the work of the electorate office of the honourable member for Wentworth as a result of telephone calls made in response to false advertisements placed in the Sydney Morning Herald of 20 September 1986. In accordance with established practice, the honourable member drew this matter to the attention of the House and it was subsequently referred to the Committee for consideration. The Committee is mindful of the effect of the unwanted telephone calls on the work of the honourable member's electorate office and has an appreciation of the disruption suffered. It believes that harassment of a member in the performance of his or her work as a member by means of repeated, nuisance or orchestrated telephone calls could be judged a contempt and members must be able to seek the protection of the House in such matters.

SPEECH.PARA: However, bearing in mind the general reluctance to extend the ambit of parliament's penal jurisdiction, the Committee has concluded that in all the circumstances in the present case further action would be inconsistent with the dignity of the House. The Committee does not recommend that any further action be taken by the House on the matter.

The Committee also draws attention to the fact that it is now over two years since the final report of the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege was presented. It is the view of this Committee that a high priority should be accorded to consideration of the Joint Committee's recommendations and decisions made which will serve to guide the House, committees and members and others involved in the work of Parliament in these important matters. I thank the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I thank the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) and the Committee of Privileges for the time that they have given to this matter which was referred to them by Madam Speaker, but I have to say that I am disappointed in the report as outlined by the honourable member for Canning. It says that the harassment of my staff could be judged a contempt but that further action would be inconsistent with the dignity of the House. It seems to me that the Committee could have done better than say it could be judged a contempt. It is either a contempt or it is not. If it is a contempt, the lack of further action is inconsistent with the dignity of this House. In that respect I am disappointed with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The essence of the complaint in reference was the harassment not so much of the member personally, because I was not personally harassed being in Canberra at the time, but the harassment of the staff. That sort of harassment of staff as a result of the placing of false advertisements deliberately-advertisements which were politically motivated as well as being deliberately placed-leads to the more serious forms of harassment of staff that we know about, certainly in these times. I do not need to go as far as to refer to terrorism, but we all know the sorts of times that we live in. I would have thought that this Government and this Committee would have been concerned with the welfare of our employees who, when we are in Canberra, are left entirely without protection and are very easily subject to this sort off harassment. The device used on this occasion is a very simple device which could be used in respect of any member of this House and the staffs of any member of this House.

I think this report can be described only as wimpish. It tends to reduce this important parliamentary committee to the level of, let us say, the Australian Journalists Association Ethics Committee, and everyone knows that that is a completely worthless committee. One would have hoped that this parliamentary Committee would have done better than it has done. I agree with the honourable member for Canning that the important report of the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege to which he referred should be considered. However, I am afraid I have to say that if the Committee puts in reports of this wimpish kind it is not surprising that that important report does not get the priority that it should get.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Saturday, 1 November a valedictory dinner is to be held at Broken Hill for a great educator to that city and of the State of New South Wales. That person is Mr Jack Misson, the principal of the Burke Ward School at Broken Hill. Honourable members will note that Saturday, 1 November is All Saints Day. I know that Jack would be embarrassed, but I am sure that many people of Broken Hill, including the parents, teachers and students of the Burke Ward School, or any- body who has been taught by him, consider him to be a saint of education. Jack and Judy Misson have six children, so they have a great experience of the care of children outside the school environment. Jack was educated by the Christian Brothers in Wagga Wagga, has taught for 39 years and served for three years in the armed forces. Jack has been at the Burke Ward School for 14 years and during that time he has earned for himself a reputation second to none as an educator in that great city. He is a wonderful teacher, a man of understanding and compassion and a man of discipline, but always a gentle man; and that is reflected by the standards of the Burke Ward School. Any principal who went to Burke Ward School would have a job ahead maintaining those standards, such are the high principles that the school always maintains.

SPEECH.PARA: One of Jack Misson's great passions is swimming. He plays a good game of billiards and snooker and cricket. In his early days he coached a number of cricketers, including such famous names as Lawson and Rixon. He is a life member of the Primary School Sports Association in Broken Hill; he is Secretary-Treasurer of the Royal Life Saving Association; and he spends many hours teaching young people life saving. He coaches netball.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great citizen.

—He is certainly a great citizen of Broken Hill and a great citizen of the State of New South Wales. Jack and Judy have not enjoyed the best of health over the past few years. The citizens of Broken Hill would not know that because of the many activities they are always engaged in. They are a team, and that team will retire from teaching on 18 December. I am sure that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and all members of this House will wish Jack and Judy a long, happy and healthy retirement. The people of Broken Hill want to join the parents, teachers, staff and, most of all, the pupils of the Burke Ward School in saying to Jack: `To sir, with love'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cross Mr M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) referred to a valedictory dinner that is to be held on 1 November; in Queensland we will have a valedictory election on that night because the election of 1 November will mark the demise of the Bjelke-Petersen National Party Government. That Government, formerly in coalition with the Liberal Party, has had for a number of years the overwhelming objective of being able to govern in its own right. This, of course, was a fatal mistake. Since 1960 the National Party-Liberal Party coalition enjoyed more than 50 per cent of the vote and the Australian Labor Party was in a minority position.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the last three years the National Party Government, with 38.9 per cent of the vote, has been clearly exposed as a minority, autocratic government. In Queensland's more recent redistribution, boundaries were created which would enable that Government to govern with 34 or 35 per cent of the vote. This election is being fought on fundamental issues. The issue in Queensland-something which the enormous resources which the National Party has from the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation can do nothing about-related to decay, decline, cronyism, corruption and all of those other aspects of the Queensland Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker.

—I will hear the honourable member for Groom on his point of order.

—It has become clearly obvious to the electors of Queensland, as it has to all the people of Australia in recent times, that the issues involved in the Queensland election are fundamental. SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —At a time when the Labor Government is promoting the cause of a deregulated exchange rate and is even conceding that the Opposition's policy of a more flexible wages system is appropriate, I wish to draw the House's attention to a paper delivered by the Attorney-General for Victoria, the Hon. Jim Kennan, to the eighth annual conference of the Australian Society of Labor Lawyers. As honourable members will be aware, a paper delivered in this forum would have attitudes and beliefs based on a socialistic approach to any problems arising in the corporate arena. At a time when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the trade union movement have been calling for businessmen to invest and take risks, we have the situation where the Labor Attorney-General in Victoria is putting forward proposals in a completely opposite direction.

SPEECH.PARA: In Australia, where there is a low level of individual ownership of shares, approximately 7 per cent compared with 18 per cent in the United States of America, it is important to encourage individual small capitalists to take a stake in Australia's future. Coupled with this commitment to the corporate future of Australia, investors are requesting that the managers and directors of their corporations show entrepreneurial flair and exercise their choice in taking business risks. Any government regulations that bear down on both directors' and management's incentive to exploit commercial opportunities on behalf of their shareholders needs to be rejected before the dead hand of regulation strangles Australian Industry to a position of no growth and no investment.

The Attorney-General in Victoria, however, spends a great amount of time in his address to the Labor lawyers, concentrating on the role of the small shareholder and the responsibilities of directors and management to `the local and national economy and employment, social and environmental conditions in the areas in which their companies operate'. He quite rightly suggests that the directors are constrained only by the market and whatever obligations are imposed by law. Those people who have been in the private sector fully understand the rigours of the market-place and the risks that companies undertake in pursuit of profits in the knowledge that there will be no big brother government to bail them out. The Victorian Attorney-General goes to great pains to suggest that it is almost a commercial wrongdoing that management has a great say in the fortune of the company that it manages. It would seem a most desirable objective of both the directors and management of any public or private company to optimise the wealth of the company and maintain its profitability for the benefit of shareholders.

What has not been written into the paper is the negative force of union power, the destructive use of restrictive work practices and the trade union movement's total disregard for profit. In the area of capital and security markets, the Victorian Attorney-General concedes that the capital markets are efficient and accessible methods of realising capital moneys to small shareholders. However, he takes the rather more sinister view that:
They can easily be distorted, they have an inherent tendency toward volatility and provide opportunities for manipulation and fraud.

The general thrust of his remarks was to suggest that by increasing regulations and more legislation, these tendencies could be overcome. Nothing could be further from the truth in that no amount of legislation will ensure that correct decisions are made in the market-place and that honesty will prevail at all times. Only today we see an example of international trading taking place on a basis of trust and understanding between share traders on both sides of the globe. The Sydney Futures Exchange and the London International Financial Futures Exchange have made history this morning when they began trading in United States Treasury futures contracts. This innovation will ensure a trading link between traders to hedge and trade United States `T' bonds for 17 hours each day while the United States markets are shut. Imagine introducing Victorian State legislation to control these sorts of international activities.

In a typically socialistic approach, the Labor lawyers wish to assess how responsibility can be imposed on directors and managers of companies to measure it with their economic and social power and to re-assess the duties and obligations which a director and a manager should owe the shareholders of the company. He wants more information and, of course, the share markets and financial markets are now overwhelmed with information to a position of excess. He suggests that, in some amazing manner, the market should not be distorted by any extraordinary event. Of course, if he was able to achieve this, he would not be in the Parliament but would be a millionaire because of his forecasting and market skills.

The general thrust of the paper was to suggest that both managers and directors take their full legal responsibility and be accountable in law. Whilst the paper conceded that this might be difficult, it suggested it was a desirable outcome. At a time when the Labor lawyers are trying to regulate Australian industry, a recommendation is coming forward to the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities that the salaries of senior executives be disclosed. This is a gross invasion of privacy by the public in the affairs of the individual managers and the companies concerned. If Australia is to progress, it needs managers of calibre, prepared to take risks and be accountable to shareholders for their actions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, 22 October, was a very important day for the peace movement in Australia and a very important day for the issue of peace and disarmament. This was the day the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) presented the Australian peace awards to many Australians who have contributed so much to the cause of peace, and several of them over a great length of time. The Government, and the Prime Minister in particular, wanted to ensure that the work of these dedicated people be acknowledged in International Year of Peace. More importantly though, most of the recipients represent a wide cross-section of the community, and their individual awards are a recognition of the active involvement of those thousands of ordinary Australians who are committed to peace and committed to the task of eliminating nuclear weapons and achieving a world free from the threat of nuclear war.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to offer my personal congratulations to the recipients of the awards, most of whom were guests of the Prime Minister and Mrs Hawke at the Lodge yesterday. Time will not permit me to name everyone, but I would like to mention just a few: The Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace; Bill Gollan, someone I have known personally for a long time and who was working for peace when `peace' was considered a dirty word; the Reverend Dorothy McMahon; the Medical Association for the Prevention of War; Dr Ian Newman, for his work in the scientific community around nuclear disarmament; the Peace Bus; the Peace Publications Co-operative; Peter Jones from the Quakers; Dr Keith Suter, former President of the United Nations Association (Australia), now heading the Peace Research Institute in Western Australia; the Wollongong City Council, which has initiated many local peace projects in the city of Wollongong.

In congratulating the recipients of these awards I want to pay a special tribute to the Peace Bus project, one which has had many enthusiastic supporters, including me, since its launch in October 1984. The story of the Peace Bus is one of great interest and one of great success. It is also one of co-operation between the originators of the project, People for Nuclear Disarmament in Sydney, and the New South Wales State Government, or more precisely, the New South Wales Premier Barrie Unsworth, who, when Minister for Transport, made it possible for PND to get access to an old government bus in a reasonable and safe condition. The Bus was purchased by raising funds, by sponsorship and by donations. People who contributed to the project came from across the political spectrum. Free information available on the Bus has been provided by each of the political parties-the Australian Labor Party, Liberal Party of Australia, National Party of Australia and the Australian Democrats. The information outlines the disarmament policies of each of the parties, and it is this material which is much sought after by visitors to the Bus.

The Peace Bus had its critics in October 1984; I am sure it has very few critics in October 1986. Since its drive for disarmament started, the Peace Bus has travelled to shopping centres, surfing carnivals, schools, universities, colleges, councils, and even Parliament House. Young people in particular are attracted to the project. They join the Bus wherever it goes and are very interested in the material that is always available. The videos on board are very popular and many of them have been reviewed by the New South Wales Department of Education as suitable viewing for high school students. A grant from IYP funds has allowed the Bus to embark on a national tour taking in southern New South Wales, Canberra, Melbourne and two months spent in South Australia.

People for Nuclear Disarmament saw this tour as a way to reach those Australians who have not had access to available material on the issues of peace and disarmament and as a way to encourage them to take an active part in preserving our future. In South Australia it was so successful that bookings had to be turned away. This week, the Bus is in Newcastle. The rest of October is heavily booked, with a visit to Grafton for the Jacaranda Festival. In November it will visit Sydney suburban high schools, it will visit Lithgow and Katoomba, and at the end of November it will be in Coffs Harbour.

The Peace Bus celebrates life and brings peace to the attention of thousands of Australians. If nuclear disarmament is to be achieved, it is up to the Peace Bus and other educational projects to raise the issue everywhere. I congratulate everyone involved in this project, and I congratulate the IYP Peace Awards Committee, which recognised the importance of the Peace Bus project.

In closing, I would just like to say that Australia has led the world in IYP activities. Australian community initiatives for IYP have been commended by the United Nations as giving a lead to the rest of the world. This is a clear indication of the Australian community's desire for peace and disarmament and the Labor Government's commitment to the achievement of that goal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter which concerns the safety of my constituents. I refer to the crayfishing industry which operates within my electorate and offshore from my electorate, particularly around the town of Geraldton. I am speaking specifically about the need for certain organisations to have access to direct radio frequencies, and in particular the frequencies 4620 and 4535, which are the general fishing frequencies for that area. The problem is that although these frequencies are available in certain areas they often are not available to people such as engine repairers and engine providers who need them to assist fishermen in emergencies. I specifically refer to the application by Wigmores Tractors Pty Ltd, which is the agent for Caterpillar engines in Western Australia and operates a repair facility in Geraldton. Since 24 October 1985 it has been seeking the right to operate these frequencies not as some spare parts convenience or selling medium but on a 24-hour call basis for fishermen who operate in extremely hazardous circumstances along the reefs, where they catch the crayfish that are their living. For some unknown reason, the Department of Communications has consistently rejected this application, as it has in a higher area for the Gantheaume Bay Fisheries, which also needs this type of assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is that the Department keeps saying that the service of the Overseas Telecommunications Commission is suitable in these situations when it is not. Fishermen can contact anybody on land through the telephone service offered by OTC by calling one of the coastal stations of OTC on the radio. This is frequently very difficult because of the power of the fishermen's sets but, more importantly, it is difficult because there is static and other interruptions. Having contacted the OTC, the OTC then has to make a telephone connection to the person the fisherman wants to contact, and this can take up to 20 minutes. I am suggesting that if the engine has failed and the fisherman needs specialist advice to restart the crayfish boat-these circumstances do occur-the rocks are getting closer and closer and 20 minutes is a little too long. He could be drowned in that time. If he were able to use the radio frequency to contact the repairer directly there would be an excellent chance of getting the information necessary to re-start the motor and get out of trouble. These situations have occurred. The professional fishermen's association in Geraldton has given strong support to this application, which is necessary to save people's lives.

I am disappointed. I have contacted the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) and I have received a response, but the fishing season starts again in Geraldton on 15 November and for the third year running Wigmores Tractors has been unable to get this frequency. I repeat that it does not want it for promoting its business; it does not want to put out early morning calls saying `Caterpillar is great'; it wants it to service people in emergencies and it is prepared to spend the money to do so. The other organisation I mentioned, Gantheaume Bay Fisheries, has another need. It has excellent export orders helping Australia's balance of payments with fresh fish. It too cannot get from OTC the service necessary to advise the shore-based station of the quantities of fresh fish that are coming in. It has to handle the fish with great speed and get them away in chiller trucks, and I think it too has sufficient argument to warrant the service and the direct access.

I do not want to say that OTC does not provide a good service in normal circumstances, but the Department of Communications should have more sense and recognise these areas of safety and specific need, particularly in relation to fresh fish which is an export commodity and has to make airline connections to Japan. I ask the Minister to respond very quickly and to get his Department to provide these frequencies to ensure people's safety in servicing Australia's export industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —The newspapers throughout the nation today have carried headlines that tell us how a trustee of the National Party of Australia, Sir Roderick Proctor, has made some major revelations-
—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am very conscious of the fact that you conveyed information to me and warned me, but I am advised-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr McVeigh

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised by the Clerk that it is my prerogative at any time to move, in relation to the question that the House do now adjourn, that the question be now put. I move:

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being past 11 p.m., the debate is interrupted.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I require the debate to be extended.
—The debate may be continued until 11.10 p.m. I call the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to extend the debate because we have just seen the following situation in the House. The honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Cross) was making serious and important allegations. He was continuously interrupted by a series of points of order. Then the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), who also wanted to exercise his rights within the adjournment debate, found himself--

—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. If you care to look at sessional order 48a you will find that the responsibility of a Minister is to respond to a matter that has been canvassed during the adjournment debate. Unfortunately, the matter that is being answered by the Minister is not a matter within sessional order 48a. I suggest to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that it is entirely out of order and you should be required to adjourn the House forthwith.

—There is no point of order. The Chair has not yet heard what the Minister was about to address himself to. If the right honourable member for New England will resume his seat, the Chair may be able to hear it.

—The honourable member for Brisbane rose to speak on corruption within the Queensland Government. He was continuously interrupted by specious points of order. When the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) rose he made it perfectly clear that he was speaking on the question--
—Why are you--
—Why are you trying to hide corruption?
—You are trying to hide corruption. Tell us about the Richmond Council.
—I would be very happy to.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order.
—Order! The right honourable member for New England will resume his seat. The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat.
—Why don't you sit there and write some cheques for Daddy?
—The Minister is entirely out of order, and you know it, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—Order! The right honourable member for New England will cease interjecting.
—He is out of order, though.
—The right honourable member for New England will cease interjecting. The honourable member for O'Connor rose on a point of order.
—I would like the Minister to resume his seat under standing order 99. The point of order is--
—I had better sit down or he will hit me with an iron bar or maybe a handle bar. That's what he goes in for.
—Well, we will talk about your robbing the Richmond Council, you crook and you cheat, if you want to talk about iron bars.
—The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat.
—I am on a point of order. I have not dealt with my point of order; I dealt with the interjection.
—The honourable member will not deal with the interjections, or the Chair will deal with him.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I would ask that the Minister not interject when I am trying to take a point of order.
—What is your point of order?

—My point of order is that the Minister is allowed to rise only on a matter related to his portfolio and which has been referred to during the adjournment debate. No matters related to the Minister's responsibilities were raised.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—If he wants to talk about corruption--
—The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat.
—The honourable member for Capricornia raised the question of corruption in the--
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I move dissent from your ruling.
—The right honourable member for New England will resume his seat.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, you said `There is no point of order' and I suggest to you that that is a ruling.
—The Minister has the call.
—I have moved dissent from the ruling that there is no point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—That is not a ruling; that is a statement of fact. I call the Minister.
—The question of corruption by the Queensland Government has now become a matter of national scandal, and that scandal will be brought out. The question has been raised and I will not be--
—We will talk about the Treasurer--
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat.

—I will not be silenced by these gentlemen who are concerned to hide corruption. The honourable member opposite was a local council crook. He always has been and he will continue to be. Why are these gentlemen behaving in this way?

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The right honourable member for New England, of all people, should know, seeing that he quite readily draws the attention of the House to the Standing Orders, that one of them states that a member shall not interrupt the Chair while the Chair is attempting to address the House. Honourable members do themselves no good with this disruptive type of performance. The Minister is attempting to address the Chair. He is within the Standing Orders. The right honourable member for New England also knows that there is no substance in his pretension that dissent can be moved against what I said. The Minister has the call. However, I advise the House that if honourable members continue with these disruptive practices I will adjourn the House forthwith until 2 p.m. on Tuesday, 11 November. I call the Minister.
—Mr Deputy Speaker--

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Sinclair) proposed:
That the honourable member be not further heard.
Grave disorder occurring-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House stands adjourned until 2 p.m. on Tuesday, 11 November 1986, in accordance with the provisions of standing order 40 as amended for this session; and I might say that honourable members should all be ashamed of themselves.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications the following question, upon notice, on 21 August 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact, as reported in the Melbourne Herald of 25 June 1986, that the ABC has settled an action by the Prime Minister who had claimed he had been defamed by the ABC in that the Corporation had imputed that he had improperly disclosed confidential matters.
(2) How much was the Prime Minister paid pursuant to the settlement with the ABC.
(3) Is the sum paid exempt from capital gains tax.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The following answer to the honourable member's question is based on information provided by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) No damages were paid to the Prime Minister. Costs of $4,699.65 were paid directly to the Prime Minister's legal advisers.
(3) No capital gains tax is applicable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 7 October 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the life saving equipment carried by Qantas and other airlines for use at sea saved lives following a crash; if so, can he provide instances?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Since the beginning of 1960 there have been three accidents involving Australian airline aircraft which crashed into water or at sea. Two accidents occurred in 1960, one near Mackay QLD and one east of the entrance to Sydney Harbour. The third accident occurred in Botany Bay in 1961. None of these aircraft was operated by Qantas Airways Pty Ltd. In these accidents all persons on board the aircraft were fatally injured and the accidents were considered non-survivable.
